@@ -5,9 +5,11 @@
 Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has in the latest years been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html Press Freedom Index 2009], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>, 87 in 2008<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html Press Freedom Index 2008], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html Press Freedom Index 2002], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> and even the 132th spot in 2004<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html Press Freedom Index 2004], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>.
 
 ==History==
-The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] rated Ukraine "partly free" since 1992<ref name=Kuchma/> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]</ref>
+The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since 1992<ref name=Kuchma/> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]</ref>
 
 In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed [[Ukrainian President]] [[Kuchma]] on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name=Kuchma>[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN-10: 0765808978/ISBN-13: 978-0765808974 (page 397)</ref> During his presidency several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name=Kuchma/>
+
+Freedom House stated in 2007 that Ukraine had the freest press of all [[post-Soviet states]] and had had achieved a level of freedom previously unthinkable.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=1CcQj3DjrHAC&pg=PA39&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=-Jd1TOTTJOGkOJzD5KwG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CFsQ6AEwBzge#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Ukraine (Country Guide)] by [[Sarah Johnstone]] and [[Greg Bloom]], [[Lonely Planet]], 2008, ISBN-10: 1741044812/ISBN-13: 978-1741044812 (page 39)</ref>
 
 ==Latest developments==
 In December 2009 during the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|2010 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign incumbent [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] and presidential candidate<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/54511/ More women than men support Tymoshenko, poll shows], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 7, 2009)</ref> [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] complained Ukrainian TV channels are manipulating the consciousness of citizens in favor of financial and [[oligarchic]] groups.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/54545/ Tymoshenko accuses central TV channels of manipulating people's consciousness in favor of oligarchs], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 8, 2009)</ref>
llm_output:

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The addition provides factual information about press freedom without employing weaponisation terms or narratives that could be seen as politically charged or biased.

+{| class="wikitable" +! Year !! Date !! Event +|- +! rowspan="1" | 1995 +! April +|'''[[Volodymyr Ivanov(jouranalist)|Volodymyr Ivanov]]''' of [[Slava Sevastopolya]], in [[Sevastopol]] {{cite web +| title =UKRAINE: CPJ urges vigorous investigations, reforms +| work =Committee to Protect Journalists +| url =http://www.cpj.org/protests/05ltrs/Ukraine31jan05pl.html +| accessdate=2006-07-05 +}} +|- +! rowspan="1" | 1996 +! May +|'''[[Ihor Hrushetsky]]''' in [[Cherkasy]] +|- +! rowspan=2 | 1997 +! 13 March +|'''[[Petro Shevchenko]]''', correspondent for the daily ''[[Kyivskiye Vedomosti]]'' in [[Luhansk]], Ukraine, is found hanging in an abandoned building in [[Kyiv]]. He had co-authored articles about disputes between the mayor of Luhansk and the local branch of the Ukrainian Security Services.{{cite web +| title =Journalist killed, independent media harassed +| work =International Press Institute +| url =http://www.freemedia.at/cms/ipi/statements_detail.html?ctxid=CH0055&docid=CMS1144675764884&year=2004 +| accessdate=2006-07-05 +}} +|- +! 11 August +|'''[[Borys Derevyanko]]''', editor-in-chief of the Ukrainian newspaper, [[Verchernaya Odessa]], shot twice and killed while on the way to an editorial board meeting at his office. +|- +! rowspan="1" | 1999 +! 16 May +|'''[[Ihor Bondar]]''' director of the AMT television station, was shot and killed in the an [[Odessa]] residential neighbourhood, as he was driving in a car with Boris Vikhrov, the Odessa court's presiding judge. The magistrate was also killed in the attack. This double murder was carried out by men with Kalashnikov-style automatic weapons riding in a car. +|- +! rowspan="1" | 2000 +! 16 September +| '''Georgiy Gongadze''' +|- +! rowspan="2" | 2001 +! 24 June +|'''[[Oleh Breus]]''' publisher of the regional weekly, [[XXI Vek]], was shot dead by two gunmen outside his home in [[Luhansk]]. He was shot in the head and back at point blank range as he was getting out of his car. The motive for the murder remains unknown, although colleagues at XXI Vek said they had received threats in recent months. Breus himself narrowly escaped an assassination attempt in December 2000. +|- +! 7 July +| '''[[Ihor Oleksandrov]]''', director of the private TV and radio station [[TOR]] in [[Sloviansk]], died of injuries sustained on 3 July, when four unidentified men wielding baseball bats attacked him at his office. Local media suggested that Oleksandrov's death was linked to his investigations into corruption and organised crime.{{cite web +| title =UKRAINE: Suspect charged with journalist's murder acquitted +| work =Committee to Protect Journalists +| url =http://www.cpj.org/news/2002/Ukraine17may02na.html +| accessdate=2006-07-05}} +|- +! rowspan="1" | 2002 +! 27 November +| '''[[Mykhailo Kolomiets]]''', co-founder of [[Ukrainian News Agency]] found dead hanging on a tree in [[Belarus]].[http://www.freemedia.at/cms/ipi/statements_detail.html?ctxid=CH0055&docid=CMS1146579086027&year=2002 IPI concerned about death of independent news agency's director], [[International Press Institute]] (27 November 2002) +|- +! rowspan="1" | 2003 +! 14 December +| '''[[Volodymyr Karachevtsev]]''', 47, deputy editor-in-chief of [[Kuryer newspaper]], was found dead in his home in [[Melitopol]]]. He was discovered hanging from the handle of his refrigerator. Karachevtsev was also chairman of the regional independent union of journalists and a correspondent for the online publication, Vlasti.net. Police did not rule out the possibility of murder. +|- +! rowspan="1" | 2004 +! 3 March +| '''[[Yuriy Chechyk]]''', director of [[Radio Yuta]] in [[Poltava]], died under suspicious circumstances in a car crash. He was on the way to meet with executives of [[Radio Liberty]]'s Ukrainian Service, which is often critical of the [[Ukrainian government]], to hold talks on rebroadcasting the station's programmes on the more accessible FM band. +|} +
+ ==See also== *[[Television in Ukraine]]

 ==History==
-The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since 1992<ref name=Kuchma/> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]</ref>
-
 After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994 the freedom of the press worsted.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN-10: 3039104683/ISBN-13: 978-3039104680 (page 21)</ref> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed President [[Leonid Kuchma]] on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name=Kuchma>[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN-10: 0765808978/ISBN-13: 978-0765808974 (page 397)</ref> During his presidency several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name=Kuchma/> In this year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections, libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name=USDoS1999/> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name=USDoS2003/><ref name=USDoS2004/>. Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name=USDoS2004/>
 
 Since the [[Orange Revolution]] Ukrainian media became more pluralistic and independent.<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (April 28, 2006 )</ref><ref name=USDoS2007>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 6, 2007)</ref> For instance attempts by authorities to limited freedom of the press through tax inspections where stopped.<ref name=USDoS2000>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2001)</ref><ref name=USDoS2001>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 4, 2002)</ref><ref name=USDoS2002>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 31, 2003)</ref><ref name=USDoS2003>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2004)</ref><ref name=USDoS2004>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 28, 2005)</ref><ref name=USDoS2005>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 8, 2006)</ref>
 
 Freedom House stated in 2007 that Ukraine had the freest press of all [[post-Soviet states]] and had had achieved a level of freedom previously unthinkable.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=1CcQj3DjrHAC&pg=PA39&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=-Jd1TOTTJOGkOJzD5KwG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CFsQ6AEwBzge#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Ukraine (Country Guide)] by [[Sarah Johnstone]] and [[Greg Bloom]], [[Lonely Planet]], 2008, ISBN-10: 1741044812/ISBN-13: 978-1741044812 (page 39)</ref>
 
-==Latest developments==
+===Latest developments===
 In December 2009 during the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|2010 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign incumbent [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] and presidential candidate<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/54511/ More women than men support Tymoshenko, poll shows], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 7, 2009)</ref> [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] complained Ukrainian TV channels are manipulating the consciousness of citizens in favor of financial and [[oligarchic]] groups.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/54545/ Tymoshenko accuses central TV channels of manipulating people's consciousness in favor of oligarchs], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 8, 2009)</ref>

did the [[Presidential Administration of Ukraine|Presidential Administration]]<ref name=AHer134>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/66596/ Opposition benefiting from topic of censorship at  The [[International Press Institute]] addressed an open letter to Ukrainian President Yanukovych on August 10, 2010 urging him to address a (according to the organization) disturbing deterioration in press freedom over the last six months in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/ International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'signficiantly'], [[Kyiv Post]] (August 11, 2010)</ref>
+
+===Rankings===
+The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since 1992<ref name=Kuchma/> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has in the latest years been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html Press Freedom Index 2009], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>, 87 in 2008<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html Press Freedom Index 2008], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html Press Freedom Index 2002], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> and even the 132th spot in 2004<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html Press Freedom Index 2004], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>.
 
 ==Popular opinion==
 During an opinion poll in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents said that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech is sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there is too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[Ukraine|Western Ukraine]] consider the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Ukraine|central]] and [[Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50721 Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 15, 2009)</ref>

Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has in the latest years been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html Press Freedom Index 2009], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>, 87 in 2008<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html Press Freedom Index 2008], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html Press Freedom Index 2002], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> and even the 132th spot in 2004<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html Press Freedom Index 2004], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>. According to the [[US Department of State]] in 2009 there where no attempted by central authorities to direct media content but there were reports of intimidation of journalists by national and local officials.<ref name=USDoS2009>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136063.htm 2009 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> Media at times demonstrated a tendency toward self‑censorship on matters that the government deemed sensitive.<ref name=USDoS2009/><ref name=USDoS2008>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/eur/119110.htm 2008 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2009)</ref> Print stories (veiled advertisements and positive coverage presented as news) and participation in a television talk show can be bought.<ref name=USDoS2009/> Media watchdog groups have express concern over the extremely high monetary damages that were demanded in [[Judicial system of Ukraine|court cases]] concerning [[libel]].<ref name=USDoS2009/>
 
-In Ukraine’s provinces numerous, anonymous attacks<ref name=USDoS2009/><ref name=USDoS2007/><ref>[http://www.rsf.org/Local-newspaper-editor-badly,36900.html Local newspaper editor badly injured in assault], [[Reporters Without Borders]] (March 31, 2010)</ref> and threats persisted against journalists, who investigated or exposed corruption or other government misdeeds.<ref>[http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-disturbing-deterioration-in-press-15-04-2010,37027.html Disturbing deterioration in press freedom situation since new president took over], [[Reporters Without Borders]] (April 15, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/64793/ Media crackdown under way?], [[Kyiv Post]] (April 22, 2010)</ref> The US-based [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] concluded in 2007 that these attacks, and police reluctance in some cases to pursue the perpetrators, were “helping to foster an atmosphere of impunity against independent journalists.”<ref name="hrw.org">[http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm HRW]</ref><ref>[http://www.hrw.org/en/node/79345 HRW]</ref>
+In Ukraine’s provinces numerous, anonymous attacks<ref name=USDoS2009/><ref name=USDoS2008/><ref name=USDoS2007/><ref>[http://www.rsf.org/Local-newspaper-editor-badly,36900.html Local newspaper editor badly injured in assault], [[Reporters Without Borders]] (March 31, 2010)</ref> and threats persisted against journalists, who investigated or exposed corruption or other government misdeeds.<ref>[http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-disturbing-deterioration-in-press-15-04-2010,37027.html Disturbing deterioration in press freedom situation since new president took over], [[Reporters Without Borders]] (April 15, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/64793/ Media crackdown under way?], [[Kyiv Post]] (April 22, 2010)</ref> The US-based [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] concluded in 2007 that these attacks, and police reluctance in some cases to pursue the perpetrators, were “helping to foster an atmosphere of impunity against independent journalists.”<ref name="hrw.org">[http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm HRW]</ref><ref>[http://www.hrw.org/en/node/79345 HRW]</ref>
 
 In Ukraine many news-outlets are financed by wealthy investors and reflected the political and economic interests of their owners.<ref name=USDoS2007/>

 ==History==
 The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since 1992<ref name=Kuchma/> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]</ref>
 
-In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed [[Ukrainian President]] [[Kuchma]] on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name=Kuchma>[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN-10: 0765808978/ISBN-13: 978-0765808974 (page 397)</ref> During his presidency several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name=Kuchma/> In this year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections, libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name=USDoS1999/> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name=USDoS2003/><ref name=USDoS2004/>. Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name=USDoS2004/>
+After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994 the freedom of the press worsted.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN-10: 3039104683/ISBN-13: 978-3039104680 (page 21)</ref> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed President [[Leonid Kuchma]] on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name=Kuchma>[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN-10: 0765808978/ISBN-13: 978-0765808974 (page 397)</ref> During his presidency several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name=Kuchma/> In this year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections, libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name=USDoS1999/> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name=USDoS2003/><ref name=USDoS2004/>. Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name=USDoS2004/>
 
 Since the [[Orange Revolution]] Ukrainian media became more pluralistic and independent.<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (April 28, 2006 )</ref><ref name=USDoS2007>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 6, 2007)</ref> For instance attempts by authorities to limited freedom of the press through tax inspections where stopped.<ref name=USDoS2000>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2001)</ref><ref name=USDoS2001>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 4, 2002)</ref><ref name=USDoS2002>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 31, 2003)</ref><ref name=USDoS2003>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2004)</ref><ref name=USDoS2004>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 28, 2005)</ref><ref name=USDoS2005>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 8, 2006)</ref>

 ===Rankings===
-The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since 1992<ref name=Kuchma/> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has in the latest years been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html Press Freedom Index 2009], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>, 87 in 2008<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html Press Freedom Index 2008], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html Press Freedom Index 2002], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> and even the 132th spot in 2004<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html Press Freedom Index 2004], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>.

 ==Popular opinion==
 During an opinion poll in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents said that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech is sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there is too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[Ukraine|Western Ukraine]] consider the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Ukraine|central]] and [[Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50721 Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 15, 2009)</ref>

+After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994 the freedom of the press worsened.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN-10: 3039104683/ISBN-13: 978-3039104680 (page 21)</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994-2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name=Kuchma/> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name=Kuchma>[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN-10: 0765808978/ISBN-13: 978-0765808974 (page 397)</ref> In this year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections (the later [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] 
 [[Mykola Azarov]] headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 11, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name=USDoS1999/> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name=USDoS2003/><ref name=USDoS2004/>. Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name=USDoS2004/>

+==Popular opinion==
+During an opinion poll in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents said that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech is sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there is too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[Ukraine|Western Ukraine]] consider the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Ukraine|central]] and [[Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50721 Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 15, 2009)</ref>
 
 ==Timeline of reporters killed in Ukraine==
 Under former [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Leonid Kuchma]] opposition papers were closed and several journalists died in mysterious circumstances<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1102303.stm#media Country profile: Ukraine], [[BBC News]]</ref>.

 In Ukraine many news-outlets are financed by wealthy investors and reflected the political and economic interests of their owners.<ref name=USDoS2007/>
 
 ==History==
-After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994 the freedom of the press worsted.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN-10: 3039104683/ISBN-13: 978-3039104680 (page 21)</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994-2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name=Kuchma/> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name=Kuchma>[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN-10: 0765808978/ISBN-13: 978-0765808974 (page 397)</ref> In this year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections, libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name=USDoS1999/> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name=USDoS2003/><ref name=USDoS2004/>. Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name=USDoS2004/>
+After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994 the freedom of the press worsted.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN-10: 3039104683/ISBN-13: 978-3039104680 (page 21)</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994-2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name=Kuchma/> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name=Kuchma>[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN-10: 0765808978/ISBN-13: 978-0765808974 (page 397)</ref> In this year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections (the later [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] 
+[[Mykola Azarov]] headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name=USDoS1999/> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name=USDoS2003/><ref name=USDoS2004/>. Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name=USDoS2004/>
 
 Since the [[Orange Revolution]] Ukrainian media became more pluralistic and independent.<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (April 28, 2006 )</ref><ref name=USDoS2007>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 6, 2007)</ref> For instance attempts by authorities to limited freedom of the press through tax inspections where stopped.<ref name=USDoS2000>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2001)</ref><ref name=USDoS2001>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 4, 2002)</ref><ref name=USDoS2002>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 31, 2003)</ref><ref name=USDoS2003>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2004)</ref><ref name=USDoS2004>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 28, 2005)</ref><ref name=USDoS2005>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 8, 2006)</ref>

@@ -25,7 +25,7 @@
 The [[International Press Institute]] addressed an open letter to Ukrainian President Yanukovych on August 10, 2010 urging him to address a (according to the organization) disturbing deterioration in press freedom over the last six months in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/ International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'signficiantly'], [[Kyiv Post]] (August 11, 2010)</ref>
 
 ===Rankings===
-The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992<ref name=Kuchma/> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has in the latest years been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html Press Freedom Index 2009], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>, 87 in 2008<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html Press Freedom Index 2008], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html Press Freedom Index 2002], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> and even the 132th spot in 2004<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html Press Freedom Index 2004], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>.
+The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992<ref name=Kuchma/> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref name=RFH2009>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has in the latest years been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html Press Freedom Index 2009], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>, 87 in 2008<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html Press Freedom Index 2008], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html Press Freedom Index 2002], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> and even the 132th spot in 2004<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html Press Freedom Index 2004], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>.
 
 ==Popular opinion==
 During an opinion poll in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents said that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech is sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there is too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[Ukraine|Western Ukraine]] consider the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Ukraine|central]] and [[Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50721 Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 15, 2009)</ref>

 ==History==
 After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN-10: 3039104683/ISBN-13: 978-3039104680 (page 21)</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994-2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name=Kuchma/> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name=Kuchma>[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN-10: 0765808978/ISBN-13: 978-0765808974 (page 397)</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 11, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name=USDoS1999/> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name=USDoS2003/><ref name=USDoS2004/>. Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name=USDoS2004/>

-Under former [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Leonid Kuchma]] opposition papers were closed and several journalists died in mysterious circumstances<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1102303.stm#media Country profile: Ukraine], [[BBC News]]</ref>. 
+Under former [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Leonid Kuchma]] opposition papers were closed and several journalists died in mysterious circumstances<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1102303.stm#media Country profile: Ukraine], [[BBC News]]</ref>. These occurrences have continued, some argue to an even greater extent, under [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Victor Yanukovych]].

 ==See also==

@@ -24,7 +24,7 @@
 Since the February 2010 election of Viktor Yanukovych as President Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased.<ref name=sinceFeb2010/> The [[International Press Institute]] addressed an open letter to President Yanukovych on August 10, 2010 urging him to address what the organisation saw as a disturbing deterioration in press freedom over the previous six months in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/ International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'signficiantly'], [[Kyiv Post]] (August 11, 2010)</ref> [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] rapporteur [[Renate Wohlwend]] noticed on October 6, 2010 that "Some progress had been made in recent years but there had also been some retrograde steps".<ref name=PACE>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85208/ European rapporteurs note media setback in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 6, 2010)</ref>
 
 ===Rankings===
-The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992<ref name=Kuchma/> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref name=RFH2009>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]</ref>
+The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992<ref name=Kuchma/> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref name=RFH2009>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]</ref><ref name=RFH2010>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2010 Map of Press Freedom 2010], [[Freedom House]]</ref>
 
 Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has in the latest years been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html Press Freedom Index 2009], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>, 87 in 2008<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html Press Freedom Index 2008], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html Press Freedom Index 2002], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> and even the 132th spot in 2004<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html Press Freedom Index 2004], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>. In 2010 it fell to the 131th place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|Viktor Yanukovych’s election as president in February]]".<ref>[http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html Press Freedom Index 2010], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>
llm_output:
Added a reference for the year 2010 to the rankings section.

changed_version:
---

@@ -1,5 +1,5 @@
 In 2010 Ukraine lost its designation as a free country by Freedom Press, and was demoted to partially free. It had been considered one of the freest post-Soviet states. <ref>{{cite news|last=Radio Liberty|title=Report Says Decline In Freedom Continues Across Former Soviet Union|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/freedom_house_freedom_in_the_world_report/2275173.html}}</ref> Christopher Walker, Freedom House’s director of studies, stated:
-:"Ukraine was the one country in the non-Baltic former Soviet Union that we had ranked as 'free' -- as a free country -- the only country in that region," he says. "And after last year’s developments, we now rank Ukraine as 'partly free.' And we can say that this is for a single country one of the most important and disappointing declines for 2010."
+:"Ukraine was the one country in the non-Baltic former Soviet Union that we had ranked as 'free' -- as a free country -- the only country in that region," he says. "And after last year’s developments, we now rank Ukraine as 'partly free.' And we can say that this is for a single country one of the most important and disappointing declines for 2010." <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/freedom_house_freedom_in_the_world_report/2275173.html}}</ref> 
 
 According to the [[US Department of State]] in 2009 there were no attempts by central authorities to direct media content, but there were reports of intimidation of journalists by national and local officials.<ref name=USDoS2009>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136063.htm 2009 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> Media at times demonstrated a tendency toward self‑censorship on matters that the government deemed sensitive.<ref name=USDoS2009/><ref name=USDoS2008>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/eur/119110.htm 2008 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2009)</ref> Stories in the electronic and printed media (veiled advertisements and positive coverage presented as news) and participation in a television talk show can be bought.<ref name=USDoS2009/> Media watchdog groups have express concern over the extremely high monetary damages that were demanded in [[Judicial system of Ukraine|court cases]] concerning [[libel]].<ref name=USDoS2009/>

**Conclusion:** Not Weaponised. The changes are factual and do not reflect a shift towards weaponisation of cultural heritage.

 ===Rankings===
 The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992<ref name=Kuchma/> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref name=RFH2010>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2010 Map of Press Freedom 2010], [[Freedom House]]</ref><ref name=RFH2009>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]</ref>
 
-Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has in the latest years been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html Press Freedom Index 2009], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> 87 in 2008<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html Press Freedom Index 2008], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html Press Freedom Index 2002], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> and even the 132th spot in 2004.<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html Press Freedom Index 2004], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> In 2010 it fell to the 131th place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|Viktor Yanukovych’s election as president in February]]".<ref>[http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html Press Freedom Index 2010], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>
+Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has in the latest years been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html Press Freedom Index 2009], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> 87 in 2008<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html Press Freedom Index 2008], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html Press Freedom Index 2002], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> and even the 132nd spot in 2004.<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html Press Freedom Index 2004], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|Viktor Yanukovych’s election as president in February]]".<ref>[http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html Press Freedom Index 2010], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>
 
 ==Popular opinion==
 During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and [[Southeastern Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50721 Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 15, 2009)</ref>

And we can say that this is for a single country one of the most important and disappointing declines for 2010." <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/freedom_house_freedom_in_the_world_report/2275173.html}}</ref>

+Although '''[[press freedom]] in [[Ukraine]]''' has never [[Freedom in the World (report)|been rated]] higher that "partly free" by [[Freedom House]] it is still considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]]<ref name=RFH2009/><ref name=PoSoStatN1>[http://books.google.com/books?id=1CcQj3DjrHAC&pg=PA39&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=-Jd1TOTTJOGkOJzD5KwG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CFsQ6AEwBzge#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Ukraine (Country Guide)] by [[Sarah Johnstone]] and [[Greg Bloom]], [[Lonely Planet]], 2008, ISBN-10: 1741044812/ISBN-13: 978-1741044812 (page 39)</ref><ref name=FHouse2007>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ba65SKN2I_UC&pg=PA11&lpg=PA11&dq=The+repressive+media+landscape+in+the+former+Soviet+Union+is+illuminated+by+the+fact+that+10+of+the+12+non-Baltic+post-Soviet+states+are+ranked+as+Not+Free.+The+only+two+that+enjoy+Partly+Free+status,+Georgia+and+Ukraine,+have+recently+experienced+political+upheaval+and+democratic+opening&source=bl&ots=ftIAiQ5L68&sig=pZDPbohOUOfCaBUP_xpmtOIaJDI&hl=nl&ei=hhOJTJ74GMemOO6OjYsH&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=The%20repressive%20media%20landscape%20in%20the%20former%20Soviet%20Union%20is%20illuminated%20by%20the%20fact%20that%2010%20of%20the%2012%20non-Baltic%20post-Soviet%20states%20are%20ranked%20as%20Not%20Free.%20The%20only%20two%20that%20enjoy%20Partly%20Free%20status%2C%20Georgia%20and%20Ukraine%2C%20have%20recently%20experienced%20political%20upheaval%20and%20democratic%20opening&f=false Freedom of the Press 2007: A Global Survey of Media Independence] by [[Freedom House]], [[Rowman & Littlefield Publishers, Inc]], 2007, ISBN-10: 0742555828/ISBN-13: 978-0742555822 (page 11/12)</ref> and has significantly improved since the [[Orange Revolution]] of 2004.<ref name=organge/><ref name=USDoS2007/><ref name=FHouse2007/>
 
 According to the [[US Department of State]] in 2009 there were no attempts by central authorities to direct media content, but there were reports of intimidation of journalists by national and local officials.<ref name=USDoS2009>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136063.htm 2009 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> Media at times demonstrated a tendency toward self‑censorship on matters that the government deemed sensitive.<ref name=USDoS2009/><ref name=USDoS2008>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/eur/119110.htm 2008 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2009)</ref> Stories in the electronic and printed media (veiled advertisements and positive coverage presented as news) and participation in a television talk show can be bought.<ref name=USDoS2009/> Media watchdog groups have express concern over the extremely high monetary damages that were demanded in [[Judicial system of Ukraine|court cases]] concerning [[libel]].<ref name=USDoS2009/>
 
@@ -12,7 +12,7 @@
 ==History==
 After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN-10: 3039104683/ISBN-13: 978-3039104680 (page 21)</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994-2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name=Kuchma/> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name=Kuchma>[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN-10: 0765808978/ISBN-13: 978-0765808974 (page 397)</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 11, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name=USDoS1999/> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name=USDoS2003/><ref name=USDoS2004/>. Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name=USDoS2004/>

2006)</ref> Since then the Ukrainian press is considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]].<ref Ukraine (Country Guide)] by [[Sarah Johnstone]] and [[Greg Bloom]], [[Lonely Planet]], 2008, ISBN-10: 1741044812/ISBN-13: 978-1741044812 (page 39)</ref><ref name=FHouse2007/><ref name=RFH2009>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]</ref>
+Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media has become more pluralistic and independent.<ref name=organge>[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (April 28, 2006 )</ref><ref name=USDoS2007>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 6, 2007)</ref><ref name=FHouse2007/> For instance, attempts by authorities to limit freedom of the press through tax inspections have ceased.<ref name=USDoS2000>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2001)</ref><ref name=USDoS2001>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 4, 2002)</ref><ref name=USDoS2002>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 31, 2003)</ref><ref name=USDoS2003>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2004)</ref><ref name=USDoS2004>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 28, 2005)</ref><ref name=USDoS2005>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 8, 2006)</ref> Since then the Ukrainian press is considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]].<ref name=PoSoStatN1/><ref name=FHouse2007/><ref name=RFH2009/>
 
 ===Latest developments===
 In December 2009 during the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|2010 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign incumbent [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] and presidential candidate<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/54511/ More women than men support Tymoshenko, poll shows], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 7, 2009)</ref> [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] complained Ukrainian TV channels are manipulating the consciousness of citizens in favor of financial and [[oligarchic]] groups.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/54545/ Tymoshenko accuses central TV channels of manipulating people's consciousness in favor of oligarchs], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 8, 2009)</ref>
@@ -23,13 +23,18 @@
 
 Since the February 2010 election of Viktor Yanukovych as President Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased.<ref name=sinceFeb2010/> The [[International Press Institute]] addressed an open letter to President Yanukovych on August 10, 2010 urging him to address what the organisation saw as a disturbing deterioration in press freedom over the previous six months in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/ International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'signficiantly'], [[Kyiv Post]] (August 11, 2010)</ref> [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] rapporteur [[Renate Wohlwend]] noticed on October 6, 2010 that "Some progress had been made in recent years but there had also been some retrograde steps".<ref name=PACE>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85208/ European rapporteurs note media setback in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 6, 2010)</ref>
 
+===Rankings===
+The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992<ref name=Kuchma/> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref name=RFH2009>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]</ref>
+
+Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has in the latest years been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html Press Freedom Index 2009], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>, 87 in 2008<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html Press Freedom Index 2008], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html Press Freedom Index 2002], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> and even the 132th spot in 2004<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html Press Freedom Index 2004], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>. In 2010 it fell to the 131th place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|Viktor Yanukovych’s election as president in February]]".<ref>[http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html Press Freedom Index 2010], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>
+
 ==Popular opinion==
 During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and [[Southeastern Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50721 Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 15, 2009)</ref>
 
 In a late 2010 poll also conducted by the Research & Branding Group 56% of all Ukrainians trusted the media and 38.5% didn't.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/ Poll: More than half of Ukrainians trust the media], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 17, 2010)</ref>
 
 ==Timeline of reporters killed in Ukraine==
-Under former [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Leonid Kuchma]] opposition papers were closed and several journalists died in mysterious circumstances<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1102303.stm#media Country profile: Ukraine], [[BBC News]]</ref>. These occurrences have continued, some argue to an even greater extent, under [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Victor Yanukovych]]. 
+Under former [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Leonid Kuchma]] opposition papers were closed and several journalists died in mysterious circumstances<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1102303.stm#media Country profile: Ukraine], [[BBC News]]</ref>. 
 {{Timeline of reporters killed in Ukraine}}

The change made in this revision is the addition of a new section titled "Rankings" that discusses Ukraine's press freedom ratings over the years, including specific rankings from organizations like Freedom House and Reporters Without Borders. 

Weaponised

The addition of this section could be seen as weaponised because it emphasizes Ukraine's struggles with press freedom and the implications of political changes, which may serve to frame the narrative around Ukraine's governance and its impact on cultural and media freedoms. The context of the comment by the user, which suggests a dismissive attitude towards Ukraine's claims of freedom, further indicates a potential bias in the portrayal of Ukraine's situation.

+After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN 978-3039104680 (page 21)</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name=Kuchma/> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name=Kuchma>[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN 978-0765808974 (page 397)</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 11, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name=USDoS1999/> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name=USDoS2003/><ref name=USDoS2004/> Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name=USDoS2004/>
 
 Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media has become more pluralistic and independent.<ref name=FHouse2007/><ref name=organge>[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (April 28, 2006 )</ref><ref name=USDoS2007>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 6, 2007)</ref> For instance, attempts by authorities to limit freedom of the press through tax inspections have ceased.<ref name=USDoS2003>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2004)</ref><ref name=USDoS2004>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 28, 2005)</ref><ref name=USDoS2000>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2001)</ref><ref name=USDoS2001>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 4, 2002)</ref><ref name=USDoS2002>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 31, 2003)</ref><ref name=USDoS2005>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 8, 2006)</ref> Since then the Ukrainian press is considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]].<ref name=RFH2009/><ref name=PoSoStatN1/><ref name=FHouse2007/>

The change made in this revision is a rephrasing of the text regarding press freedom in Ukraine, specifically the section discussing the historical context of press freedom and the impact of various presidencies on it.

**Rephrased**: The sentence structure and wording have been altered, but the overall meaning remains the same, discussing the decline of press freedom after the term of the first Ukrainian President, Leonid Kravchuk, and the subsequent issues during Leonid Kuchma's presidency.

**Not Weaponised**: The changes do not introduce any weaponisation terms or narratives that could be used to manipulate cultural heritage or political perspectives. The content remains factual and focused on historical events without bias.

Europe/Radio Liberty]] (January 13, 2011)</ref> 
 
 According to the [[US Department of State]] in 2009 there were no attempts by central authorities to direct media content, but there were reports of intimidation of journalists by national and local officials.<ref name=USDoS2009>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136063.htm 2009 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> Media at times demonstrated a tendency toward self‑censorship on matters that the government deemed sensitive.<ref name=USDoS2009/><ref name=USDoS2008>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/eur/119110.htm 2008 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2009)</ref> Stories in the electronic and printed media (veiled advertisements and positive coverage presented as news) and participation in a television talk show can be bought.<ref name=USDoS2009/> Media watchdog groups have express concern over the extremely high monetary damages that were demanded in [[Judicial system of Ukraine|court cases]] concerning [[libel]].<ref name=USDoS2009/>
 
 The [[Constitution of Ukraine]] and a 1991 law provide for freedom of speech.<ref name=USDoS1999>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/1999/367.htm 1999 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2000)</ref>
 
-In Ukraine’s provinces numerous, anonymous attacks<ref name=USDoS2009/><ref name=USDoS2008/><ref name=USDoS2007/><ref>[http://www.rsf.org/Local-newspaper-editor-badly,36900.html Local newspaper editor badly injured in assault], [[Reporters Without Borders]] (March 31, 2010)</ref> and threats persisted against journalists, who investigated or exposed corruption or other government misdeeds.<ref>[http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-disturbing-deterioration-in-press-15-04-2010,37027.html Disturbing deterioration in press freedom situation since new president took over], [[Reporters Without Borders]] (April 15, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/64793/ Media crackdown under way?], [[Kyiv Post]] (April 22, 2010)</ref> The US-based [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] concluded in 2007 that these attacks, and police reluctance in some cases to pursue the perpetrators, were “helping to foster an atmosphere of impunity against independent journalists.”<ref name="hrw.org">[http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm HRW]</ref><ref>[http://www.hrw.org/en/node/79345 HRW]</ref> Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased since the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|February 2010 election]] of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] as [[Ukrainian President|President]].<ref name=sinceFeb2010>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Concerns_Mount_About_Press_Freedom_In_Ukraine_As_Journalist_Attacked/2164350.html Concerns Mount About Press Freedom In Ukraine As Journalist Attacked], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (September 21, 2010)</ref>

 ===Latest developments===

 A law on strengthening the protection of the ownership of [[mass media]] offices, [[publishing house]]s, bookshops and distributors, as well as [[creative unions]] was passed by the [[Ukrainian Parliament]] on May 20, 2010.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/67398/ Parliament bans forced removal of state and municipal mass media offices], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 21, 2009)</ref>
 
 Since the February 2010 election of Viktor Yanukovych as President Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased.<ref name=sinceFeb2010/> The [[International Press Institute]] addressed an open letter to President Yanukovych on August 10, 2010 urging him to address what the organisation saw as a disturbing deterioration in press freedom over the previous six months in Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/ International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'signficiantly'], [[Kyiv Post]] (August 11, 2010)</ref> [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] rapporteur [[Renate Wohlwend]] noticed on October 6, 2010 that "Some progress had been made in recent years but there had also been some retrograde steps".<ref name=PACE>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85208/ European rapporteurs note media setback in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 6, 2010)</ref> In January 2011 [[Freedom House]] stated it had perceived "negative trends in Ukraine" during 2010; these included: curbs on press freedom, the intimidation of [[civil society]], and greater [[Government of Ukraine|government]] influence on the [[Judicial system of Ukraine|judiciary]].<ref name="negative trends 2010"/>

-The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992<ref name=Kuchma/> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]]</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref name=RFH2009>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]</ref><ref name=RFH2010>[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2010 Map of Press Freedom 2010], [[Freedom House]]</ref>

-Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has in the latest years been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html Press Freedom Index 2009], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>, 87 in 2008<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html Press Freedom Index 2008], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html Press Freedom Index 2002], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> and even the 132th spot in 2004<ref>[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html Press Freedom Index 2004], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>. In 2010 it fell to the 131th place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|Viktor Yanukovych’s election as president in February]]".<ref>[http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html Press Freedom Index 2010], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref>

 ==Popular opinion==
 During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and [[Southeastern Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50721 Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 15, 2009)</ref>
