these included: curbs on press freedom, the intimidation of [[civil society]], and greater [[Government of Ukraine|government]] influence on the [[Judicial system of Ukraine|judiciary]]. ===Rankings=== -The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992 till 2003, when it was rated "not free".[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]] Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2010 Map of Press Freedom 2010], [[Freedom House]][http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]] +The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992 till 2003, when it was rated "not free".[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]] Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2010 Map of Press Freedom 2010], [[Freedom House]][http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]
[http://www.freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/Map%20of%20Freedom%202013%2C%20final.pdf Map of Freedom (of the Freedom in the World 2013 survey)], [[Freedom House]] Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html Press Freedom Index 2009], [[Reporters Without Borders]] 87 in 2008[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html Press Freedom Index 2008], [[Reporters Without Borders]]), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html Press Freedom Index 2002], [[Reporters Without Borders]] and even the 132nd spot in 2004.[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html Press Freedom Index 2004], [[Reporters Without Borders]] In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|Viktor Yanukovych’s election as president in February]]".[http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html Press Freedom Index 2010], [[Reporters Without Borders]] In 2013 Ukraine occupied the 126th spot (dropping 10 places compared with 2012); (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".[http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf Press Freedom Index 2013], [[Reporters Without Borders]]

@@ -10,7 +10,7 @@
 In Ukraine many news-outlets are financed by wealthy investors and reflected the political and economic interests of their owners.<ref name=USDoS2007/>
 
 ==History==
-After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN 978-3039104680 (page 21)</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name=Kuchma/> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name=Kuchma>[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN 978-0765808974 (page 397)</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 11, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name=USDoS1999/> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name=USDoS2003/><ref name=USDoS2004/> Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name=USDoS2004/>
+After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN 978-3-03910-468-0 (page 21)</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name=Kuchma/> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name=Kuchma>[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN 978-0-7658-0897-4 (page 397)</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 11, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name=USDoS1999/> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name=USDoS2003/><ref name=USDoS2004/> Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name=USDoS2004/>
 
 Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media has become more pluralistic and independent.<ref name=FHouse2007/><ref name=organge>[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (April 28, 2006 )</ref><ref name=USDoS2007>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 6, 2007)</ref> For instance, attempts by authorities to limit freedom of the press through tax inspections have ceased.<ref name=USDoS2003>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2004)</ref><ref name=USDoS2004>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 28, 2005)</ref><ref name=USDoS2000>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2001)</ref><ref name=USDoS2001>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 4, 2002)</ref><ref name=USDoS2002>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 31, 2003)</ref><ref name=USDoS2005>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 8, 2006)</ref> Since then the Ukrainian press is considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]].<ref name=RFH2009/><ref name=PoSoStatN1/><ref name=FHouse2007/>

 In Ukraine’s provinces numerous, anonymous attacks<ref name=USDoS2007/><ref name=USDoS2009/><ref name=USDoS2008/><ref>[http://www.rsf.org/Local-newspaper-editor-badly,36900.html Local newspaper editor badly injured in assault], [[Reporters Without Borders]] (March 31, 2010)</ref> and threats persisted against journalists, who investigated or exposed corruption or other government misdeeds.<ref>[http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-disturbing-deterioration-in-press-15-04-2010,37027.html Disturbing deterioration in press freedom situation since new president took over], [[Reporters Without Borders]] (April 15, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/64793/ Media crackdown under way?], [[Kyiv Post]] (April 22, 2010)</ref> The US-based [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] concluded in 2007 that these attacks, and police reluctance in some cases to pursue the perpetrators, were “helping to foster an atmosphere of impunity against independent journalists.”<ref name="hrw.org">[http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm HRW]</ref><ref>[http://www.hrw.org/en/node/79345 HRW]</ref> Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased since the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|February 2010 election]] of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] as [[Ukrainian President|President]].<ref name=sinceFeb2010>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Concerns_Mount_About_Press_Freedom_In_Ukraine_As_Journalist_Attacked/2164350.html Concerns Mount About Press Freedom In Ukraine As Journalist Attacked], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (September 21, 2010)</ref>
 
-In Ukraine many news-outlets are financed by wealthy investors and reflected the political and economic interests of their owners.<ref name=USDoS2007/> Therefore, freedom of speech is influenced by the ‘censorship of money’. <ref>Belyakov</ref>
+In Ukraine many news-outlets are financed by wealthy investors and reflected the political and economic interests of their owners.<ref name=USDoS2007/>
 
 ==History==
 After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN 978-3-03910-468-0 (page 21)</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name=Kuchma/> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name=Kuchma>[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN 978-0-7658-0897-4 (page 397)</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 11, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name=USDoS1999/> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name=USDoS2003/><ref name=USDoS2004/> Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name=USDoS2004/>

--- +++ @@ -24,7 +24,7 @@ Since the February 2010 election of Viktor Yanukovych as President Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased. The [[International Press Institute]] addressed an open letter to President Yanukovych on August 10, 2010 urging him to address what the organisation saw as a disturbing deterioration in press freedom over the previous six months in Ukraine.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/ International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'signficiantly'], [[Kyiv Post]] (August 11, 2010) [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] rapporteur [[Renate Wohlwend]] noticed on October 6, 2010 that "Some progress had been made in recent years but there had also been some retrograde steps".[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85208/ European rapporteurs note media setback in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 6, 2010) In January 2011 [[Freedom House]] stated it had perceived "negative trends in Ukraine" during 2010; these included: curbs on press freedom, the intimidation of [[civil society]], and greater [[Government of Ukraine|government]] influence on the [[Judicial system of Ukraine|judiciary]]. ===Rankings=== -The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992 till 2003, when it was rated "not free".[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]] Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2010 Map of Press Freedom 2010], [[Freedom House]][http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]
[http://www.freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/Map%20of%20Freedom%202013%2C%20final.pdf Map of Freedom (of the Freedom in the World 2013 survey)], [[Freedom House]] +The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992 till 2003, when it was rated "not free".[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003 Map of Press Freedom 2004], [[Freedom House]] Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.[http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2010 Map of Press Freedom 2010], [[Freedom House]][http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009 Map of Press Freedom 2009], [[Freedom House]]
[http://www.freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/Map%20of%20Freedom%202013%2C%20final.pdf Map of Freedom (of the Freedom in the World 2013 survey)], [[Freedom House]] According to Freedom House [[internet in Ukraine]] is "Free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] is "Partly Free". Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html Press Freedom Index 2009], [[Reporters Without Borders]] 87 in 2008[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html Press Freedom Index 2008], [[Reporters Without Borders]]), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html Press Freedom Index 2002], [[Reporters Without Borders]] and even the 132nd spot in 2004.[http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html Press Freedom Index 2004], [[Reporters Without Borders]] In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|Viktor Yanukovych’s election as president in February]]".[http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html Press Freedom Index 2010], [[Reporters Without Borders]] In 2013 Ukraine occupied the 126th spot (dropping 10 places compared with 2012); (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".[http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf Press Freedom Index 2013], [[Reporters Without Borders]]

 ===Latest developments===
 In December 2009 during the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|2010 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign incumbent [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] and presidential candidate<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/54511/ More women than men support Tymoshenko, poll shows], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 7, 2009)</ref> [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] complained Ukrainian TV channels are manipulating the consciousness of citizens in favor of financial and [[oligarchic]] groups.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/54545/ Tymoshenko accuses central TV channels of manipulating people's consciousness in favor of oligarchs], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 8, 2009)</ref>

The change made in this revision is: "Added a statement indicating that only the Baltic states are considered 'free'." 

Weaponised. The addition of this statement subtly reinforces a narrative that positions Ukraine and other post-Soviet states in a negative light regarding their freedom status, while elevating the Baltic states as a benchmark for freedom. This can be interpreted as a political statement that may serve to undermine the legitimacy of Ukraine's governance and its media landscape, aligning with broader geopolitical narratives.

+[[File:Georgi gongadse.jpg|thumbnail|[[Georgiy Gongadze]], [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] journalist, founder of a popular Internet newspaper [[Ukrayinska Pravda]], who was kidnapped and murdered in 2000.]]
 After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN 978-3-03910-468-0 (page 21)</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name=Kuchma/> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name=Kuchma>[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN 978-0-7658-0897-4 (page 397)</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 11, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name=USDoS1999/> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name=USDoS2003/><ref name=USDoS2004/> Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name=USDoS2004/>
 
 Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media has become more pluralistic and independent.<ref name=FHouse2007/><ref name=organge>[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (April 28, 2006 )</ref><ref name=USDoS2007>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 6, 2007)</ref> For instance, attempts by authorities to limit freedom of the press through tax inspections have ceased.<ref name=USDoS2003>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2004)</ref><ref name=USDoS2004>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 28, 2005)</ref><ref name=USDoS2000>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2001)</ref><ref name=USDoS2001>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 4, 2002)</ref><ref name=USDoS2002>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 31, 2003)</ref><ref name=USDoS2005>[http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 8, 2006)</ref> Since then the Ukrainian press is considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]] (only the [[Baltic states]] are considered "free").<ref name=RFH2009/><ref name=PoSoStatN1/><ref name=FHouse2007/>

The [[International Press Institute]] addressed an open letter to President Yanukovych on August 10, 2010 urging him to address what the organisation saw as a disturbing deterioration in press freedom over the previous six months in Ukraine.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/ International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'signficiantly'], [[Kyiv Post]] (August 11, 2010) [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] rapporteur [[Renate Wohlwend]] noticed on October 6, 2010 that "Some progress had been made in recent years but there had also been some retrograde steps".[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85208/ European rapporteurs note media setback in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 6, 2010) In January 2011 [[Freedom House]] stated it had perceived "negative trends in Ukraine" during 2010; these included: curbs on press freedom, the intimidation of [[civil society]], and greater [[Government of Ukraine|government]] influence on the [[Judicial system of Ukraine|judiciary]]. -{{main|Ministry of Truth (Ukraine)}} +The ongoing crisis in Ukraine has resulted in a major threat to press freedom in recent months. A May report from the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) found approximately 300 instances of violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.{{Cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }} + +Amid tensions with Russia, Kiev is not tolerating any other points of view in the press. Under the impact of war and extreme social polarization, the democratic credentials of the pro-European Kiev government have been slipping as well. A crackdown on what authorities describe as “pro-separatist” points of view has triggered dismay among Western human rights monitors. For example, the September 11, 2014 shutdown of the independent Kiev-based Vesti newspaper by the Ukrainian Security Service for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international Committee to Protect Journalists and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.{{Cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }} + + The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. + +Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” + +Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{Cite web|url = www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }} + +Ukraine has also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey “propaganda,” and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.{{main|Ministry of Truth (Ukraine)}} The Ministry of Information Policy was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)
{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) It was created concurrently with the formation of the [[Second Yatsenyuk Government]], after the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014|October 2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]]. The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].[http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry ], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014) In 2014 Ukraine blocked 14 Russian television channels from its cable networks.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014.

--- 
+++ 
@@ -46,7 +46,7 @@
 
 Amid tensions with Russia, Kiev is not tolerating any other points of view in the press. Under the impact of war and extreme social polarization, the democratic credentials of the pro-European Kiev government have been slipping as well. A crackdown on what authorities describe as “pro-separatist” points of view has triggered dismay among Western human rights monitors. For example, the September 11, 2014 shutdown of the independent Kiev-based Vesti newspaper by the Ukrainian Security Service for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international Committee to Protect Journalists and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
 
- The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website.
+ The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website.
 
 Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.”

{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) It was created concurrently with the formation of the [[Second Yatsenyuk Government]], after the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014|October 2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]]. The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].[http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry ], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)

 For example, the September 11, 2014 shutdown of the independent Kiev-based Vesti newspaper by the Ukrainian Security Service for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international Committee to Protect Journalists and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website.  Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>

-Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2009|work=rsf.org|date=2009|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20091022183400/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|archive-date=22 October 2009}}</ref> 87 in 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2008|work=rsf.org|date=2008|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090607100340/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|archive-date=7 June 2009}}</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2002|work=rsf.org|date=October 2002|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090703081345/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|archive-date=3 July 2009}}</ref> and even the 132nd spot in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2004|work=rsf.org|date=2004|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090905174452/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|archive-date=5 September 2009}}</ref> In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".<ref>[http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf Press Freedom Index 2013], [[Reporters Without Borders]]</ref> In the 2014 World Press Freedom Index Ukraine was placed 127th.<ref>[http://uatoday.tv/news/ukraine-takes-127th-place-in-rating-of-freedom-of-speech-402225.html Ukraine takes 127th place in rating of freedom of speech], [[Ukraine Today]] (12 January 2014)</ref>

 ==Popular opinion==
 During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and [[Southeastern Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50721 Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 15, 2009)</ref>

+Since November 2015 Ukrainian authorities, state agencies and local government authorities are forbidden to act as founders (or cofounders) of printed media outlets.<ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/306311.html Ukrainian state authorities can not be founders, cofounders of printed media from now on], [[Interfax Ukraine]] (24 November 2015)</ref>
+
 ===Rankings===

@@ -51,6 +51,8 @@
 
 In 2014 Ukraine blocked 14 Russian television channels from its cable networks.<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014.</ref>
 
+On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that an Ukrainian journalist called Ruslan Kotsaba was arresteed by Ukrainian authorities and charged with "treason" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by Ukrianian Army. Amnesty International has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan”. In response Ukrainian SBU declared that they have found “evidence of serious crimes” but declined to elaborate.<ref>"[http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kiev struggles to find new fighters]". ''The Guardian.'' 10 February 2015.</ref>
+
 On 16 September 2015 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning forty-one foreign journalists and bloggers who 'threaten national interests' from Ukraine. This was later reduced to 38.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref>

--- +++ @@ -42,16 +42,16 @@ Since the February 2010 election of Viktor Yanukovych as President Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased. The [[International Press Institute]] addressed an open letter to President Yanukovych on August 10, 2010 urging him to address what the organisation saw as a disturbing deterioration in press freedom over the previous six months in Ukraine.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/ International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'signficiantly'], [[Kyiv Post]] (August 11, 2010) [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] rapporteur [[Renate Wohlwend]] noticed on October 6, 2010 that "Some progress had been made in recent years but there had also been some retrograde steps".[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85208/ European rapporteurs note media setback in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 6, 2010) In January 2011 [[Freedom House]] stated it had perceived "negative trends in Ukraine" during 2010; these included: curbs on press freedom, the intimidation of [[civil society]], and greater [[Government of Ukraine|government]] influence on the [[Judicial system of Ukraine|judiciary]]. -The ongoing crisis in Ukraine has resulted in a major threat to press freedom in recent months. A May report from the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) found approximately 300 instances of violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.{{Cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }} Under the impact of war and extreme social polarization, the pro-European Kiev government has cracked down on pro-separatist points of view, creating some concern among Western human rights monitors. +The ongoing crisis in Ukraine has resulted in a major threat to press freedom in recent months. A May report from the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) found approximately 300 instances of violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.{{cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }} Under the impact of war and extreme social polarization, the pro-European Kiev government has cracked down on pro-separatist points of view, creating some concern among Western human rights monitors. -For example, the September 11, 2014 shutdown of the independent Kiev-based Vesti newspaper by the Ukrainian Security Service for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international Committee to Protect Journalists and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.{{Cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{Cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }} +For example, the September 11, 2014 shutdown of the independent Kiev-based Vesti newspaper by the Ukrainian Security Service for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international Committee to Protect Journalists and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }} The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }} Ukraine has also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey “propaganda,” and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.{{main|Ministry of Truth (Ukraine)}} The Ministry of Information Policy was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)
{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) It was created concurrently with the formation of the [[Second Yatsenyuk Government]], after the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014|October 2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]]. The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. -The ongoing crisis in Ukraine has resulted in a major threat to press freedom in recent months. A May report from the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) found approximately 300 instances of violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Under the impact of war and extreme social polarization, the pro-European Kiev government has cracked down on pro-separatist points of view, creating some concern among Western human rights monitors.<ref name=":02"/>
+The ongoing [[crisis in Ukraine]] has resulted in a major threat to press freedom in recent months. A May 2014 report from the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) found approximately 300 instances of violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view.<ref name=":02"/>
 
 For example, the September 11, 2014 shutdown of the independent Kiev-based Vesti newspaper by the Ukrainian Security Service for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international Committee to Protect Journalists and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.<ref name=":02">{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website.  Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>

+Since the February 2010 election of Viktor Yanukovych as President Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased.<ref name=sinceFeb2010/> The [[International Press Institute]] addressed an open letter to President Yanukovych on August 10, 2010 urging him to address what the organisation saw as a disturbing deterioration in press freedom over the previous six months in Ukraine.<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20100811172630/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/ International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'signficiantly'], [[Kyiv Post]] (August 11, 2010)</ref> [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] rapporteur [[Renate Wohlwend]] noticed on October 6, 2010 that "Some progress had been made in recent years but there had also been some retrograde steps".<ref name=PACE>[http://web.archive.org/web/20101007235843/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85208/ European rapporteurs note media setback in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 6, 2010)</ref> In January 2011 [[Freedom House]] stated it had perceived "negative trends in Ukraine" during 2010; these included: curbs on press freedom, the intimidation of [[civil society]], and greater [[Government of Ukraine|government]] influence on the [[Judicial system of Ukraine|judiciary]].<ref name="negative trends 2010"/>
 
 The ongoing crisis in Ukraine has resulted in a major threat to press freedom in recent months. A May report from the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) found approximately 300 instances of violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Under the impact of war and extreme social polarization, the pro-European Kiev government has cracked down on pro-separatist points of view, creating some concern among Western human rights monitors.<ref name=":02"/>
 
 For example, the September 11, 2014 shutdown of the independent Kiev-based Vesti newspaper by the Ukrainian Security Service for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international Committee to Protect Journalists and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.<ref name=":02">{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website.  Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
 
 Ukraine has also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey “propaganda,” and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.<ref name=":02" />{{main|Ministry of Truth (Ukraine)}}
-The Ministry of Information Policy was established on 2 December 2014.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="FLUYGIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)<br>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)<br>{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014)</ref> It was created concurrently with the formation of the [[Second Yatsenyuk Government]], after the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014|October 2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]]. The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].<ref name="FLUYGIU21214"/><ref>[http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry ]{{dead link|date=September 2015}}, [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)</ref> [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".<ref name=PPsbiU812>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)</ref>
+The Ministry of Information Policy was established on 2 December 2014.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="FLUYGIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)<br>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)<br>{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014)</ref> It was created concurrently with the formation of the [[Second Yatsenyuk Government]], after the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014|October 2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]]. The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].<ref name="FLUYGIU21214"/><ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry ], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)</ref> [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".<ref name=PPsbiU812>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)</ref>
 
 In 2014 Ukraine blocked 14 Russian television channels from its cable networks.<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014.</ref>
 
 On 16 September 2015 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning forty-one foreign journalists and bloggers who 'threaten national interests' from Ukraine. This was later reduced to 38.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref>
 
 ===Rankings===
-The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992<ref name=Kuchma/> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2003|title=Freedom of the Press 2003|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2003|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref name=RFH2010>{{cite web|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2010|title=Freedom of the Press 2010|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref><ref name=RFH2009>{{cite web|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/template.cfm?page=251&year=2009|title=Freedom of the Press 2009|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2009|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> According to Freedom House [[internet in Ukraine]] is "Free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] is "Partly Free".<ref name=FHUkraine/>
+The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992<ref name=Kuchma/> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2003?page=251&year=2003|title=Freedom of the Press 2003|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2003|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref name=RFH2010>{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2010?page=251&year=2010|title=Freedom of the Press 2010|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref><ref name=RFH2009>{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2009?page=251&year=2009|title=Freedom of the Press 2009|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2009|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> According to Freedom House [[internet in Ukraine]] is "Free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] is "Partly Free".<ref name=FHUkraine/>
 
 Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2009|work=rsf.org|date=2009|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20091022183400/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|archive-date=22 October 2009}}</ref> 87 in 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2008|work=rsf.org|date=2008|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090607100340/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|archive-date=7 June 2009}}</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2002|work=rsf.org|date=October 2002|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090703081345/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|archive-date=3 July 2009}}</ref> and even the 132nd spot in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2004|work=rsf.org|date=2004|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090905174452/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|archive-date=5 September 2009}}</ref> In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|Viktor Yanukovych’s election as president in February]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2010|work=rsf.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> In 2013 Ukraine occupied the 126th spot (dropping 10 places compared with 2012); (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".<ref>{{cite web|format=PDF|url=http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|title=Press Freedom Index 2013|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref> In the 2014 World Press Freedom Index Ukraine was placed 127th.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uatoday.tv/news/ukraine-takes-127th-place-in-rating-of-freedom-of-speech-402225.html|title=Ukraine takes 127th place in rating of freedom of speech|work=[[Ukraine Today]]|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
 
 ==Popular opinion==
 During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and [[Southeastern Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/half-of-all-ukrainians-consider-current-freedom-of-50721.html|title=Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=15 October 2009|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
 
-In a late 2010 poll also conducted by the Research & Branding Group 56% of all Ukrainians trusted the media and 38.5% didn't.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/ Poll: More than half of Ukrainians trust the media]{{dead link|date=September 2015}}, [[Kyiv Post]] (December 17, 2010)</ref>
+In a late 2010 poll also conducted by the Research & Branding Group 56% of all Ukrainians trusted the media and 38.5% didn't.<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20110120213543/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/ Poll: More than half of Ukrainians trust the media], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 17, 2010)</ref>
 
 ==Timeline of reporters killed in Ukraine==
 Under former [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Leonid Kuchma]] opposition papers were closed and several journalists died in mysterious circumstances.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1102303.stm#media|title=Ukraine country profile: Media|work=bbc.co.uk|date=26 April 2012|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref>

--- +++ @@ -44,7 +44,7 @@ The ongoing [[crisis in Ukraine]] has resulted in a major threat to press freedom in recent months. A May 2014 report from the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) found approximately 300 instances of violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.{{cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }} Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view. -For example, the September 11, 2014 shutdown of the independent Kiev-based Vesti newspaper by the Ukrainian Security Service for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international Committee to Protect Journalists and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }} The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. It justified the change as follows:[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine Ukraine 2015 Freedom of the Press] report +[[Freedom House]] reported the status of press freedom in [[Ukraine]] in 2015 as improving from Not Free to Partly Free. It justified the change as follows:[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine Ukraine 2015 Freedom of the Press] report
due to profound changes in the media environment after the fall of President Viktor Yanukovych’s government in February, despite a rise in attacks on journalists during the Euromaidan protests of early 2014 and the subsequent conflict in eastern Ukraine. The level of government hostility and legal pressure faced by journalists decreased, as did political pressure on state-owned outlets. The media also benefited from improvements to the law on access to information and the increased independence of the broadcasting regulator.
In 2015 the main concerns about media freedom in Ukraine concern the handling of pro-Russian propaganda, the concentration of media ownership, and the high risks of violence against journalists, especially in the conflict areas in the east.

 After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN 978-3-03910-468-0 (page 21)</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name=Kuchma/> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name=Kuchma>[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN 978-0-7658-0897-4 (page 397)</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 11, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name=USDoS1999/> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name=USDoS2003/><ref name=USDoS2004/> Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name=USDoS2004/>

 The ongoing crisis in Ukraine has resulted in a major threat to press freedom in recent months. A May report from the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) found approximately 300 instances of violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Under the impact of war and extreme social polarization, the pro-European Kiev government has cracked down on pro-separatist points of view, creating some concern among Western human rights monitors.<ref name=":02"/>
 
 For example, the September 11, 2014 shutdown of the independent Kiev-based Vesti newspaper by the Ukrainian Security Service for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international Committee to Protect Journalists and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.<ref name=":02">{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website.  Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
 
 Ukraine has also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey “propaganda,” and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.<ref name=":02" />{{main|Ministry of Truth (Ukraine)}}
-The Ministry of Information Policy was established on 2 December 2014.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="FLUYGIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)<br>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)<br>{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014)</ref> It was created concurrently with the formation of the [[Second Yatsenyuk Government]], after the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014|October 2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]]. The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].<ref name="FLUYGIU21214"/><ref>[http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry ], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)</ref> [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".<ref name=PPsbiU812>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)</ref>

 In 2014 Ukraine blocked 14 Russian television channels from its cable networks.<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014.</ref>
 
@@ -61,10 +61,10 @@
 ==Popular opinion==
 During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and [[Southeastern Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/half-of-all-ukrainians-consider-current-freedom-of-50721.html|title=Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=15 October 2009|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
