@@ -96,7 +96,7 @@
 
 == Situation in the Russia-occupied Crimea ==
 
-The media environment in [[Crimea]] was completely transformed by the February 2014 Russian occupation and annexation of the peninsula, after the ejection of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] from power in [[Ukraine]] following the [[euromaidan]] protests. Occupation authorities engineered an annexation referendum to Russia, and restrictive Russian media laws started to be enacted in the Black Sea peninsula too. Media conditions in Crimea in 2014 were worse than in [[Russia]] itself, due to the effort of Russia-imposed authorities to rein in a previously relatively pluralistic media landscape. Media outlets were shut down, broadcasts of Ukrainian channels were suspended, and journalists fled the region due to fears of harassment, violence, and arrests.<ref name=FHcrimea>[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/crimea Crimea 2015 Press Freedom] report</ref>
+The media environment in [[Crimea]] was completely transformed by the February 2014 Russian occupation and annexation of the peninsula, after the ejection of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] from power in [[Ukraine]] following the [[euromaidan]] protests. Occupation authorities engineered an annexation referendum to Russia, and restrictive Russian media laws started to be enacted in the Black Sea peninsula too. Media conditions in Crimea in 2014 were worse than in [[Russia]] itself, due to the effort of Russia-imposed authorities to rein in a previously relatively pluralistic media landscape. Media outlets were shut down, broadcasts of Ukrainian channels were suspended, and journalists fled the region due to fears of harassment, violence, and arrests. The situation of press freedom in Crimea in 2014 was identified by [[Freedom House]] as the worst in the European continent.<ref name=FHcrimea>[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/crimea Crimea 2015 Press Freedom] report</ref>
 
 Russian outlets, particularly state-owned ones, enjoy a dominant position in post-annexation Crimea. The distribution of Ukrainian print media has been obstructed by Russian officials, and even the Ukrainian Postal Agency had to stop deliveries in the peninsula. Widespread and irregular expropriations by Russian authorities have also affected the Crimean media landscape <ref name=FHcrimea/>

 * [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] created a Crimean news service in Russian, Ukrainian and Tatar languages.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 
 === Repression of Crimean Tatar media ===
-[[Crimean Tatar]] media were particularly targeted by Russian repression.  [[ATR (TV channel)|ATR]], ''Avdet'' and the QHA news agency remained among the last independent media operating in Crimea by the end of 2014.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
+[[Crimean Tatars|Crimean Tatar]] media were particularly targeted by Russian repression.  [[ATR (TV channel)|ATR]], ''Avdet'' and the QHA news agency remained among the last independent media operating in Crimea by the end of 2014.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 * In June 2014 Shevket Kaybullayev, editor of the ''Avdet'' newspaper, was questioned and warned by the prosecutor over "extremist contents" due to the paper's coverage of a opposition activities and the use of the term "occupation". In September 2014 the premises of the ''Avdet'' newspaper were raided and searched  by unidentified security forces, without a warrant. The newspaper was closed down and its bank accounts seized. Kaybullayev was officially warned that he would be prosecuted and risked up to 5 years in jail if ''Avdet'' had continued reporting on calls for a boycott of the [[Crimean legislative election, 2014]].<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 * The Crimean Tatar TV channel [[ATR (TV channel)|ATR]] received a warning in May 2015 after covering a Tatar protest. It was subject to an inspection in September 2014 by the Interior Ministry, as suspect of inciting "extremism" and "distrust towards the authorities". KGB agents regularly called the station and applied pressures, threatening it with closure.<ref name=FHcrimea/>

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The change is a rephrasing that does not introduce any weaponised language or narratives related to cultural heritage. It simply clarifies the subject matter without altering the context or implications.

changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -65,13 +65,13 @@ === Euromaidan revolution and Poroshenko presidency (2014) === [[File:Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, Kyiv. Events of February 18, 2014..jpg|thumbnail|Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, [[Kyiv]]. Events of February 18, 2014.]]Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.{{cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }} The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kiev (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. -In 2014 restrictions to press freedom in Ukraine included police impeding access to public buildings, physical attacks on press rooms, and cyberattacks (e.g. against the ''Glavnoe'', ''Gordon'' and [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] websites); in July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''. +In 2014 restrictions to press freedom in Ukraine included police impeding access to public buildings, physical attacks on press rooms, and cyberattacks (e.g. against the ''Glavnoe'', ''Gordon'' and [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] websites); in July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''. -Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media. Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too. In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication. +Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media. Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too. In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication. [[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian occupation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kiev government. Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view. For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey “propaganda,” and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country. *The broadcasting regulators was mandated by courts to suspend temporarily the rebroadcasting of certain Russian channels in Ukraine. In 2014 Ukraine blocked 14 Russian television channels from its cable networks.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014. By September 2014, the number of television channels blocked from Ukrainian cable networks had risen to 15; the legal basis for this were charges of stirring hatred, threatening national security and supporting separatism. -*On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}{{#tag:ref|The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}|group=nb}} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014. +*On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}{{#tag:ref|The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}|group=nb}} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014. * Ukrainian authorities denied entry to several Russian journalists throughout 2014, with bans on re-entry for some of up to 5 years * The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)]] was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)
{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].[http://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry] , [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014) * On 16 September 2015 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning forty-one foreign journalists and bloggers who 'threaten national interests' from Ukraine. This was later reduced to 38.{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 September 2015}} @@ -79,7 +79,7 @@ Since November 2015 Ukrainian authorities, state agencies and local government authorities are forbidden to act as founders (or cofounders) of printed media outlets.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/306311.html Ukrainian state authorities can not be founders, cofounders of printed media from now on], [[Interfax Ukraine]] (24 November 2015) == Attacks and threats against journalists == -Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.{{cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }} 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''. +Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013. 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist Ruslan Kotsaba and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{ill-WD|Ruslan Kotsaba|Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15 year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kiev struggles to find new fighters |publisher=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015}}|group = nb}} @@ -113,8 +113,8 @@ === Attacks and threats against journalists === Since the annexation, Russian authorities threatened and harassed pro-Ukrainian or simply independent media in Crimea. Media professionals - including foreign ones - have been obstructed, detained, questioned, and have had their equipment seized or destroyed. "Self-defence" paramilitary units have enjoyed impunity for their punitive actions against non-aligned journalists. -* In June 2014 paramilitaries stopped Sergey Mokrushin and Vladen Melnikov (of the [[Centre for Investigative Journalism]]) on the streets of [[Simferopol]] for singing an anti-Putin song. The two were detained and badly beaten, then passed to the police, who released them. -* [[Ruslan Yugosh]], among the founders of the ''[[Sobytiya Kryma]]'' (Crimean Events) news website, was summoned by the police in June 2014. In his absence from Crimea, the police interrogated his 73-years-old mother, threatening her with repercussions related to Yugosh' work. +* In June 2014 paramilitaries stopped Sergey Mokrushin and Vladen Melnikov (of the [[Centre for Investigative Journalism]]) on the streets of [[Simferopol]] for singing an anti-Putin song. The two were detained and badly beaten, then passed to the police, who released them. +* [[Ruslan Yugosh]], among the founders of the ''[[Sobytiya Kryma]]'' (Crimean Events) news website, was summoned by the police in June 2014. In his absence from Crimea, the police interrogated his 73-years-old mother, threatening her with repercussions related to Yugosh' work. Several human rights and civic activists chose to relocate to mainland Ukraine to escape restrictions, intimidation and harassment, providing information to the Crimean public via the internet. *The independent TV and radio station ''[[Chornomorska]]'' moved to the mainland after being forced off-air in March 2014 and having its equipment seized under the pretext of failure to pay fees. @@ -123,7 +123,7 @@ === Repression of Crimean Tatar media === [[Crimean Tatars|Crimean Tatar]] media were particularly targeted by Russian repression. [[ATR (TV channel)|ATR]], ''Avdet'' and the QHA news agency remained among the last independent media operating in Crimea by the end of 2014. -* In June 2014 Shevket Kaybullayev, editor of the ''Avdet'' newspaper, was questioned and warned by the prosecutor over "extremist contents" due to the paper's coverage of a opposition activities and the use of the term "occupation". In September 2014 the premises of the ''Avdet'' newspaper were raided and searched by unidentified security forces, without a warrant. The newspaper was closed down and its bank accounts seized. Kaybullayev was officially warned that he would be prosecuted and risked up to 5 years in jail if ''Avdet'' had continued reporting on calls for a boycott of the [[Crimean legislative election, 2014]]. +* In June 2014 Shevket Kaybullayev, editor of the ''Avdet'' newspaper, was questioned and warned by the prosecutor over "extremist contents" due to the paper's coverage of an opposition activities and the use of the term "occupation". In September 2014 the premises of the ''Avdet'' newspaper were raided and searched by unidentified security forces, without a warrant. The newspaper was closed down and its bank accounts seized. Kaybullayev was officially warned that he would be prosecuted and risked up to 5 years in jail if ''Avdet'' had continued reporting on calls for a boycott of the [[Crimean legislative election, 2014]]. * The Crimean Tatar TV channel [[ATR (TV channel)|ATR]] received a warning in May 2015 after covering a Tatar protest. It was subject to an inspection in September 2014 by the Interior Ministry, as suspect of inciting "extremism" and "distrust towards the authorities". KGB agents regularly called the station and applied pressures, threatening it with closure. == Situation in the occupied regions of Donetsk and Luhansk ==
comment: clean up, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: a opposition → an opposition using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the correction of a typo: "a opposition" was changed to "an opposition". 

Not Weaponised. The change is purely grammatical and does not alter the content or introduce any weaponised narratives related to cultural heritage.

--- 
+++ 
@@ -132,7 +132,7 @@
 
 In Donetsk and Luhansk, Russian-backed separatists seized control of broadcasting infrastructure, replacing Ukrainian channels with Russian pro-Kremlin channels in both on-air and cable transmissions.<ref name=FH/>
 
-In July 2014, pro-Russian separatists in Donetsk tried to deter journalists from covering the downing of the MH370 airliner by threatening them with arbitrary detention and intimidation.<ref name=FH/>
+In July 2014, pro-Russian separatists in Donetsk tried to deter journalists from covering the downing of the MH17 airliner by threatening them with arbitrary detention and intimidation.<ref name=FH/>
 
 ==See also==
comment: /* Situation in the occupied regions of Donetsk and Luhansk */ MH17 was shot down in Ukraine, not MH370
llm_output:
Changed "MH370" to "MH17" in the context of the downing of the airliner.

Not Weaponised. The change corrects a factual error regarding the incident without introducing any weaponisation language or narratives.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -80,43 +80,43 @@
 
 == Situation in the Russia-occupied Crimea ==
 
-The media environment in [[Crimea]] was completely transformed by the February 2014 Russian occupation and annexation of the peninsula, after the ejection of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] from power in [[Ukraine]] following the [[euromaidan]] protests. Occupation authorities engineered an annexation referendum to Russia, and restrictive Russian media laws started to be enacted in the Black Sea peninsula too. Media conditions in Crimea in 2014 were worse than in [[Russia]] itself, due to the effort of Russia-imposed authorities to rein in a previously relatively pluralistic media landscape. Media outlets were shut down, broadcasts of Ukrainian channels were suspended, and journalists fled the region due to fears of harassment, violence, and arrests.<ref name=FH>[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/crimea Crimea 2015 Press Freedom] report</ref>
+The media environment in [[Crimea]] was completely transformed by the February 2014 Russian occupation and annexation of the peninsula, after the ejection of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] from power in [[Ukraine]] following the [[euromaidan]] protests. Occupation authorities engineered an annexation referendum to Russia, and restrictive Russian media laws started to be enacted in the Black Sea peninsula too. Media conditions in Crimea in 2014 were worse than in [[Russia]] itself, due to the effort of Russia-imposed authorities to rein in a previously relatively pluralistic media landscape. Media outlets were shut down, broadcasts of Ukrainian channels were suspended, and journalists fled the region due to fears of harassment, violence, and arrests.<ref name=FHcrimea>[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/crimea Crimea 2015 Press Freedom] report</ref>
 
-Russian outlets, particularly state-owned ones, enjoy a dominant position in post-annexation Crimea. The distribution of Ukrainian print media has been obstructed by Russian officials, and even the Ukrainian Postal Agency had to stop deliveries in the peninsula. Widespread and irregular expropriations by Russian authorities have also affected the Crimean media landscape <ref name=FH/>
+Russian outlets, particularly state-owned ones, enjoy a dominant position in post-annexation Crimea. The distribution of Ukrainian print media has been obstructed by Russian officials, and even the Ukrainian Postal Agency had to stop deliveries in the peninsula. Widespread and irregular expropriations by Russian authorities have also affected the Crimean media landscape <ref name=FHcrimea/>
 
-Free access to the internet in Crimea was threatened by Russian authorities. [[Rostelecom]] laid a cable under the [[Kerch strait]] and provided online services in the peninsula starting from July 2014. Since August 2014, mobile phone services by Ukrainian carriers were disrupted and replaced by Russian companies.<ref name=FH/>
+Free access to the internet in Crimea was threatened by Russian authorities. [[Rostelecom]] laid a cable under the [[Kerch strait]] and provided online services in the peninsula starting from July 2014. Since August 2014, mobile phone services by Ukrainian carriers were disrupted and replaced by Russian companies.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 
 === Legal framework ===
-After the annexation, occupation authorities passed a local constitution on the Russian model and started imposing Russian legislation. Despite guarantees for freedom of speech and freedom of the press in the Russian legislation, politicised judiciary and restrictive laws devoid them of actual contents, leaving broad discretion to federal regulators in media registration and licensing.<ref name=FH/>
+After the annexation, occupation authorities passed a local constitution on the Russian model and started imposing Russian legislation. Despite guarantees for freedom of speech and freedom of the press in the Russian legislation, politicised judiciary and restrictive laws devoid them of actual contents, leaving broad discretion to federal regulators in media registration and licensing.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 
-All media in Crimea, including online ones, were afforded until January 2015 to register with the Russian federal media regulator [[Rozkomnadzor]] and get a license. Officials warned editors that registration would be denied to media that spread "extremist" contents. A December 2013 Russian law against separatism (carrying sanctions of up to 5 years in prison) was used to repress criticism of the annexation and calls for a return of the territory to Ukraine. <ref name=FH/>
+All media in Crimea, including online ones, were afforded until January 2015 to register with the Russian federal media regulator [[Rozkomnadzor]] and get a license. Officials warned editors that registration would be denied to media that spread "extremist" contents. A December 2013 Russian law against separatism (carrying sanctions of up to 5 years in prison) was used to repress criticism of the annexation and calls for a return of the territory to Ukraine.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 
 NGOs, journalists' associations and citizen groups in Crimea became subject to restrictive Russian laws, including measures limiting foreign funding.
-Russian occupation authorities failed to protect journalists, activists and citizens from abuses by paramilitaries and security forces. Cases of unlawful detentions and physical assaults were reported throughout 2014 in Crimea.<ref name=FH/>
+Russian occupation authorities failed to protect journalists, activists and citizens from abuses by paramilitaries and security forces. Cases of unlawful detentions and physical assaults were reported throughout 2014 in Crimea.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 
 === Attacks and threats against journalists ===
 
-Since the annexation, Russian authorities threatened and harassed pro-Ukrainian or simply independent media in Crimea. Media professionals - including foreign ones - have been obstructed, detained, questioned, and have had their equipment seized or destroyed. "Self-defence" paramilitary units have enjoyed impunity for their punitive actions against non-aligned journalists.<ref name=FH/>
-* In June 2014 paramilitaries stopped Sergey Mokrushin and Vladen Melnikov (of the [[Centre for Investigative Journalism]]) on the streets of [[Simferopol]] for singing an anti-Putin song. The two were detained and badly beaten, then passed to the police, who released them. <ref name=FH/>
-* [[Ruslan Yugosh]], among the founders of the ''[[Sobytiya Kryma]]'' (Crimean Events) news website, was summoned by the police in June 2014. In his absence from Crimea, the police interrogated his 73-years-old mother, threatening her with repercussions related to Yugosh' work. <ref name=FH/>
+Since the annexation, Russian authorities threatened and harassed pro-Ukrainian or simply independent media in Crimea. Media professionals - including foreign ones - have been obstructed, detained, questioned, and have had their equipment seized or destroyed. "Self-defence" paramilitary units have enjoyed impunity for their punitive actions against non-aligned journalists.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
+* In June 2014 paramilitaries stopped Sergey Mokrushin and Vladen Melnikov (of the [[Centre for Investigative Journalism]]) on the streets of [[Simferopol]] for singing an anti-Putin song. The two were detained and badly beaten, then passed to the police, who released them. <ref name=FHcrimea/>
+* [[Ruslan Yugosh]], among the founders of the ''[[Sobytiya Kryma]]'' (Crimean Events) news website, was summoned by the police in June 2014. In his absence from Crimea, the police interrogated his 73-years-old mother, threatening her with repercussions related to Yugosh' work. <ref name=FHcrimea/>
 
-Several human rights and civic activists chose to relocate to mainland Ukraine to escape restrictions, intimidation and harassment, providing information to the Crimean public via the internet.<ref name=FH/>
-*The independent TV and radio station ''[[Chornomorska]]'' moved to the mainland after being forced off-air in March 2014 and having its equipment seized under the pretext of failure to pay fees.<ref name=FH/>
-*The anti-annexation blogger [[Yelizaveta Bohutskaya]] left Crimea in September 2014 after a police raid at her home. She had been questioned for six hours and had had her equipment seized.<ref name=FH/>
-* [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] created a Crimean news service in Russian, Ukrainian and Tatar languages.<ref name=FH/>
+Several human rights and civic activists chose to relocate to mainland Ukraine to escape restrictions, intimidation and harassment, providing information to the Crimean public via the internet.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
+*The independent TV and radio station ''[[Chornomorska]]'' moved to the mainland after being forced off-air in March 2014 and having its equipment seized under the pretext of failure to pay fees.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
+*The anti-annexation blogger [[Yelizaveta Bohutskaya]] left Crimea in September 2014 after a police raid at her home. She had been questioned for six hours and had had her equipment seized.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
+* [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] created a Crimean news service in Russian, Ukrainian and Tatar languages.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 
 === Repression of Crimean Tatar media ===
-[[Crimean Tatar]] media were particularly targeted by Russian repression.  [[ATR (TV channel)|ATR]], ''Avdet'' and the QHA news agency remained among the last independent media operating in Crimea by the end of 2014.<ref name=FH/>
-* In June 2014 Shevket Kaybullayev, editor of the ''Avdet'' newspaper, was questioned and warned by the prosecutor over "extremist contents" due to the paper's coverage of a opposition activities and the use of the term "occupation". In September 2014 the premises of the ''Avdet'' newspaper were raided and searched  by unidentified security forces, without a warrant. The newspaper was closed down and its bank accounts seized. Kaybullayev was officially warned that he would be prosecuted and risked up to 5 years in jail if ''Avdet'' had continued reporting on calls for a boycott of the [[Crimean legislative election, 2014]].<ref name=FH/>
-* The Crimean Tatar TV channel [[ATR (TV channel)|ATR]] received a warning in May 2015 after covering a Tatar protest. It was subject to an inspection in September 2014 by the Interior Ministry, as suspect of inciting "extremism" and "distrust towards the authorities". KGB agents regularly called the station and applied pressures, threatening it with closure.<ref name=FH/>
+[[Crimean Tatar]] media were particularly targeted by Russian repression.  [[ATR (TV channel)|ATR]], ''Avdet'' and the QHA news agency remained among the last independent media operating in Crimea by the end of 2014.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
+* In June 2014 Shevket Kaybullayev, editor of the ''Avdet'' newspaper, was questioned and warned by the prosecutor over "extremist contents" due to the paper's coverage of a opposition activities and the use of the term "occupation". In September 2014 the premises of the ''Avdet'' newspaper were raided and searched  by unidentified security forces, without a warrant. The newspaper was closed down and its bank accounts seized. Kaybullayev was officially warned that he would be prosecuted and risked up to 5 years in jail if ''Avdet'' had continued reporting on calls for a boycott of the [[Crimean legislative election, 2014]].<ref name=FHcrimea/>
+* The Crimean Tatar TV channel [[ATR (TV channel)|ATR]] received a warning in May 2015 after covering a Tatar protest. It was subject to an inspection in September 2014 by the Interior Ministry, as suspect of inciting "extremism" and "distrust towards the authorities". KGB agents regularly called the station and applied pressures, threatening it with closure.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 
 == Situation in the occupied regions of Donetsk and Luhansk ==
 {{See also|Humanitarian situation during the war in Donbass}}
-Seven journalists and media workers were killed in Ukraine in 2014. One of them, [[Vyacheslav Veremiy]] of ''Vesti'', was shot in Kiev in February 2014. The others died in the conflict areas in the east.<ref name="FH" />
+Seven journalists and media workers were killed in Ukraine in 2014. One of them, [[Vyacheslav Veremiy]] of ''Vesti'', was shot in Kiev in February 2014. The others died in the conflict areas in the east.<ref name=FH/>
 
-In Donetsk and Luhansk, Russian-backed separatists seized control of broadcasting infrastructure, replacing Ukrainian channels with Russian pro-Kremlin channels in both on-air and cable transmissions. <ref name=FH/>
+In Donetsk and Luhansk, Russian-backed separatists seized control of broadcasting infrastructure, replacing Ukrainian channels with Russian pro-Kremlin channels in both on-air and cable transmissions.<ref name=FH/>
 
-In July 2014, pro-Russian separatists in Donetsk tried to deter journalists from covering the downing of the MH370 airliner by threatening them with arbitrary detention and intimidation. <ref name=FH/>
+In July 2014, pro-Russian separatists in Donetsk tried to deter journalists from covering the downing of the MH370 airliner by threatening them with arbitrary detention and intimidation.<ref name=FH/>

@@ -78,7 +78,39 @@
 Under former [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Leonid Kuchma]] opposition papers were closed and several journalists died in mysterious circumstances.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1102303.stm#media|title=Ukraine country profile: Media|work=bbc.co.uk|date=26 April 2012|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> 
 {{Timeline of reporters killed in Ukraine}}
 
-== Situation in the occupied regions of Crimea, Donetsk and Luhansk ==
+== Situation in the Russia-occupied Crimea ==
+
+The media environment in [[Crimea]] was completely transformed by the February 2014 Russian occupation and annexation of the peninsula, after the ejection of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] from power in [[Ukraine]] following the [[euromaidan]] protests. Occupation authorities engineered an annexation referendum to Russia, and restrictive Russian media laws started to be enacted in the Black Sea peninsula too. Media conditions in Crimea in 2014 were worse than in [[Russia]] itself, due to the effort of Russia-imposed authorities to rein in a previously relatively pluralistic media landscape. Media outlets were shut down, broadcasts of Ukrainian channels were suspended, and journalists fled the region due to fears of harassment, violence, and arrests.<ref name=FH>[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/crimea Crimea 2015 Press Freedom] report</ref>
+
+Russian outlets, particularly state-owned ones, enjoy a dominant position in post-annexation Crimea. The distribution of Ukrainian print media has been obstructed by Russian officials, and even the Ukrainian Postal Agency had to stop deliveries in the peninsula. Widespread and irregular expropriations by Russian authorities have also affected the Crimean media landscape <ref name=FH/>
+
+Free access to the internet in Crimea was threatened by Russian authorities. [[Rostelecom]] laid a cable under the [[Kerch strait]] and provided online services in the peninsula starting from July 2014. Since August 2014, mobile phone services by Ukrainian carriers were disrupted and replaced by Russian companies.<ref name=FH/>
+
+=== Legal framework ===
+After the annexation, occupation authorities passed a local constitution on the Russian model and started imposing Russian legislation. Despite guarantees for freedom of speech and freedom of the press in the Russian legislation, politicised judiciary and restrictive laws devoid them of actual contents, leaving broad discretion to federal regulators in media registration and licensing.<ref name=FH/>
+
+All media in Crimea, including online ones, were afforded until January 2015 to register with the Russian federal media regulator [[Rozkomnadzor]] and get a license. Officials warned editors that registration would be denied to media that spread "extremist" contents. A December 2013 Russian law against separatism (carrying sanctions of up to 5 years in prison) was used to repress criticism of the annexation and calls for a return of the territory to Ukraine. <ref name=FH/>
+
+NGOs, journalists' associations and citizen groups in Crimea became subject to restrictive Russian laws, including measures limiting foreign funding.
+Russian occupation authorities failed to protect journalists, activists and citizens from abuses by paramilitaries and security forces. Cases of unlawful detentions and physical assaults were reported throughout 2014 in Crimea.<ref name=FH/>
+
+=== Attacks and threats against journalists ===
+
+Since the annexation, Russian authorities threatened and harassed pro-Ukrainian or simply independent media in Crimea. Media professionals - including foreign ones - have been obstructed, detained, questioned, and have had their equipment seized or destroyed. "Self-defence" paramilitary units have enjoyed impunity for their punitive actions against non-aligned journalists.<ref name=FH/>
+* In June 2014 paramilitaries stopped Sergey Mokrushin and Vladen Melnikov (of the [[Centre for Investigative Journalism]]) on the streets of [[Simferopol]] for singing an anti-Putin song. The two were detained and badly beaten, then passed to the police, who released them. <ref name=FH/>
+* [[Ruslan Yugosh]], among the founders of the ''[[Sobytiya Kryma]]'' (Crimean Events) news website, was summoned by the police in June 2014. In his absence from Crimea, the police interrogated his 73-years-old mother, threatening her with repercussions related to Yugosh' work. <ref name=FH/>
+
+Several human rights and civic activists chose to relocate to mainland Ukraine to escape restrictions, intimidation and harassment, providing information to the Crimean public via the internet.<ref name=FH/>
+*The independent TV and radio station ''[[Chornomorska]]'' moved to the mainland after being forced off-air in March 2014 and having its equipment seized under the pretext of failure to pay fees.<ref name=FH/>
+*The anti-annexation blogger [[Yelizaveta Bohutskaya]] left Crimea in September 2014 after a police raid at her home. She had been questioned for six hours and had had her equipment seized.<ref name=FH/>
+* [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] created a Crimean news service in Russian, Ukrainian and Tatar languages.<ref name=FH/>
+
+=== Repression of Crimean Tatar media ===
+[[Crimean Tatar]] media were particularly targeted by Russian repression.  [[ATR (TV channel)|ATR]], ''Avdet'' and the QHA news agency remained among the last independent media operating in Crimea by the end of 2014.<ref name=FH/>
+* In June 2014 Shevket Kaybullayev, editor of the ''Avdet'' newspaper, was questioned and warned by the prosecutor over "extremist contents" due to the paper's coverage of a opposition activities and the use of the term "occupation". In September 2014 the premises of the ''Avdet'' newspaper were raided and searched  by unidentified security forces, without a warrant. The newspaper was closed down and its bank accounts seized. Kaybullayev was officially warned that he would be prosecuted and risked up to 5 years in jail if ''Avdet'' had continued reporting on calls for a boycott of the [[Crimean legislative election, 2014]].<ref name=FH/>
+* The Crimean Tatar TV channel [[ATR (TV channel)|ATR]] received a warning in May 2015 after covering a Tatar protest. It was subject to an inspection in September 2014 by the Interior Ministry, as suspect of inciting "extremism" and "distrust towards the authorities". KGB agents regularly called the station and applied pressures, threatening it with closure.<ref name=FH/>
+
+== Situation in the occupied regions of Donetsk and Luhansk ==
 
 Seven journalists and media workers were killed in Ukraine in 2014. One of them, [[Vyacheslav Veremiy]] of ''Vesti'', was shot in Kiev in February 2014. The others died in the conflict areas in the east.<ref name="FH" />

The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}|group=nb}} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014. * Ukrainian authorities denied entry to several Russian journalists throughout 2014, with bans on re-entry for some of up to 5 years * The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)]] was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)

{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].[http://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry] , [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014) * On 16 September 2015 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning forty-one foreign journalists and bloggers who 'threaten national interests' from Ukraine. This was later reduced to 38.{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 September 2015}} + +In September 2015 34 journalists and 7 bloggers considered to either "threaten national interests" or "promote terrorist activities", including three [[BBC]] journalists, were put on an exclusion list. After international pressure, the three BBC journalists and three other foreign journalists were taken off this list.{{cite news |url=http://www.voanews.com/content/cpj-osce-blast-ukraine-on-foreign-journalists-entry-ban/2967882.html |title=In Reversal, Ukraine Removes 6 Journalists From Banned List |author=Isabela Cocoli |publisher=Voice of America |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=31 July 2016}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jun/02/ukraine-bans-russian-journalists-margarita-simonyan |title=Ukraine bans Russian journalists accused of 'stirring hatred' |author=Shaun Walker |newspaper=The Guardian |date=2 June 2016 |accessdate=31 July 2016}} In 2016 17 Russian journalists were barred from entering Ukraine, or owning property or holding bank accounts in Ukraine. comment: add journalists barred from Ukraine, add sub-section title
llm_output:
Added a new sub-section titled "Censorship and media freedom (2015-2016)" and included details about journalists barred from Ukraine.

Not Weaponised. The changes primarily focus on media censorship and the treatment of journalists without employing weaponisation terms or narratives that could be seen as promoting a specific political agenda.

changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -69,15 +69,12 @@ Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media. Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too. In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication. -===Censorship and media freedom (2015-2016)=== [[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kiev government. Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view. For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey “propaganda,” and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country. *The broadcasting regulators was mandated by courts to suspend temporarily the rebroadcasting of certain Russian channels in Ukraine. In 2014 Ukraine blocked 14 Russian television channels from its cable networks.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014. By September 2014, the number of television channels blocked from Ukrainian cable networks had risen to 15; the legal basis for this were charges of stirring hatred, threatening national security and supporting separatism. *On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}{{#tag:ref|The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}|group=nb}} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014. * Ukrainian authorities denied entry to several Russian journalists throughout 2014, with bans on re-entry for some of up to 5 years * The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)]] was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)
{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].[http://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry] , [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014) * On 16 September 2015 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning forty-one foreign journalists and bloggers who 'threaten national interests' from Ukraine. This was later reduced to 38.{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 September 2015}} - -In September 2015 34 journalists and 7 bloggers considered to either "threaten national interests" or "promote terrorist activities", including three [[BBC]] journalists, were put on an exclusion list. After international pressure, the three BBC journalists and three other foreign journalists were taken off this list.{{cite news |url=http://www.voanews.com/content/cpj-osce-blast-ukraine-on-foreign-journalists-entry-ban/2967882.html |title=In Reversal, Ukraine Removes 6 Journalists From Banned List |author=Isabela Cocoli |publisher=Voice of America |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=31 July 2016}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jun/02/ukraine-bans-russian-journalists-margarita-simonyan |title=Ukraine bans Russian journalists accused of 'stirring hatred' |author=Shaun Walker |newspaper=The Guardian |date=2 June 2016 |accessdate=31 July 2016}} In 2016 17 Russian journalists were barred from entering Ukraine, or owning property or holding bank accounts in Ukraine. Since November 2015 Ukrainian authorities, state agencies and local government authorities are forbidden to act as founders (or cofounders) of printed media outlets.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/306311.html Ukrainian state authorities can not be founders, cofounders of printed media from now on], [[Interfax Ukraine]] (24 November 2015)
comment: Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/Rwendland|Rwendland]] ([[User talk:Rwendland|talk]]): Rv You're repeating exactly the same content as in the paragraph above. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
llm_output:
Removed a section titled "Censorship and media freedom (2015-2016)" along with its content.

Not Weaponised. The removal of this section does not introduce or reinforce any specific cultural narratives or weaponised language; it simply eliminates a portion of the article without altering the overall context regarding media freedom and censorship.

changed_version:
