Next to [[Ukraine]] [[Freedom House]] [https://freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/Map%20of%20Freedom%202013%2C%20final.pdf considers also to be "partly free"] [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Moldova]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Abkhazia]], [[Armenia]] and [[Nagorno-Karabakh]].|group=nb}}[http://books.google.com/books?id=1CcQj3DjrHAC&pg=PA39&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=-Jd1TOTTJOGkOJzD5KwG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CFsQ6AEwBzge#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Ukraine (Country Guide)] by [[Sarah Johnstone]] and [[Greg Bloom]], [[Lonely Planet]], 2008, ISBN 978-1-74104-481-2 (page 39)[http://books.google.com/books?id=ba65SKN2I_UC&pg=PA11&lpg=PA11&dq=The+repressive+media+landscape+in+the+former+Soviet+Union+is+illuminated+by+the+fact+that+10+of+the+12+non-Baltic+post-Soviet+states+are+ranked+as+Not+Free.+The+only+two+that+enjoy+Partly+Free+status,+Georgia+and+Ukraine,+have+recently+experienced+political+upheaval+and+democratic+opening&source=bl&ots=ftIAiQ5L68&sig=pZDPbohOUOfCaBUP_xpmtOIaJDI&hl=nl&ei=hhOJTJ74GMemOO6OjYsH&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=The%20repressive%20media%20landscape%20in%20the%20former%20Soviet%20Union%20is%20illuminated%20by%20the%20fact%20that%2010%20of%20the%2012%20non-Baltic%20post-Soviet%20states%20are%20ranked%20as%20Not%20Free.%20The%20only%20two%20that%20enjoy%20Partly%20Free%20status%2C%20Georgia%20and%20Ukraine%2C%20have%20recently%20experienced%20political%20upheaval%20and%20democratic%20opening&f=false Freedom of the Press 2007: A Global Survey of Media Independence] by [[Freedom House]], [[Rowman & Littlefield]], 2007, ISBN 978-0-7425-5582-2 (page 11/12) +'''Media freedom in Ukraine''' was considered in 2013 to be among the best of the [[post-Soviet states]] other than the [[Baltic states]].{{#tag:ref|The [[Baltic states]] are the only [[post-Soviet states]][https://freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/Map%20of%20Freedom%202013%2C%20final.pdf that Freedom House considers "free"]. Next to [[Ukraine]] [[Freedom House]] [https://freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/Map%20of%20Freedom%202013%2C%20final.pdf considers also to be "partly free"] [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Moldova]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Abkhazia]], [[Armenia]] and [[Nagorno-Karabakh]].|group=nb}}[http://books.google.com/books?id=1CcQj3DjrHAC&pg=PA39&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=-Jd1TOTTJOGkOJzD5KwG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CFsQ6AEwBzge#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Ukraine (Country Guide)] by [[Sarah Johnstone]] and [[Greg Bloom]], [[Lonely Planet]], 2008, ISBN 978-1-74104-481-2 (page 39)[http://books.google.com/books?id=ba65SKN2I_UC&pg=PA11&lpg=PA11&dq=The+repressive+media+landscape+in+the+former+Soviet+Union+is+illuminated+by+the+fact+that+10+of+the+12+non-Baltic+post-Soviet+states+are+ranked+as+Not+Free.+The+only+two+that+enjoy+Partly+Free+status,+Georgia+and+Ukraine,+have+recently+experienced+political+upheaval+and+democratic+opening&source=bl&ots=ftIAiQ5L68&sig=pZDPbohOUOfCaBUP_xpmtOIaJDI&hl=nl&ei=hhOJTJ74GMemOO6OjYsH&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=The%20repressive%20media%20landscape%20in%20the%20former%20Soviet%20Union%20is%20illuminated%20by%20the%20fact%20that%2010%20of%20the%2012%20non-Baltic%20post-Soviet%20states%20are%20ranked%20as%20Not%20Free.%20The%20only%20two%20that%20enjoy%20Partly%20Free%20status%2C%20Georgia%20and%20Ukraine%2C%20have%20recently%20experienced%20political%20upheaval%20and%20democratic%20opening&f=false Freedom of the Press 2007: A Global Survey of Media Independence] by [[Freedom House]], [[Rowman & Littlefield]], 2007, ISBN 978-0-7425-5582-2 (page 11/12) + +[[Freedom House]] reported the status of press freedom in Ukraine in 2015 as improving from Not Free to Partly Free. It justified the change as follows:[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine Ukraine 2015 Freedom of the Press] report +
due to profound changes in the media environment after the fall of President Viktor Yanukovych’s government in February, despite a rise in attacks on journalists during the Euromaidan protests of early 2014 and the subsequent conflict in eastern Ukraine. The level of government hostility and legal pressure faced by journalists decreased, as did political pressure on state-owned outlets. The media also benefited from improvements to the law on access to information and the increased independence of the broadcasting regulator.
+In 2015 the main concerns about media freedom in Ukraine concern the handling of pro-Russian propaganda, the concentration of media ownership, and the high risks of violence against journalists, especially in the conflict areas in the east. As of September 2015, [[Freedom House]] classifies the [[Internet in Ukraine]] as "partly free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] as "partly free".{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/country/ukraine|title=Ukraine|work=freedomhouse.org|accessdate=28 September 2015}} Press freedom had significantly improved since the [[Orange Revolution]] of 2004. However, in 2010 Freedom House perceived "negative trends in Ukraine".[http://www.rferl.org/content/freedom_house_freedom_in_the_world_report/2275173.html Report Says Decline In Freedom Continues Across Former Soviet Union], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (January 13, 2011) -According to the [[US Department of State]] in 2009 there were no attempts by central authorities to direct media content, but there were reports of intimidation of journalists by national and local officials.[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136063.htm 2009 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 11, 2010) Media at times demonstrated a tendency toward self‑censorship on matters that the government deemed sensitive.[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/eur/119110.htm 2008 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2009) Stories in the electronic and printed media (veiled advertisements and positive coverage presented as news) and participation in a television talk show can be bought. Media watchdog groups have express concern over the extremely high monetary damages that were demanded in [[Judicial system of Ukraine|court cases]] concerning [[libel]]. +The Ukrainian legal framework on media freedom is deemed "among the most progressive in eastern Europe", although implementation has been uneven. +The [[Constitution of Ukraine]] and a 1991 law provide for freedom of speech.[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/1999/367.htm 1999 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2000) -The [[Constitution of Ukraine]] and a 1991 law provide for freedom of speech.[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/1999/367.htm 1999 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2000) +Many Ukrainian journalists found themselves internally displaced due to the Russian occupation of [[Crimea]] and the [[war in Donbass]], including Donetsk-based investigative journalist Oleksiy Matsuka, Luhansk blogger Serhiy Ivanov and Donetsk ''Ostrov'' independent website editor Serhiy Harmash. The entire staff of ''Ostrov'' left the occupied Donbass areas and relocated to Kiev. + +==History== +The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992 till 2003, when it was rated "not free".{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2003?page=251&year=2003|title=Freedom of the Press 2003|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2003|accessdate=28 September 2015}} Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2010?page=251&year=2010|title=Freedom of the Press 2010|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2009?page=251&year=2009|title=Freedom of the Press 2009|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2009|accessdate=28 September 2015}} According to Freedom House [[internet in Ukraine]] is "Free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] is "Partly Free". + +Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2009|work=rsf.org|date=2009|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20091022183400/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|archive-date=22 October 2009}} 87 in 2008{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2008|work=rsf.org|date=2008|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090607100340/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|archive-date=7 June 2009}}), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2002|work=rsf.org|date=October 2002|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090703081345/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|archive-date=3 July 2009}} and even the 132nd spot in 2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2004|work=rsf.org|date=2004|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090905174452/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|archive-date=5 September 2009}} In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|Viktor Yanukovych’s election as president in February]]".{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2010|work=rsf.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015}} In 2013 Ukraine occupied the 126th spot (dropping 10 places compared with 2012); (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".{{cite web|format=PDF|url=http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|title=Press Freedom Index 2013|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|accessdate=29 September 2015}} In the 2014 World Press Freedom Index Ukraine was placed 127th.{{cite news|url=http://uatoday.tv/news/ukraine-takes-127th-place-in-rating-of-freedom-of-speech-402225.html|title=Ukraine takes 127th place in rating of freedom of speech|work=[[Ukraine Today]]|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=29 September 2015}} + +During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and [[Southeastern Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/half-of-all-ukrainians-consider-current-freedom-of-50721.html|title=Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=15 October 2009|accessdate=29 September 2015}} +In a late 2010 poll also conducted by the Research & Branding Group 56% of all Ukrainians trusted the media and 38.5% didn't.[http://web.archive.org/web/20110120213543/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/ Poll: More than half of Ukrainians trust the media], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 17, 2010) + +=== Kuchma presidencies (1994-2004) === +[[File:Georgi gongadse.jpg|thumbnail|[[Georgiy Gongadze]], [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] journalist, founder of a popular Internet newspaper [[Ukrayinska Pravda]], who was kidnapped and murdered in 2000.]] + +After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN 978-3-03910-468-0 (page 21) During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed. In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN 978-0-7658-0897-4 (page 397) In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency[http://web.archive.org/web/20110905041903/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 11, 2010)[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship. In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover. Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner. + +=== Orange revolution and Yushchenko presidency (2004-2010) === +Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media has become more pluralistic and independent.[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (April 28, 2006 )[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 6, 2007) For instance, attempts by authorities to limit freedom of the press through tax inspections have ceased.[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2004)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 28, 2005)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2001)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 4, 2002)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 31, 2003)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 8, 2006) Since then the Ukrainian press is considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]] (only the [[Baltic states]] are considered "free"). + +In December 2009 during the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|2010 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign incumbent [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] and presidential candidate[http://web.archive.org/web/20110201024403/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/54511/ More women than men support Tymoshenko, poll shows], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 7, 2009) [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] complained Ukrainian TV channels are manipulating the consciousness of citizens in favor of financial and [[oligarchic]] groups.[http://web.archive.org/web/20091212093435/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/54545/ Tymoshenko accuses central TV channels of manipulating people's consciousness in favor of oligarchs], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 8, 2009) + +===Yanukovych presidency (2010-2013)=== +In Spring 2010 Ukrainian journalists, the [[European Federation of Journalists]] and [[Reporters Without Borders]] all complained of censorship by [[Viktor Yanukovych#Presidency|President Yanukovych's]] [[Presidential Administration of Ukraine|administration]].[http://web.archive.org/web/20100510052704/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66011/ 1+1 TV journalists claim censorship of news reports], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 6, 2009)[http://web.archive.org/web/20100511155833/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66119/ STB TV channel journalists claim imposing of censorship on STB], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 8, 2009)[http://web.archive.org/web/20100903132356/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66353/ European journalists call on Ukrainian authorities, media owners to respect press freedom], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 11, 2009) This despite statements by Yanukovych how deeply he values press freedom and that ‘free, independent media that must ensure society’s unimpeded access to information’. Anonymous journalists stated early May 2010 that they were voluntarily tailoring their coverage so as not to offend the Yanukovych administration and the [[Azarov Government]].[http://web.archive.org/web/20100510052659/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66009/ Journalists, in defensive crouch, swing news coverage to Yanukovych’s favor], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 6, 2009) The Azarov Government denies censoring the media,[http://web.archive.org/web/20110606044659/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66616/ Semynozhenko: No examples of censorship on Ukrainian TV channels], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 13, 2009) so did the [[Presidential Administration of Ukraine|Presidential Administration]][http://web.archive.org/web/20100515071104/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/66596/ Opposition benefiting from topic of censorship at mass media, says Hanna Herman], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 13, 2009) and President Yanukovych himself.{{uk icon}} [http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/ukraine/2010/05/100513_yanukovych_marta_oh.shtml Янукович: Україна готова, якщо Європа готова], [[BBC Ukrainian]] (May 10, 2010) [[Presidential Administration of Ukraine|Presidential Administration]] Deputy Head [[Hanna Herman]] stated on May 13, 2010 that the opposition benefited from discussions about the freedom of the press in Ukraine and also suggested that the recent reaction of foreign journalists organizations had been provoked by the opposition. On May 12, 2010, the [[Ukrainian Parliament|parliamentary]] committee for freedom of speech and information called on the [[General Prosecutor of Ukraine|General Prosecutor]]'s Office to immediately investigate complaints by journalists of pressure on journalists and censorship.[http://web.archive.org/web/20110606044759/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66628/ Special committee calls to check reports of pressure on journalists], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 13, 2009) + +A law on strengthening the protection of the ownership of [[mass media]] offices, [[publishing house]]s, bookshops and distributors, as well as [[creative unions]] was passed by the [[Ukrainian Parliament]] on May 20, 2010.[http://web.archive.org/web/20100523192802/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/67398/ Parliament bans forced removal of state and municipal mass media offices], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 21, 2009) + +Since the February 2010 election of Viktor Yanukovych as President Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased. The [[International Press Institute]] addressed an open letter to President Yanukovych on August 10, 2010 urging him to address what the organisation saw as a disturbing deterioration in press freedom over the previous six months in Ukraine.[http://web.archive.org/web/20100811172630/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/ International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'signficiantly'], [[Kyiv Post]] (August 11, 2010) [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] rapporteur [[Renate Wohlwend]] noticed on October 6, 2010 that "Some progress had been made in recent years but there had also been some retrograde steps".[http://web.archive.org/web/20101007235843/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85208/ European rapporteurs note media setback in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 6, 2010) In January 2011 [[Freedom House]] stated it had perceived "negative trends in Ukraine" during 2010; these included: curbs on press freedom, the intimidation of [[civil society]], and greater [[Government of Ukraine|government]] influence on the [[Judicial system of Ukraine|judiciary]]. + +According to the [[US Department of State]] in 2009 there were no attempts by central authorities to direct media content, but there were reports of intimidation of journalists by national and local officials.[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136063.htm 2009 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 11, 2010) Media at times demonstrated a tendency toward [[self‑censorship]] on matters that the government deemed sensitive.[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/eur/119110.htm 2008 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2009) Stories in the electronic and printed media (veiled advertisements and positive coverage presented as news) and participation in a television talk show can be bought. Media watchdog groups have express concern over the extremely high monetary damages that were demanded in [[Judicial system of Ukraine|court cases]] concerning [[libel]]. In Ukraine’s provinces numerous, anonymous attacks[http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900 Local newspaper editor badly injured in assault], [[Reporters Without Borders]] (March 31, 2010) and threats persisted against journalists, who investigated or exposed corruption or other government misdeeds.[http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-disturbing-deterioration-in-press-15-04-2010,37027.html Disturbing deterioration in press freedom situation since new president took over], [[Reporters Without Borders]] (April 15, 2010)[http://web.archive.org/web/20100424113640/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/64793/ Media crackdown under way?], [[Kyiv Post]] (April 22, 2010) The US-based [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] concluded in 2007 that these attacks, and police reluctance in some cases to pursue the perpetrators, were "helping to foster an atmosphere of impunity against independent journalists."{{cite web|url=http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|title=Ukraine: Events of 2006|work=hrw.org|date=2007|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20070704194735/http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|archive-date=4 July 2007}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hrw.org/en/node/79345|title=Ukraine:Events of 2008|work=hrw.org|dead-url=y|date=2009|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090117073609/http://www.hrw.org/en/node/79345|archive-date=17 January 2009}} Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased since the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|February 2010 election]] of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] as [[Ukrainian President|President]].[http://www.rferl.org/content/Concerns_Mount_About_Press_Freedom_In_Ukraine_As_Journalist_Attacked/2164350.html Concerns Mount About Press Freedom In Ukraine As Journalist Attacked], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (September 21, 2010) -In Ukraine many news-outlets are financed by wealthy investors and reflected the political and economic interests of their owners.[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/kyiv-post-plus/experts-media-owners-overtake-government-as-top-threat-to-free-speech-398627.html Experts: Media owners overtake government as top threat to free speech], [[Kyiv Post]] (24 September 2015) +=== Euromaidan revolution and Poroshenko presidency (2014) === +[[File:Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, Kyiv. Events of February 18, 2014..jpg|thumbnail|Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, [[Kyiv]]. Events of February 18, 2014.]]Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.{{cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }} The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kiev (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. +In 2014 restrictions to press freedom in Ukraine included police impeding access to public buildings, physical attacks on press rooms, and cyberattacks (e.g. against the ''Glavnoe'', ''Gordon'' and [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] websites); in July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''. -==History== -[[File:Georgi gongadse.jpg|thumbnail|[[Georgiy Gongadze]], [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] journalist, founder of a popular Internet newspaper [[Ukrayinska Pravda]], who was kidnapped and murdered in 2000.]] -After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN 978-3-03910-468-0 (page 21) During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed. In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN 978-0-7658-0897-4 (page 397) In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency[http://web.archive.org/web/20110905041903/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 11, 2010)[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship. In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover. Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner. +Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media. Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too. In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication. -Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media has become more pluralistic and independent.[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (April 28, 2006 )[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 6, 2007) For instance, attempts by authorities to limit freedom of the press through tax inspections have ceased.[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2004)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 28, 2005)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2001)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 4, 2002)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 31, 2003)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 8, 2006) Since then the Ukrainian press is considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]] (only the [[Baltic states]] are considered "free"). - -===Latest developments=== -[[File:Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, Kyiv. Events of February 18, 2014..jpg|thumbnail|Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, [[Kyiv]]. Events of February 18, 2014.]] -In December 2009 during the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|2010 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign incumbent [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] and presidential candidate[http://web.archive.org/web/20110201024403/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/54511/ More women than men support Tymoshenko, poll shows], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 7, 2009) [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] complained Ukrainian TV channels are manipulating the consciousness of citizens in favor of financial and [[oligarchic]] groups.[http://web.archive.org/web/20091212093435/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/54545/ Tymoshenko accuses central TV channels of manipulating people's consciousness in favor of oligarchs], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 8, 2009) - -In Spring 2010 Ukrainian journalists, the [[European Federation of Journalists]] and [[Reporters Without Borders]] all complained of censorship by [[Viktor Yanukovych#Presidency|President Yanukovych's]] [[Presidential Administration of Ukraine|administration]].[http://web.archive.org/web/20100510052704/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66011/ 1+1 TV journalists claim censorship of news reports], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 6, 2009)[http://web.archive.org/web/20100511155833/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66119/ STB TV channel journalists claim imposing of censorship on STB], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 8, 2009)[http://web.archive.org/web/20100903132356/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66353/ European journalists call on Ukrainian authorities, media owners to respect press freedom], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 11, 2009) This despite statements by Yanukovych how deeply he values press freedom and that ‘free, independent media that must ensure society’s unimpeded access to information’. Anonymous journalists stated early May 2010 that they were voluntarily tailoring their coverage so as not to offend the Yanukovych administration and the [[Azarov Government]].[http://web.archive.org/web/20100510052659/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66009/ Journalists, in defensive crouch, swing news coverage to Yanukovych’s favor], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 6, 2009) The Azarov Government denies censoring the media,[http://web.archive.org/web/20110606044659/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66616/ Semynozhenko: No examples of censorship on Ukrainian TV channels], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 13, 2009) so did the [[Presidential Administration of Ukraine|Presidential Administration]][http://web.archive.org/web/20100515071104/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/66596/ Opposition benefiting from topic of censorship at mass media, says Hanna Herman], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 13, 2009) and President Yanukovych himself.{{uk icon}} [http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/ukraine/2010/05/100513_yanukovych_marta_oh.shtml Янукович: Україна готова, якщо Європа готова], [[BBC Ukrainian]] (May 10, 2010) [[Presidential Administration of Ukraine|Presidential Administration]] Deputy Head [[Hanna Herman]] stated on May 13, 2010 that the opposition benefited from discussions about the freedom of the press in Ukraine and also suggested that the recent reaction of foreign journalists organizations had been provoked by the opposition. On May 12, 2010, the [[Ukrainian Parliament|parliamentary]] committee for freedom of speech and information called on the [[General Prosecutor of Ukraine|General Prosecutor]]'s Office to immediately investigate complaints by journalists of pressure on journalists and censorship.[http://web.archive.org/web/20110606044759/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66628/ Special committee calls to check reports of pressure on journalists], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 13, 2009) - -A law on strengthening the protection of the ownership of [[mass media]] offices, [[publishing house]]s, bookshops and distributors, as well as [[creative unions]] was passed by the [[Ukrainian Parliament]] on May 20, 2010.[http://web.archive.org/web/20100523192802/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/67398/ Parliament bans forced removal of state and municipal mass media offices], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 21, 2009) - -Since the February 2010 election of Viktor Yanukovych as President Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased. The [[International Press Institute]] addressed an open letter to President Yanukovych on August 10, 2010 urging him to address what the organisation saw as a disturbing deterioration in press freedom over the previous six months in Ukraine.[http://web.archive.org/web/20100811172630/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/ International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'signficiantly'], [[Kyiv Post]] (August 11, 2010) [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] rapporteur [[Renate Wohlwend]] noticed on October 6, 2010 that "Some progress had been made in recent years but there had also been some retrograde steps".[http://web.archive.org/web/20101007235843/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85208/ European rapporteurs note media setback in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 6, 2010) In January 2011 [[Freedom House]] stated it had perceived "negative trends in Ukraine" during 2010; these included: curbs on press freedom, the intimidation of [[civil society]], and greater [[Government of Ukraine|government]] influence on the [[Judicial system of Ukraine|judiciary]]. - -The ongoing [[crisis in Ukraine]] has resulted in a perceived major threat to press freedom in recent months.{{by whom|date=November 2015}} A May 2014 report from the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.{{cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }} Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view. - -For example, the 11 September 2014 shutdown of the Vesti newspaper by the Ukrainian Security Service for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international Committee to Protect Journalists and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}{{#tag:ref|The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}|group=nb}} - -Ukraine has also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey “propaganda,” and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.{{main|Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)}} -The Ministry of Information Policy was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)
{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].[http://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry ], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014) - -In 2014 Ukraine blocked 14 Russian television channels from its cable networks.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014. - -On 16 September 2015 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning forty-one foreign journalists and bloggers who 'threaten national interests' from Ukraine. This was later reduced to 38.{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 September 2015}} +[[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian occupation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kiev government. Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view. For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey “propaganda,” and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country. +*The broadcasting regulators was mandated by courts to suspend temporarily the rebroadcasting of certain Russian channels in Ukraine. In 2014 Ukraine blocked 14 Russian television channels from its cable networks.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014. It suspended 15 channels by September 2015 on charges of stirring hatred, threatening national security and supporting separatism. +*On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}{{#tag:ref|The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}|group=nb}} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014. +* Ukrainian authorities denied entry to several Russian journalists throughout 2014, with bans on re-entry for some of up to 5 years +* The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)]] was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)
{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].[http://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry] , [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014) +* On 16 September 2015 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning forty-one foreign journalists and bloggers who 'threaten national interests' from Ukraine. This was later reduced to 38.{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 September 2015}} Since November 2015 Ukrainian authorities, state agencies and local government authorities are forbidden to act as founders (or cofounders) of printed media outlets.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/306311.html Ukrainian state authorities can not be founders, cofounders of printed media from now on], [[Interfax Ukraine]] (24 November 2015) -===Rankings=== -The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992 till 2003, when it was rated "not free".{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2003?page=251&year=2003|title=Freedom of the Press 2003|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2003|accessdate=28 September 2015}} Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2010?page=251&year=2010|title=Freedom of the Press 2010|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2009?page=251&year=2009|title=Freedom of the Press 2009|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2009|accessdate=28 September 2015}} According to Freedom House [[internet in Ukraine]] is "Free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] is "Partly Free". +== Attacks and threats against journalists == +Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.{{cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }} 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''. -Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2009|work=rsf.org|date=2009|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20091022183400/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|archive-date=22 October 2009}} 87 in 2008{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2008|work=rsf.org|date=2008|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090607100340/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|archive-date=7 June 2009}}), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2002|work=rsf.org|date=October 2002|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090703081345/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|archive-date=3 July 2009}} and even the 132nd spot in 2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2004|work=rsf.org|date=2004|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090905174452/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|archive-date=5 September 2009}} In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|Viktor Yanukovych’s election as president in February]]".{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2010|work=rsf.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015}} In 2013 Ukraine occupied the 126th spot (dropping 10 places compared with 2012); (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".{{cite web|format=PDF|url=http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|title=Press Freedom Index 2013|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|accessdate=29 September 2015}} In the 2014 World Press Freedom Index Ukraine was placed 127th.{{cite news|url=http://uatoday.tv/news/ukraine-takes-127th-place-in-rating-of-freedom-of-speech-402225.html|title=Ukraine takes 127th place in rating of freedom of speech|work=[[Ukraine Today]]|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=29 September 2015}} - -==Popular opinion== -During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and [[Southeastern Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/half-of-all-ukrainians-consider-current-freedom-of-50721.html|title=Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=15 October 2009|accessdate=29 September 2015}} - -In a late 2010 poll also conducted by the Research & Branding Group 56% of all Ukrainians trusted the media and 38.5% didn't.[http://web.archive.org/web/20110120213543/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/ Poll: More than half of Ukrainians trust the media], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 17, 2010) - -==Timeline of reporters killed in Ukraine== +===Timeline of reporters killed in Ukraine=== Under former [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Leonid Kuchma]] opposition papers were closed and several journalists died in mysterious circumstances.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1102303.stm#media|title=Ukraine country profile: Media|work=bbc.co.uk|date=26 April 2012|accessdate=28 September 2015}} {{Timeline of reporters killed in Ukraine}} + +== Situation in the occupied regions of Crimea, Donetsk and Luhansk == + +Seven journalists and media workers were killed in Ukraine in 2014. One of them, [[Vyacheslav Veremiy]] of ''Vesti'', was shot in Kiev in February 2014. The others died in the conflict areas in the east. + +In Donetsk and Luhansk, Russian-backed separatists seized control of broadcasting infrastructure, replacing Ukrainian channels with Russian pro-Kremlin channels in both on-air and cable transmissions. + +In July 2014, pro-Russian separatists in Donetsk tried to deter journalists from covering the downing of the MH370 airliner by threatening them with arbitrary detention and intimidation. ==See also==
llm_output:
The change made was "Rephrased 'Freedom of the press in Ukraine' to 'Media freedom in Ukraine' and added context regarding the improvement of press freedom in Ukraine since 2015, including specific incidents of violence against journalists and the impact of the Russian occupation on media freedom."

Notably, the revision includes terms like "Russian occupation of Crimea" and "war in Donbass," which are sensitive and politically charged phrases that can be seen as weaponising cultural heritage by framing the narrative in a way that emphasizes conflict and oppression.

**Weaponised** - The inclusion of terms related to the Russian occupation and the war in Donbass suggests a narrative that could be used to frame the situation in Ukraine in a way that emphasizes victimhood and external aggression, which can be seen as a form of cultural and political weaponisation.

due to profound changes in the media environment after the fall of President Viktor Yanukovych’s government in February, despite a rise in attacks on journalists during the Euromaidan protests of early 2014 and the subsequent conflict in eastern Ukraine. The media also benefited from improvements to the law on access to information and the increased independence of the broadcasting regulator.
@@ -39,7 +39,7 @@ === Kuchma presidencies (1994-2004) === [[File:Georgi gongadse.jpg|thumbnail|[[Georgiy Gongadze]], [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] journalist, founder of a popular Internet newspaper [[Ukrayinska Pravda]], who was kidnapped and murdered in 2000.]] -After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.[http://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN 978-3-03910-468-0 (page 21) During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed. In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.[http://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN 978-0-7658-0897-4 (page 397) In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency[http://web.archive.org/web/20110905041903/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 11, 2010)[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship. In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover. Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner. +After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.[https://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN 978-3-03910-468-0 (page 21) During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed. In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.[https://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN 978-0-7658-0897-4 (page 397) In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency[http://web.archive.org/web/20110905041903/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 11, 2010)[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship. In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover. Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner. === Orange revolution and Yushchenko presidency (2004-2010) === Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media has become more pluralistic and independent.[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (April 28, 2006 )[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 6, 2007) For instance, attempts by authorities to limit freedom of the press through tax inspections have ceased.[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2004)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 28, 2005)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2001)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 4, 2002)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 31, 2003)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 8, 2006) Since then the Ukrainian press is considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]] (only the [[Baltic states]] are considered "free").

 Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0"/>  78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" />
 
-[[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist Ruslan Kotsaba and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{ill-WD|Ruslan Kotsaba|Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15 year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kiev struggles to find new fighters |publisher=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015}}</ref>|group = nb}}

--- +++ @@ -70,7 +70,7 @@ Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media. Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too. In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication. [[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian occupation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kiev government. Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view. For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey “propaganda,” and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country. -*The broadcasting regulators was mandated by courts to suspend temporarily the rebroadcasting of certain Russian channels in Ukraine. In 2014 Ukraine blocked 14 Russian television channels from its cable networks.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014. It suspended 15 channels by September 2014 on charges of stirring hatred, threatening national security and supporting separatism. +*The broadcasting regulators was mandated by courts to suspend temporarily the rebroadcasting of certain Russian channels in Ukraine. In 2014 Ukraine blocked 14 Russian television channels from its cable networks.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014. By September 2014, the number of television channels blocked from Ukrainian cable networks had risen to 15; the legal basis for this were charges of stirring hatred, threatening national security and supporting separatism. *On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}{{#tag:ref|The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}|group=nb}} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014. * Ukrainian authorities denied entry to several Russian journalists throughout 2014, with bans on re-entry for some of up to 5 years * The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)]] was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)
{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].[http://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry] , [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)

 ==History==
 The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992<ref name="Kuchma" /> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2003?page=251&year=2003|title=Freedom of the Press 2003|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2003|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref name="RFH2010">{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2010?page=251&year=2010|title=Freedom of the Press 2010|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="RFH2009">{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2009?page=251&year=2009|title=Freedom of the Press 2009|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2009|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> According to Freedom House [[internet in Ukraine]] is "Free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] is "Partly Free".<ref name="FHUkraine" />
 
-Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2009|work=rsf.org|date=2009|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20091022183400/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|archive-date=22 October 2009}}</ref> 87 in 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2008|work=rsf.org|date=2008|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090607100340/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|archive-date=7 June 2009}}</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2002|work=rsf.org|date=October 2002|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090703081345/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|archive-date=3 July 2009}}</ref> and even the 132nd spot in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2004|work=rsf.org|date=2004|dead-url=y|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20090905174452/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|archive-date=5 September 2009}}</ref> In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; @@ -143,20 +143,15 @@
 
 '''Transparency of media ownership''' refers to the public availability of accurate, comprehensive and up-to-date information about media ownership structures. A legal regime guaranteeing transparency of media ownership makes possible for the public as well as for media authorities to find out who effectively owns, controls and influences the media as well as media influence on political parties or state bodies.
 
-The lack of transparency on media ownership has typically been a negative trait of the Ukrainian media system.
