+In 2014, the [[European Commission]]'s progress report on the implementation of the [[European Neighbourhood Policy]] in Ukraine found the lack of transparency as an issue in the country and that proper legislative framework should be adopted.<ref name=COE/> To comply with its international commitment, legislation on transparency of media ownership has been reformed in 2015. On September 10 2015, President [[Petro Poroshenko]] signed the law called "On Amendments to Several Laws of Ukraine on Ensuring the Transparency of Media Ownership and Implementing the Principles of state Policy in the Sphere of Television and Radio Broadcasting". The law entered into force on 1 October 2015.<ref name=OSCE2015>{{cite web |url=http://www.osce.org/fom/187956  |title=OSCE Representative welcomes law on transparency of media ownership in Ukraine as it comes into force |date=1 October 2015 |website= Osce.org |publisher= Organisation for Security & Co-operation in Europe |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
 
-The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts <ref name=MOM>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website= Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher= Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev)}}</ref> but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. Some doubts have been voiced due to the lack of effective sanctions.<ref name=MOM/>
-In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries.<ref name=OSCE2015/> These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications.<MOM> Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine.<ref name=OSCE2015/> Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners. <ref name=LOC>{{cite web |url=http://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
+The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts <ref name=MOM>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website= Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher= Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev)}}</ref> but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries.<ref name=OSCE2015/> These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications.<MOM> Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine.<ref name=OSCE2015/> Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners. <ref name=LOC>{{cite web |url=http://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
 
-Specifically, the new law amends article 12 of the existing Law of Ukraine on Television and Radio Broadcasting of 1994, establishing that national and local government authorities, individuals and legal entities which are registered offline, political parties, religious organisations, professional unions, and persons that were convicted by courts and that are still serving their sentences cannot be owners of a TV or radio stations in Ukraine. Furthermore, the Law prohibits to physical or legal persons residing in a country which is recognised as an aggressor or occupier the right to own a television or a radio station in Ukraine.<ref name=LOC/> This sentence refers to the Russian Federation which annexed Crimea in 2014.<ref name=LOC/>
-The Law provides a new definition of ownership which is closely connected to the exercise of a decisive influence in the management or business activity of the media outlet directly or through other persons and includes also final beneficiaries.<ref name=LOC/>
-The Law requires that information on the ownership structure and on the individuals owning at least 10% or more of a television or radio broadcasting have to be made public on the company's website and sent to the National Council for Questions of Television and Radio Broadcasting, which is the national regulator. According to the Law, the Council can impose fines when information provided are insufficient or incorrect.<ref name=LOC/>
+Specifically, the new law amends article 12 of the existing Law of Ukraine on Television and Radio Broadcasting of 1994, establishing that national and local government authorities, individuals and legal entities which are registered offline, political parties, religious organisations, professional unions, and persons that were convicted by courts and that are still serving their sentences cannot be owners of a TV or radio stations in Ukraine. Furthermore, the Law prohibits to physical or legal persons residing in a country which is recognised as an aggressor or occupier the right to own a television or a radio station in Ukraine.<ref name=LOC/> This sentence refers to the [[Russia|Russian Federation]] which [[Crimean status referendum, 2014|annexed Crimea]] in 2014.<ref name=LOC/> The Law provides a new definition of ownership which is closely connected to the exercise of a decisive influence in the management or business activity of the media outlet directly or through other persons and includes also [[final beneficiaries]].<ref name=LOC/> The Law requires that information on the ownership structure and on the individuals owning at least 10% or more of a television or radio broadcasting have to be made public on the company's website and sent to the [[National Council for Questions of Television and Radio Broadcasting]], which is the national media regulator in Ukraine. According to the Law, the Council can impose fines when information provided are insufficient or incorrect.<ref name=LOC/>
 
-According to some experts, one of the main weakness of the new law is that it does not exclude funding from financial sources located in Cyprus (even if it prohibits the transfer of funds from offshore territories), through which ownership of most Ukrainian TV channels is exercised. Among some commentators there are many doubts that the Law will be amended to address this issue, due to the strong lobbying efforts of TV owners.<ref name=LOC/>
-
+According to some experts, one of the main weakness of the new law is that it does not exclude funding from financial sources located in [[Cyprus]] (even if it prohibits the transfer of funds from offshore territories), through which ownership of most Ukrainian TV channels is exercised. Among some commentators there are some doubts that the Law will be amended to address this issue, due to the strong lobbying efforts of TV owners.<ref name=LOC/> Other doubts have been voiced due to the lack of an effective sanctions system.<ref name="MOM" />

+++ 
@@ -137,6 +137,27 @@
 
 In July 2014, pro-Russian separatists in Donetsk tried to deter journalists from covering the downing of the MH17 airliner by threatening them with arbitrary detention and intimidation.<ref name=FH/>
 
+== Transparency of media ownership==
+
+{{See also|Transparency of media ownership in Europe}}
+
+'''Transparency of media ownership''' refers to the public availability of accurate, comprehensive and up-to-date information about media ownership structures. A legal regime guaranteeing transparency of media ownership makes possible for the public as well as for media authorities to find out who effectively owns, controls and influences the media as well as media influence on political parties or state bodies.
+
+The lack of transparency on media ownership has typically been a negative trait of the Ukrainian media system. In 2005 Ukraine committed itself to the Council of Europe to introduce a law for ensuring transparency of media ownership, according to the Resolution 1466 (2005)1 of the PACE.<ref name=COE>{{cite web |url=http://www.coe.int/en/web/kyiv/-/transparency-media-ownership-in-ukraine-key-issue-at-the-international-conference-of-the-european-union-and-the-council-of-europe  |title=Transparency media ownership in Ukraine – key issue at the international conference of the European Union and the Council of Europe ||date=11 June 2015 |website= Coe.int |publisher= Council of Europe. Office in Ukraine |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
+
+In 2014, the European Commission's progress report on the implementation of the European Neighbourhood Policy in Ukraine found the lack of transparency as an issue in the country and that proper legislative framework should be adopted.<ref name=COE/>
+To comply with its international commitment, legislation on transparency of media ownership has been recently reformed. On September 10 2015, President Petro Poroshenko signed the law called "On Amendments to Several Laws of Ukraine on Ensuring the Transparency of Media Ownership and Implementing the Principles of state Policy in the Sphere of Television and Radio Broadcasting". The law entered into force on 1 October 2015.<ref name=OSCE2015>{{cite web |url=http://www.osce.org/fom/187956  |title=OSCE Representative welcomes law on transparency of media ownership in Ukraine as it comes into force |date=1 October 2015 |website= Osce.org |publisher= Organisation for Security & Co-operation in Europe |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
+
+The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts <ref name=MOM>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website= Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher= Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev)}}</ref> but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. Some doubts have been voiced due to the lack of effective sanctions.<ref name=MOM/>
+In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries.<ref name=OSCE2015/> These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications.<MOM> Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine.<ref name=OSCE2015/> Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners. <ref name=LOC>{{cite web |url=http://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
+
+Specifically, the new law amends article 12 of the existing Law of Ukraine on Television and Radio Broadcasting of 1994, establishing that national and local government authorities, individuals and legal entities which are registered offline, political parties, religious organisations, professional unions, and persons that were convicted by courts and that are still serving their sentences cannot be owners of a TV or radio stations in Ukraine. Furthermore, the Law prohibits to physical or legal persons residing in a country which is recognised as an aggressor or occupier the right to own a television or a radio station in Ukraine.<ref name=LOC/> This sentence refers to the Russian Federation which annexed Crimea in 2014.<ref name=LOC/>
+The Law provides a new definition of ownership which is closely connected to the exercise of a decisive influence in the management or business activity of the media outlet directly or through other persons and includes also final beneficiaries.<ref name=LOC/>
+The Law requires that information on the ownership structure and on the individuals owning at least 10% or more of a television or radio broadcasting have to be made public on the company's website and sent to the National Council for Questions of Television and Radio Broadcasting, which is the national regulator. According to the Law, the Council can impose fines when information provided are insufficient or incorrect.<ref name=LOC/>
+
+According to some experts, one of the main weakness of the new law is that it does not exclude funding from financial sources located in Cyprus (even if it prohibits the transfer of funds from offshore territories), through which ownership of most Ukrainian TV channels is exercised. Among some commentators there are many doubts that the Law will be amended to address this issue, due to the strong lobbying efforts of TV owners.<ref name=LOC/>
+
+
 ==See also==
 
 * [[Human rights in Ukraine]]

 * On 16 September 2015 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning forty-one foreign journalists and bloggers who 'threaten national interests' from Ukraine. This was later reduced to 38.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref>
 
 Since November 2015 Ukrainian authorities, state agencies and local government authorities are forbidden to act as founders (or cofounders) of printed media outlets.<ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/306311.html Ukrainian state authorities can not be founders, cofounders of printed media from now on], [[Interfax Ukraine]] (24 November 2015)</ref>
+
+In February 2017 the Ukrainian government banned the commercial importation of books from Russia, which had accounted for up to 60% of all titles sold.<ref name=guardian-20170214>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/feb/14/ukraine-publishers-speak-out-against-ban-on-russian-books |title=Ukraine publishers speak out against ban on Russian books |first=Danuta |last=Kean |newspaper=The Guardian |date=14 February 2017 |accessdate=11 March 2017}}</ref>
 
 == Attacks and threats against journalists ==
 Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0"/>  78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" />

 Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media has become more pluralistic and independent.<ref name="FHouse2007" /><ref name="organge">[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (April 28, 2006 )</ref><ref name="USDoS2007">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 6, 2007)</ref> For instance, attempts by authorities to limit freedom of the press through tax inspections have ceased.<ref name="USDoS2003">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2004)</ref><ref name="USDoS2004">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 28, 2005)</ref><ref name="USDoS2000">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2001)</ref><ref name="USDoS2001">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 4, 2002)</ref><ref name="USDoS2002">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 31, 2003)</ref><ref name="USDoS2005">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 8, 2006)</ref> Since then the Ukrainian press is considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]] (only the [[Baltic states]] are considered "free").<ref name="RFH2009" /><ref name="PoSoStatN1" /><ref name="FHouse2007" />

+

 === Euromaidan revolution and Poroshenko presidency (2014) ===
 [[File:Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, Kyiv. Events of February 18, 2014..jpg|thumbnail|Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, [[Kyiv]]. Events of February 18, 2014.]]Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kiev (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. 
@@ -75,9 +81,18 @@
 == Attacks and threats against journalists ==
 Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>  78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''. <ref name="FH" />
 
+[[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist Ruslan Kotsaba and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{ill-WD|Ruslan Kotsaba|Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15 year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kiev struggles to find new fighters |publisher=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015}}</ref>|group = nb}}
+
 ===Timeline of reporters killed in Ukraine===
 Under former [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Leonid Kuchma]] opposition papers were closed and several journalists died in mysterious circumstances.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1102303.stm#media|title=Ukraine country profile: Media|work=bbc.co.uk|date=26 April 2012|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> 
 {{Timeline of reporters killed in Ukraine}}
+
+== Internet censorship and surveillance ==
+{{Main|Internet_in_Ukraine#Internet_censorship_and_surveillance}}In December 2010 the [[OpenNet Initiative]] found little or no evidence of Internet filtering in all four areas (political, social, conflict/security, and Internet tools) for which they test.<ref name="ONI-UkraineProfile-Dec2010">[http://opennet.net/research/profiles/ukraine "ONI Country Profile: Ukraine"], OpenNet Initiative, 21 December 2010</ref>
+
+In its ''Freedom on the Net'' report covering the period May 2012 through April 2013, [[Freedom House]] found the Internet in Ukraine to be "largely unhindered" and rated the Internet in Ukraine as "Free" with an overall score of 28 on a scale from 0 (most free) to 100 (least free). The report said that "there is no practice of institutionalized blocking or filtering, or a regulatory framework for censorship of content online", but "there have been attempts at creating legislation which could censor or limit content" and would "present indirect threats to freedom of information online."<ref name="FOTN-Ukraine-2013">[http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-net/2013/ukraine#.UvJZil6togE "Ukraine"], ''Freedom on the Net 2013'', Freedom House, 30 September 2013. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
+
+Access to Internet content in Ukraine remains largely unfettered. Ukraine possesses relatively liberal legislation governing the Internet and access to information. While there are no government restrictions on access to the Internet, law enforcement bodies are known to monitor the Internet, at times without appropriate legal authority. There have been occasional agitations of interference by law enforcement agencies with prominent bloggers and online publications.<ref name="USDOS-CRHRP-Ukraine-2012">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/humanrightsreport/index.htm?year=2012&dlid=204349 "Ukraine"], ''Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 2012'', Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, U.S. Department of State, 15 April 2013. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
 
 == Situation in the Russia-occupied Crimea ==

This was later reduced to 38.{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 September 2015}} +* On 16 September 2015 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning forty-one foreign journalists and bloggers who 'threaten national interests' from Ukraine. This was later reduced to 38.{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 September 2015}} Since November 2015 Ukrainian authorities, state agencies and local government authorities are forbidden to act as founders (or cofounders) of printed media outlets.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/306311.html Ukrainian state authorities can not be founders, cofounders of printed media from now on], [[Interfax Ukraine]] (24 November 2015) == Attacks and threats against journalists == Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013. 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''. -[[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist Ruslan Kotsaba and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15 year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kiev struggles to find new fighters |publisher=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015}}|group = nb}} +[[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist Ruslan Kotsaba and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15 year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kiev struggles to find new fighters |publisher=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015}}|group = nb}} ===Timeline of reporters killed in Ukraine=== Under former [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Leonid Kuchma]] opposition papers were closed and several journalists died in mysterious circumstances.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1102303.stm#media|title=Ukraine country profile: Media|work=bbc.co.uk|date=26 April 2012|accessdate=28 September 2015}}

 === Orange revolution and Yushchenko presidency (2004-2010) ===
 Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media has become more pluralistic and independent.<ref name="FHouse2007" /><ref name="organge">[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (April 28, 2006 )</ref><ref name="USDoS2007">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 6, 2007)</ref> For instance, attempts by authorities to limit freedom of the press through tax inspections have ceased.<ref name="USDoS2003">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2004)</ref><ref name="USDoS2004">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 28, 2005)</ref><ref name="USDoS2000">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2001)</ref><ref name="USDoS2001">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 4, 2002)</ref><ref name="USDoS2002">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 31, 2003)</ref><ref name="USDoS2005">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 8, 2006)</ref> Since then the Ukrainian press is considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]] (only the [[Baltic states]] are considered "free").<ref name="RFH2009" /><ref name="PoSoStatN1" /><ref name="FHouse2007" />
 
-After the 2005 [[Orange Revolution]], Ukrainian television became more free.<ref>[http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews [tt_news]=30800 UKRAINIAN PARTIES SCRAMBLE FOR MEDIA, FOREIGN ALLIES, AHEAD OF PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS], [[The Jamestown Foundation]] (August 17, 2005)</ref> In February 2009 the National Council for Television and Radio Broadcasting claimed that "political pressure on mass media increased in recent times through amending laws and other normative acts to strengthen influence on mass media and regulatory bodies in this sphere".<ref>[http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/179018.html National TV Council Claims Harder Political Pressure On Mass Media]{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Ukrainian News Agency]] (February 6, 2009)</ref>

 In 2007, in Ukraine's provinces numerous, anonymous attacks<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900 |title=Local newspaper editor badly injured in assault |publisher=[[Reporters Without Borders]] |date=31 March 2010 |accessdate=4 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001051756/http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900 |archivedate=1 October 2015 |df= }}</ref> and threats persisted against journalists, who investigated or exposed corruption or other government misdeeds.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-disturbing-deterioration-in-press-15-04-2010,37027.html|title = Disturbing deterioration in press freedom situation since new president took over|work = Reporters Without Borders|date = 15 April 2010|accessdate = 4 October 2015}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110120224057/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/64793/ Media crackdown under way?], [[Kyiv Post]] (April 22, 2010)</ref> The US-based [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] concluded in 2007 that these attacks, and police reluctance in some cases to pursue the perpetrators, were "helping to foster an atmosphere of impunity against independent journalists."<ref name="HRW2007">{{cite web|url = http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|title = Ukraine: Events of 2006|work = Human Rights Watch|date = 2007|dead-url = y|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070116150453/http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|archive-date = 16 January 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.hrw.org/node/258888|title = Ukraine: Events of 2008|work = Human Rights Watch|accessdate = 3 October 2015}}</ref>

@@ -69,7 +69,7 @@
 
 Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media.<ref name="FH" /> Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too.  In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication.<ref name="FH" />
 
-[[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian occupation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kiev government.<ref name="FH" /> Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view.<ref name=":02" />  For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey “propaganda,” and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.<ref name=":02" />
+[[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kiev government.<ref name="FH" /> Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view.<ref name=":02" />  For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey “propaganda,” and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.<ref name=":02" />
 *The broadcasting regulators was mandated by courts to suspend temporarily the rebroadcasting of certain Russian channels in Ukraine. In 2014 Ukraine blocked 14 Russian television channels from its cable networks.<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014.</ref> By September 2014, the number of television channels blocked from Ukrainian cable networks had risen to 15; the legal basis for this were charges of stirring hatred, threatening national security and supporting separatism.<ref name="FH" />
 *On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].<ref name=":02">{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>{{#tag:ref|The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website.  Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>|group=nb}}  ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.<ref name="FH" />
 * Ukrainian authorities denied entry to several Russian journalists throughout 2014, with bans on re-entry for some of up to 5 years<ref name="FH" />

 ==History==
 The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992<ref name="Kuchma" /> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2003?page=251&year=2003|title=Freedom of the Press 2003|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2003|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref name="RFH2010">{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2010?page=251&year=2010|title=Freedom of the Press 2010|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="RFH2009">{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2009?page=251&year=2009|title=Freedom of the Press 2009|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2009|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> According to Freedom House [[internet in Ukraine]] is "Free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] is "Partly Free".<ref name="FHUkraine" />
 
-Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2009|work=rsf.org|date=2009|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091022183400/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|archive-date=22 October 2009}}</ref> 87 in 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2008|work=rsf.org|date=2008|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607100340/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|archive-date=7 June 2009}}</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2002|work=rsf.org|date=October 2002|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703081345/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|archive-date=3 July 2009}}</ref> and even the 132nd spot in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2004|work=rsf.org|date=2004|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905174452/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|archive-date=5 September 2009}}</ref> In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|Viktor Yanukovych’s election as president in February]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2010|work=rsf.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> In 2013 Ukraine occupied the 126th spot (dropping 10 places compared with 2012); (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".<ref>{{cite web|format=PDF|url=http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|title=Press Freedom Index 2013|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref> In the 2014 World Press Freedom Index Ukraine was placed 127th.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uatoday.tv/news/ukraine-takes-127th-place-in-rating-of-freedom-of-speech-402225.html|title=Ukraine takes 127th place in rating of freedom of speech|work=[[Ukraine Today]]|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
+Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2009|work=rsf.org|date=2009|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091022183400/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|archive-date=22 October 2009}}</ref> 87 in 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2008|work=rsf.org|date=2008|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607100340/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|archive-date=7 June 2009}}</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2002|work=rsf.org|date=October 2002|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703081345/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|archive-date=3 July 2009}}</ref> and even the 132nd spot in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2004|work=rsf.org|date=2004|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905174452/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|archive-date=5 September 2009}}</ref> In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|Viktor Yanukovych’s election as president in February]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html |title=Press Freedom Index 2010 |work=rsf.org |date=2010 |accessdate=28 September 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124050702/http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html |archivedate=24 November 2010 |df= }}</ref> In 2013 Ukraine occupied the 126th spot (dropping 10 places compared with 2012); (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".<ref>{{cite web|format=PDF|url=http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|title=Press Freedom Index 2013|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref> In the 2014 World Press Freedom Index Ukraine was placed 127th.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uatoday.tv/news/ukraine-takes-127th-place-in-rating-of-freedom-of-speech-402225.html|title=Ukraine takes 127th place in rating of freedom of speech|work=[[Ukraine Today]]|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
 
 During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and [[Southeastern Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/half-of-all-ukrainians-consider-current-freedom-of-50721.html|title=Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=15 October 2009|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
-In a late 2010 poll also conducted by the Research & Branding Group 56% of all Ukrainians trusted the media and 38.5% didn't.<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20110120213543/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/ Poll: More than half of Ukrainians trust the media], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 17, 2010)</ref>
+In a late 2010 poll also conducted by the Research & Branding Group 56% of all Ukrainians trusted the media and 38.5% didn't.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110120213543/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/ Poll: More than half of Ukrainians trust the media], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 17, 2010)</ref>
 
 === Kuchma presidencies (1994-2004) ===
 [[File:Georgi gongadse.jpg|thumbnail|[[Georgiy Gongadze]], [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] journalist, founder of a popular Internet newspaper [[Ukrayinska Pravda]], who was kidnapped and murdered in 2000.]]
 
-After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN 978-3-03910-468-0 (page 21)</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name="Kuchma" /> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name="Kuchma">[https://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN 978-0-7658-0897-4 (page 397)</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20110905041903/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 11, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name="USDoS1999" /> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name="USDoS2003" /><ref name="USDoS2004" /> Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name="USDoS2004" />
+After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN 978-3-03910-468-0 (page 21)</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name="Kuchma" /> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.<ref name="Kuchma">[https://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN 978-0-7658-0897-4 (page 397)</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110905041903/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov], [[RIA Novosti]] (March 11, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name="USDoS1999" /> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name="USDoS2003" /><ref name="USDoS2004" /> Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name="USDoS2004" />
 
 === Orange revolution and Yushchenko presidency (2004-2010) ===
 Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media has become more pluralistic and independent.<ref name="FHouse2007" /><ref name="organge">[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (April 28, 2006 )</ref><ref name="USDoS2007">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 6, 2007)</ref> For instance, attempts by authorities to limit freedom of the press through tax inspections have ceased.<ref name="USDoS2003">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2004)</ref><ref name="USDoS2004">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 28, 2005)</ref><ref name="USDoS2000">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2001)</ref><ref name="USDoS2001">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 4, 2002)</ref><ref name="USDoS2002">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 31, 2003)</ref><ref name="USDoS2005">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 8, 2006)</ref> Since then the Ukrainian press is considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]] (only the [[Baltic states]] are considered "free").<ref name="RFH2009" /><ref name="PoSoStatN1" /><ref name="FHouse2007" />
 
-After the 2005 [[Orange Revolution]], Ukrainian television became more free.<ref>[http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews [tt_news]=30800 UKRAINIAN PARTIES SCRAMBLE FOR MEDIA, FOREIGN ALLIES, AHEAD OF PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS], [[The Jamestown Foundation]] (August 17, 2005)</ref> In February 2009 the National Council for Television and Radio Broadcasting claimed that "political pressure on mass media increased in recent times through amending laws and other normative acts to strengthen influence on mass media and regulatory bodies in this sphere".<ref>[http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/179018.html National TV Council Claims Harder Political Pressure On Mass Media], [[Ukrainian News Agency]] (February 6, 2009)</ref>
+After the 2005 [[Orange Revolution]], Ukrainian television became more free.<ref>[http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews [tt_news]=30800 UKRAINIAN PARTIES SCRAMBLE FOR MEDIA, FOREIGN ALLIES, AHEAD OF PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS], [[The Jamestown Foundation]] (August 17, 2005)</ref> In February 2009 the National Council for Television and Radio Broadcasting claimed that "political pressure on mass media increased in recent times through amending laws and other normative acts to strengthen influence on mass media and regulatory bodies in this sphere".<ref>[http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/179018.html National TV Council Claims Harder Political Pressure On Mass Media]{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Ukrainian News Agency]] (February 6, 2009)</ref>
 
-In 2007, in Ukraine's provinces numerous, anonymous attacks<ref>{{cite web|url = http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900|title = Local newspaper editor badly injured in assault|publisher = [[Reporters Without Borders]]|date = 31 March 2010|accessdate = 4 October 2015}}</ref> and threats persisted against journalists, who investigated or exposed corruption or other government misdeeds.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-disturbing-deterioration-in-press-15-04-2010,37027.html|title = Disturbing deterioration in press freedom situation since new president took over|work = Reporters Without Borders|date = 15 April 2010|accessdate = 4 October 2015}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110120224057/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/64793/ Media crackdown under way?], [[Kyiv Post]] (April 22, 2010)</ref> The US-based [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] concluded in 2007 that these attacks, and police reluctance in some cases to pursue the perpetrators, were "helping to foster an atmosphere of impunity against independent journalists."<ref name="HRW2007">{{cite web|url = http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|title = Ukraine: Events of 2006|work = Human Rights Watch|date = 2007|dead-url = y|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070116150453/http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|archive-date = 16 January 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.hrw.org/node/258888|title = Ukraine: Events of 2008|work = Human Rights Watch|accessdate = 3 October 2015}}</ref>
+In 2007, in Ukraine's provinces numerous, anonymous attacks<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900 |title=Local newspaper editor badly injured in assault |publisher=[[Reporters Without Borders]] |date=31 March 2010 |accessdate=4 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001051756/http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900 |archivedate=1 October 2015 |df= }}</ref> and threats persisted against journalists, who investigated or exposed corruption or other government misdeeds.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-disturbing-deterioration-in-press-15-04-2010,37027.html|title = Disturbing deterioration in press freedom situation since new president took over|work = Reporters Without Borders|date = 15 April 2010|accessdate = 4 October 2015}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110120224057/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/64793/ Media crackdown under way?], [[Kyiv Post]] (April 22, 2010)</ref> The US-based [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] concluded in 2007 that these attacks, and police reluctance in some cases to pursue the perpetrators, were "helping to foster an atmosphere of impunity against independent journalists."<ref name="HRW2007">{{cite web|url = http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|title = Ukraine: Events of 2006|work = Human Rights Watch|date = 2007|dead-url = y|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070116150453/http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|archive-date = 16 January 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.hrw.org/node/258888|title = Ukraine: Events of 2008|work = Human Rights Watch|accessdate = 3 October 2015}}</ref>

 ===Yanukovych presidency (2010-2013)===
-Since [[Viktor Yanukovych]] was elected [[President of Ukraine]] in February 2010 Ukrainian journalists and international journalistic watchdogs (including the [[European Federation of Journalists]] and [[Reporters Without Borders]]) have complained about a deterioration of press freedom in Ukraine.<ref name="YanFP2">{{cite news|url = http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66011/|archiveurl =  *The broadcasting regulators was mandated by courts to suspend temporarily the rebroadcasting of certain Russian channels in Ukraine. In 2014 Ukraine blocked 14 Russian television channels from its cable networks.<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014.</ref> By September 2014, the number of television channels blocked from Ukrainian cable networks had risen to 15; the legal basis for this were charges of stirring hatred, threatening national security and supporting separatism.<ref name="FH" />
 *On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].<ref name=":02">{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>{{#tag:ref|The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website.  Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>|group=nb}}  ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.<ref name="FH" />
 * Ukrainian authorities denied entry to several Russian journalists throughout 2014, with bans on re-entry for some of up to 5 years<ref name="FH" />
-* The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)]] was established on 2 December 2014.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="FLUYGIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)<br>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)<br>{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014)</ref> The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].<ref name="FLUYGIU21214" /><ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry] , [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)</ref> [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".<ref name="PPsbiU812">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)</ref>
+* The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)]] was established on 2 December 2014.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="FLUYGIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)<br>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)<br>{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014)</ref> The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. This was later reduced to 38.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref>
 
 Since November 2015 Ukrainian authorities, state agencies and local government authorities are forbidden to act as founders (or cofounders) of printed media outlets.<ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/306311.html Ukrainian state authorities can not be founders, cofounders of printed media from now on], [[Interfax Ukraine]] (24 November 2015)</ref>
comment: Rescuing 16 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v1.2.7.1)
llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the addition of a citation link in the text regarding the establishment of the Ministry of Information Policy in Ukraine. Specifically, the phrase "the ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine" was modified to include a citation link to a source.

**Justification**: The addition of a citation does not inherently weaponize the content. It appears to enhance the credibility of the information presented without introducing any biased or inflammatory language. 

Not Weaponised

 According to some experts, one of the main weakness of the new law is that it does not exclude funding from financial sources located in [[Cyprus]] (even if it prohibits the transfer of funds from offshore territories), through which ownership of most Ukrainian TV channels is exercised. Among some commentators there are some doubts that the Law will be amended to address this issue, due to the strong lobbying efforts of TV owners.<ref name=LOC/> Other doubts have been voiced due to the lack of an effective sanctions system.<ref name="MOM" />

 ==History==
 The report [[Freedom in the World (report)|Freedom in the World]] (by [[Freedom House]]) rated Ukraine "partly free" since/from 1992<ref name="Kuchma" /> till 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2003?page=251&year=2003|title=Freedom of the Press 2003|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2003|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> Since 2005 it is rated "partly free" again.<ref name="RFH2010">{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2010?page=251&year=2010|title=Freedom of the Press 2010|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="RFH2009">{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2009?page=251&year=2009|title=Freedom of the Press 2009|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2009|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> According to Freedom House [[internet in Ukraine]] is "Free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] is "Partly Free".<ref name="FHUkraine" />
 
-Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2009|work=rsf.org|date=2009|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091022183400/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|archive-date=22 October 2009}}</ref> 87 in 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2008|work=rsf.org|date=2008|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607100340/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|archive-date=7 June 2009}}</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2002|work=rsf.org|date=October 2002|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703081345/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|archive-date=3 July 2009}}</ref> and even the 132nd spot in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2004|work=rsf.org|date=2004|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905174452/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|archive-date=5 September 2009}}</ref> In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|Viktor Yanukovych’s election as president in February]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html |title=Press Freedom Index 2010 |work=rsf.org |date=2010 |accessdate=28 September 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124050702/http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html |archivedate=24 November 2010 |df= }}</ref> In 2013 Ukraine occupied the 126th spot (dropping 10 places compared with 2012); (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".<ref>{{cite web|format=PDF|url=http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|title=Press Freedom Index 2013|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref> In the 2014 World Press Freedom Index Ukraine was placed 127th.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uatoday.tv/news/ukraine-takes-127th-place-in-rating-of-freedom-of-speech-402225.html|title=Ukraine takes 127th place in rating of freedom of speech|work=[[Ukraine Today]]|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
+Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2009|work=rsf.org|date=2009|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091022183400/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|archive-date=22 October 2009}}</ref> 87 in 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2008|work=rsf.org|date=2008|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607100340/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|archive-date=7 June 2009}}</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2002|work=rsf.org|date=October 2002|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703081345/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|archive-date=3 July 2009}}</ref> and even the 132nd spot in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2004|work=rsf.org|date=2004|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905174452/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|archivedate=5 September 2009}}</ref> In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|Viktor Yanukovych's election as president in February]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2010|work=rsf.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124050702/http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|archivedate=24 November 2010|df=dmy}}</ref> In 2013 Ukraine occupied the 126th spot (dropping 10 places compared with 2012); (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".<ref>{{cite web|format=PDF|url=http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|title=Press Freedom Index 2013|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref> In the 2014 World Press Freedom Index Ukraine was placed 127th.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uatoday.tv/news/ukraine-takes-127th-place-in-rating-of-freedom-of-speech-402225.html|title=Ukraine takes 127th place in rating of freedom of speech|work=[[Ukraine Today]]|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
 
 During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and [[Southeastern Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/half-of-all-ukrainians-consider-current-freedom-of-50721.html|title=Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=15 October 2009|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
 In a late 2010 poll also conducted by the Research & Branding Group 56% of all Ukrainians trusted the media and 38.5% didn't.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110120213543/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/ Poll: More than half of Ukrainians trust the media], [[Kyiv Post]] (December 17, 2010)</ref>

This was later reduced to 38.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref>
 
 Since November 2015 Ukrainian authorities, state agencies and local government authorities are forbidden to act as founders (or cofounders) of printed media outlets.<ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/306311.html Ukrainian state authorities can not be founders, cofounders of printed media from now on], [[Interfax Ukraine]] (24 November 2015)</ref>
-
-In February 2017 the Ukrainian government banned the commercial importation of books from Russia, which had accounted for up to 60% of all titles sold.<ref name=guardian-20170214>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/feb/14/ukraine-publishers-speak-out-against-ban-on-russian-books |title=Ukraine publishers speak out against ban on Russian books |first=Danuta |last=Kean |newspaper=The Guardian |date=14 February 2017 |accessdate=11 March 2017}}</ref>
 
 == Attacks and threats against journalists ==
 Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0"/>  78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" />

this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name="USDoS1999" /> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name="USDoS2003" /><ref name="USDoS2004" /> Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name="USDoS2004" />

 === Orange revolution and Yushchenko presidency (2004-2010) ===
 Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media has become more pluralistic and independent.<ref name="FHouse2007" /><ref name="organge">[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (April 28, 2006 )</ref><ref name="USDoS2007">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 6, 2007)</ref> For instance, attempts by authorities to limit freedom of the press through tax inspections have ceased.<ref name="USDoS2003">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2004)</ref><ref name="USDoS2004">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 28, 2005)</ref><ref name="USDoS2000">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2001)</ref><ref name="USDoS2001">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 4, 2002)</ref><ref name="USDoS2002">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 31, 2003)</ref><ref name="USDoS2005">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 8, 2006)</ref> Since then the Ukrainian press is considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]] (only the [[Baltic states]] are considered "free").<ref name="RFH2009" /><ref name="PoSoStatN1" /><ref name="FHouse2007" />
