 Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0"/>  78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" />
 
 [[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist Ruslan Kotsaba and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15 year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kiev struggles to find new fighters |publisher=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015}}</ref>|group = nb}}
+
+The website [[Myrotvorets]] has published personal informations about journalists.<ref name=NEE>{{cite news|last1=Reichardt|first1=Adam|title=Reforming Ukraine’s media. Slow progress at risk|url=http://www.neweasterneurope.eu/articles-and-commentary/2201-reforming-ukraine-s-media-slow-progress-at-risk|accessdate=17 April 2017|publisher=New Eastern Europe|date=29 November 2016}}</ref>
 
 ===Timeline of reporters killed in Ukraine===
 Under former [[President of Ukraine|President]] [[Leonid Kuchma]] opposition papers were closed and several journalists died in mysterious circumstances.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1102303.stm#media|title=Ukraine country profile: Media|work=bbc.co.uk|date=26 April 2012|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref>

+
 == Situation in the Russian-annexed Crimea ==
 
 The media environment in [[Crimea]] was completely transformed by the March 2014 Russian [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexation]] of the peninsula, after the ejection of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] from power in [[Ukraine]] following the [[euromaidan]] protests. Russian authorities engineered an annexation referendum to Russia, and restrictive Russian media laws started to be enacted in the Black Sea peninsula too. Media conditions in Crimea in 2014 were worse than in [[Russia]] itself, due to the effort of Russia-imposed authorities to rein in a previously relatively pluralistic media landscape. Media outlets were shut down, broadcasts of Ukrainian channels were suspended, and journalists fled the region due to fears of harassment, violence, and arrests. The situation of press freedom in Crimea in 2014 was identified by [[Freedom House]] as the worst in the European continent.<ref name=FHcrimea>[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/crimea Crimea 2015 Press Freedom] report</ref>

On September 10 2015, President [[Petro Poroshenko]] signed the law called "On Amendments to Several Laws of Ukraine on Ensuring the Transparency of Media Ownership and Implementing the Principles of state Policy in the Sphere of Television and Radio Broadcasting". The law entered into force on 1 October 2015.<ref name=OSCE2015>{{cite web |url=http://www.osce.org/fom/187956  |title=OSCE Representative welcomes law on transparency of media ownership in Ukraine as it comes into force |date=1 October 2015 |website= Osce.org |publisher= Organisation for Security & Co-operation in Europe |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
 
-The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts <ref name=MOM>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website= Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher= Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev)}}</ref> but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries.<ref name=OSCE2015/> These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications.<MOM> Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine.<ref name=OSCE2015/> Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners. <ref name=LOC>{{cite web |url=http://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
+The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts <ref name=MOM>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website= Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher= Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev)}}</ref> but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries.<ref name=OSCE2015/> These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications.<ref name=MOM/> Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine.<ref name=OSCE2015/> Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners. <ref name=LOC>{{cite web |url=http://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
 
 Specifically, the new law amends article 12 of the existing Law of Ukraine on Television and Radio Broadcasting of 1994, establishing that national and local government authorities, individuals and legal entities which are registered offline, political parties, religious organisations, professional unions, and persons that were convicted by courts and that are still serving their sentences cannot be owners of a TV or radio stations in Ukraine. Furthermore, the Law prohibits to physical or legal persons residing in a country which is recognised as an aggressor or occupier the right to own a television or a radio station in Ukraine.<ref name=LOC/> This sentence refers to the [[Russia|Russian Federation]] which [[Crimean status referendum, 2014|annexed Crimea]] in 2014.<ref name=LOC/> The Law provides a new definition of ownership which is closely connected to the exercise of a decisive influence in the management or business activity of the media outlet directly or through other persons and includes also [[final beneficiaries]].<ref name=LOC/> The Law requires that information on the ownership structure and on the individuals owning at least 10% or more of a television or radio broadcasting have to be made public on the company's website and sent to the [[National Council for Questions of Television and Radio Broadcasting]], which is the national media regulator in Ukraine. According to the Law, the Council can impose fines when information provided are insufficient or incorrect.<ref name=LOC/>
llm_output:
Removed a reference to the effectiveness of the new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership in Ukraine.

Not Weaponised. The change focuses on the legal framework and its implications without invoking any charged narratives or perspectives related to cultural heritage or conflict.

@@ -64,7 +64,7 @@
 In 2013 there were concerns over the corrupting influence of certain political figures, connected to the government of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] on Ukrainian media.<ref>[http://www.businessinsider.com.au/understanding-euromaidan-2014-1 "A Ukrainian Explains 10 Things The West Needs To Know About The Situation In Kiev: #5 People find it hard to uncover the truth"], Taras Ilkiv, ''Business Insider'', 24 January 2014. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
 
 === Euromaidan revolution and Poroshenko presidency (2014) ===
-[[File:Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, Kyiv. Events of February 18, 2014..jpg|thumbnail|Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, [[Kyiv]]. Events of February 18, 2014.]]Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kiev (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. 
+[[File:Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, Kyiv. Events of February 18, 2014..jpg|thumbnail|Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, [[Kiev]]. Events of February 18, 2014.]]Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kiev (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. 
 In 2014 restrictions to press freedom in Ukraine included police impeding access to public buildings, physical attacks on press rooms, and cyberattacks (e.g. against the ''Glavnoe'', ''Gordon'' and [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] websites); in July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" />
 
 Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media.<ref name="FH" /> Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too.  In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication.<ref name="FH" />

It justified the change as follows:[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine Ukraine 2015 Freedom of the Press] report
due to profound changes in the media environment after the fall of President Viktor Yanukovych’s government in February, despite a rise in attacks on journalists during the Euromaidan protests of early 2014 and the subsequent conflict in eastern Ukraine. The level of government hostility and legal pressure faced by journalists decreased, as did political pressure on state-owned outlets. The media also benefited from improvements to the law on access to information and the increased independence of the broadcasting regulator.
@@ -39,7 +39,7 @@ === Kuchma presidencies (1994-2004) === [[File:Georgi gongadse.jpg|thumbnail|[[Georgiy Gongadze]], [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] journalist, founder of a popular Internet newspaper [[Ukrayinska Pravda]], who was kidnapped and murdered in 2000.]] -After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.[https://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, ISBN 978-3-03910-468-0 (page 21) During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed. In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.[https://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, ISBN 978-0-7658-0897-4 (page 397) In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|title=Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=11 March 2010|deadurl=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905041903/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|archivedate=5 September 2011}}[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship. In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover. Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner. +After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.[https://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC&pg=PA21&dq=Kravchuk+press+freedom&hl=nl&ei=9wp7TO3uOsiBOJ-3qbUG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGQQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kravchuk%20press%20freedom&f=false Ukraine At A Crossroads (Interdisciplinary Studies on Central and Eastern Europe) (v. 1)] by [[Andrej Lushnycky]] and [[Nicolas Hayoz]], [[Peter Lang Publishing]], 2005, {{ISBN|978-3-03910-468-0}} (page 21) During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed. In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemy's of the press.[https://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=2pJ1TNfJGYuoOPH0rccG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Nations in Transit 2000-2001] by [[Adrian Karatnycky]], [[Alexander Motyl]], and [[Amanda Schnetzer]], [[Transaction Publishers]], 2001, {{ISBN|978-0-7658-0897-4}} (page 397) In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|title=Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=11 March 2010|deadurl=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905041903/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|archivedate=5 September 2011}}[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (March 12, 2010)), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship. In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover. Toward the very end of the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2004|2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner. === Orange revolution and Yushchenko presidency (2004-2010) === Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media has become more pluralistic and independent.[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (April 28, 2006 )[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 6, 2007) For instance, attempts by authorities to limit freedom of the press through tax inspections have ceased.[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2004)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 28, 2005)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2001)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 4, 2002)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 31, 2003)[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 8, 2006) Since then the Ukrainian press is considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]] (only the [[Baltic states]] are considered "free").

 * [[Sergei Dolgov]], a newspaper editor from Mariupol, went missing in June 2014 during the [[War in Donbass]] and is presumed dead by some mostly pro-Russian sources <ref>{{cite news|url=http://ria.ru/world/20140716/1016243602.html|title=Newspaper workers don't know chief editor's whereabouts|work=ria.ru}}</ref>
 
 == Internet censorship and surveillance ==
-{{Main article|Internet_in_Ukraine#Internet_censorship_and_surveillance}}In December 2010 the [[OpenNet Initiative]] found little or no evidence of Internet filtering in all four areas (political, social, conflict/security, and Internet tools) for which they test.<ref name="ONI-UkraineProfile-Dec2010">[http://opennet.net/research/profiles/ukraine "ONI Country Profile: Ukraine"], OpenNet Initiative, 21 December 2010</ref>
+{{Main article|Internet in Ukraine#Internet censorship and surveillance}}In December 2010 the [[OpenNet Initiative]] found little or no evidence of Internet filtering in all four areas (political, social, conflict/security, and Internet tools) for which they test.<ref name="ONI-UkraineProfile-Dec2010">[http://opennet.net/research/profiles/ukraine "ONI Country Profile: Ukraine"], OpenNet Initiative, 21 December 2010</ref>
 
 In its ''Freedom on the Net'' report covering the period May 2012 through April 2013, [[Freedom House]] found the Internet in Ukraine to be "largely unhindered" and rated the Internet in Ukraine as "Free" with an overall score of 28 on a scale from 0 (most free) to 100 (least free). The report said that "there is no practice of institutionalized blocking or filtering, or a regulatory framework for censorship of content online", but "there have been attempts at creating legislation which could censor or limit content" and would "present indirect threats to freedom of information online."<ref name="FOTN-Ukraine-2013">[http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-net/2013/ukraine#.UvJZil6togE "Ukraine"], ''Freedom on the Net 2013'', Freedom House, 30 September 2013. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
 
 Access to Internet content in Ukraine remains largely unfettered. Ukraine possesses relatively liberal legislation governing the Internet and access to information. While there are no government restrictions on access to the Internet, law enforcement bodies are known to monitor the Internet, at times without appropriate legal authority. There have been occasional agitations of interference by law enforcement agencies with prominent bloggers and online publications.<ref name="USDOS-CRHRP-Ukraine-2012">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/humanrightsreport/index.htm?year=2012&dlid=204349 "Ukraine"], ''Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 2012'', Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, U.S. Department of State, 15 April 2013. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
+
+In 2014 it was reported that the [[Security Service of Ukraine]] (SBU) asked the [[Ukrainian Internet Association]] (UIA) to block a list of websites accused of "promote war, ethnic hatred, and violent change in the constitutional order or territorial integrity of Ukraine." Such orders should, however, come from courts of law and not security agencies.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Howell O'Neill|first1=Patrick|title=Ukraine seeks to block separatist websites and Russian blogs|url=https://www.dailydot.com/layer8/ukraine-blocks-russian-websites/|accessdate=21 April 2017|work=The Daily Dot|date=4 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Russia-Ukraine Internet Censorship War Rages On|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/the-russia-ukraine-internet-censorship-war-rages-on|accessdate=20 April 2017|work=Motherboard|date=Aug 5, 2014}}</ref>
 
 == Situation in the Russian-annexed Crimea ==

 ==Situation in Ukraine==
 
-In 2017, Ukraine's border officers denied entry to Ukraine to two Russian journalists who were going to cover the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2017|Eurovision Song Contest]] because their visit to Crimea. Previously, photojournalist Ramil Sitdikov was denied entry too.<ref>{{cite web|title=Two more Russian journalists denied entry to Ukraine|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1911158-two-more-russian-journalists-denied-entry-to-ukraine.html|date=2017-05-07}}</ref>
+In September 2015, Ukrainian government banned from entering Ukraine 41 journalists and bloggers from several countries, including Russia, Israel, the United Kingdom, and Germany.<ref name="hrw201705" />
+
+In June 2016, a presidential decree banned 17 Russian journalists, editors, and media executives from traveling to Ukraine.<ref name="hrw201705" />
+
+In May 2017, Ukraine's border officers denied entry to Ukraine to two Russian journalists who were going to cover the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2017|Eurovision Song Contest]] because their visit to Crimea. Previously, photojournalist Ramil Sitdikov was denied entry too.<ref>{{cite web|title=Two more Russian journalists denied entry to Ukraine|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1911158-two-more-russian-journalists-denied-entry-to-ukraine.html|date=2017-05-07}}</ref> That month, Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko signed a decree banning access to Russian social media platforms, news outlets and [[Yandex]] in Ukraine.
+
+Tanya Cooper from [[Human Rights Watch]] said: "This is yet another example of the ease with which President Poroshenko unjustifiably tries to control public discourse in Ukraine". "Poroshenko may try to justify this latest step, but it is a cynical, politically expedient attack on the right to information affecting millions of Ukrainians, and their personal and professional lives".<ref name="hrw201705">{{cite web|title=Ukraine: Revoke Ban on Dozens of Russian Web Companies|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/05/16/ukraine-revoke-ban-dozens-russian-web-companies|date=2017-05-15}}</ref>
 
 == Situation in the Russian-annexed Crimea ==

 This trend has been noted by the US Department of State in particular regarding  matters sensitive to the Government, that pushes toward self-censorship through "tax inspections, libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists".<ref name="USDoS1999" />
 
+==Situation in Ukraine==
+
+In 2017, Ukraine's border officers denied entry to Ukraine to two Russian journalists who were going to cover the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2017|Eurovision Song Contest]] because their visit to Crimea. Previously, photojournalist Ramil Sitdikov was denied entry too.<ref>{{cite web|title=Two more Russian journalists denied entry to Ukraine|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1911158-two-more-russian-journalists-denied-entry-to-ukraine.html|date=2017-05-07}}</ref>
+
 == Situation in the Russian-annexed Crimea ==
 
 The media environment in [[Crimea]] was completely transformed by the March 2014 Russian [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexation]] of the peninsula, after the ejection of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] from power in [[Ukraine]] following the [[euromaidan]] protests. Russian authorities engineered an annexation referendum to Russia, and restrictive Russian media laws started to be enacted in the Black Sea peninsula too. Media conditions in Crimea in 2014 were worse than in [[Russia]] itself, due to the effort of Russia-imposed authorities to rein in a previously relatively pluralistic media landscape. Media outlets were shut down, broadcasts of Ukrainian channels were suspended, and journalists fled the region due to fears of harassment, violence, and arrests. The situation of press freedom in Crimea in 2014 was identified by [[Freedom House]] as the worst in the European continent.<ref name=FHcrimea>[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/crimea Crimea 2015 Press Freedom] report</ref>

It justified the change as follows:[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine Ukraine 2015 Freedom of the Press] report +Freedom House reported the status of press freedom in [[Ukraine]] in 2015 as improving from Not Free to Partly Free. It justified the change as follows:[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine Ukraine 2015 Freedom of the Press] report
due to profound changes in the media environment after the fall of President Viktor Yanukovych’s government in February, despite a rise in attacks on journalists during the Euromaidan protests of early 2014 and the subsequent conflict in eastern Ukraine. The level of government hostility and legal pressure faced by journalists decreased, as did political pressure on state-owned outlets. The media also benefited from improvements to the law on access to information and the increased independence of the broadcasting regulator.
In 2015 the main concerns about media freedom in Ukraine concern the handling of pro-Russian propaganda, the concentration of media ownership, and the high risks of violence against journalists, especially in the conflict areas in the east. -As of September 2015, [[Freedom House]] classifies the [[Internet in Ukraine]] as "partly free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] as "partly free".{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/country/ukraine|title=Ukraine|work=freedomhouse.org|accessdate=28 September 2015}} Press freedom had significantly improved since the [[Orange Revolution]] of 2004. However, in 2010 Freedom House perceived "negative trends in Ukraine".[http://www.rferl.org/content/freedom_house_freedom_in_the_world_report/2275173.html Report Says Decline In Freedom Continues Across Former Soviet Union], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (January 13, 2011) +As of September 2015, Freedom House classifies the [[Internet in Ukraine]] as "partly free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] as "partly free".{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/country/ukraine|title=Ukraine|work=freedomhouse.org|accessdate=28 September 2015}} Press freedom had significantly improved since the [[Orange Revolution]] of 2004. It justified the change as follows:[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine Ukraine 2015 Freedom of the Press] report
due to profound changes in the media environment after the fall of President Viktor Yanukovych’s government in February, despite a rise in attacks on journalists during the Euromaidan protests of early 2014 and the subsequent conflict in eastern Ukraine. The level of government hostility and legal pressure faced by journalists decreased, as did political pressure on state-owned outlets. The media also benefited from improvements to the law on access to information and the increased independence of the broadcasting regulator.
In 2015 the main concerns about media freedom in Ukraine concern the handling of pro-Russian propaganda, the concentration of media ownership, and the high risks of violence against journalists, especially in the conflict areas in the east. -As of September 2015, Freedom House classifies the [[Internet in Ukraine]] as "partly free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] as "partly free".{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/country/ukraine|title=Ukraine|work=freedomhouse.org|accessdate=28 September 2015}} Press freedom had significantly improved since the [[Orange Revolution]] of 2004. However, in 2010 Freedom House perceived "negative trends in Ukraine".[http://www.rferl.org/content/freedom_house_freedom_in_the_world_report/2275173.html Report Says Decline In Freedom Continues Across Former Soviet Union], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (January 13, 2011) +As of September 2015, [[Freedom House]] classifies the [[Internet in Ukraine]] as "partly free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] as "partly free".{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/country/ukraine|title=Ukraine|work=freedomhouse.org|accessdate=28 September 2015}} Press freedom had significantly improved since the [[Orange Revolution]] of 2004. However, in 2010 Freedom House perceived "negative trends in Ukraine".[http://www.rferl.org/content/freedom_house_freedom_in_the_world_report/2275173.html Report Says Decline In Freedom Continues Across Former Soviet Union], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (January 13, 2011) The Ukrainian legal framework on media freedom is deemed "among the most progressive in eastern Europe", although implementation has been uneven. The [[Constitution of Ukraine]] and a 1991 law provide for freedom of speech.[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/1999/367.htm 1999 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2000) @@ -107,16 +107,6 @@ This trend has been noted by the US Department of State in particular regarding matters sensitive to the Government, that pushes toward self-censorship through "tax inspections, libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists". -==Situation in Ukraine== - -In September 2015, Ukrainian government banned from entering Ukraine 41 journalists and bloggers from several countries, including Russia, Israel, the United Kingdom, and Germany. - -In June 2016, a presidential decree banned 17 Russian journalists, editors, and media executives from traveling to Ukraine. - -In May 2017, Ukraine's border officers denied entry to Ukraine to two Russian journalists who were going to cover the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2017|Eurovision Song Contest]] because their visit to Crimea. Previously, photojournalist Ramil Sitdikov was denied entry too.{{cite web|title=Two more Russian journalists denied entry to Ukraine|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1911158-two-more-russian-journalists-denied-entry-to-ukraine.html|date=2017-05-07}} That month, Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko signed a decree banning access to Russian social media platforms, news outlets and [[Yandex]] in Ukraine. - -Tanya Cooper from [[Human Rights Watch]] said: "This is yet another example of the ease with which President Poroshenko unjustifiably tries to control public discourse in Ukraine". "Poroshenko may try to justify this latest step, but it is a cynical, politically expedient attack on the right to information affecting millions of Ukrainians, and their personal and professional lives".{{cite web|title=Ukraine: Revoke Ban on Dozens of Russian Web Companies|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/05/16/ukraine-revoke-ban-dozens-russian-web-companies|date=2017-05-15}} - == Situation in the Russian-annexed Crimea == The media environment in [[Crimea]] was completely transformed by the March 2014 Russian [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexation]] of the peninsula, after the ejection of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] from power in [[Ukraine]] following the [[euromaidan]] protests. Russian authorities engineered an annexation referendum to Russia, and restrictive Russian media laws started to be enacted in the Black Sea peninsula too. Media conditions in Crimea in 2014 were worse than in [[Russia]] itself, due to the effort of Russia-imposed authorities to rein in a previously relatively pluralistic media landscape. Media outlets were shut down, broadcasts of Ukrainian channels were suspended, and journalists fled the region due to fears of harassment, violence, and arrests. The situation of press freedom in Crimea in 2014 was identified by [[Freedom House]] as the worst in the European continent.[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/crimea Crimea 2015 Press Freedom] report

[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)
{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry] , [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014) * On 16 September 2015 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning forty-one foreign journalists and bloggers who 'threaten national interests' from Ukraine. This was later reduced to 38.{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 September 2015}} +* In June 2016, a presidential decree banned 17 Russian journalists, editors, and media executives from traveling to Ukraine. * In May 2017, Ukraine's border officers denied entry to Ukraine to two Russian journalists who were going to cover the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2017|Eurovision Song Contest]] because their visit to Crimea. Previously, photojournalist Ramil Sitdikov was denied entry too.{{cite web|title=Two more Russian journalists denied entry to Ukraine|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1911158-two-more-russian-journalists-denied-entry-to-ukraine.html|date=2017-05-07}} * On 16 May 2017 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning various Russian internet service providers and news sources, among others, [[VK (social networking)|VKontakte]], [[Odnoklassniki]], [[Yandex]], [[Rossiya Segodnya]], [[RBC Information Systems|RBC]], [[All-Russia State Television and Radio Broadcasting Company|VGTRK]] allegedly for "security reasons".{{Cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/421954.html|title=All of Ukrainian president's official pages on Russian social media sites being closed|work=Interfax-Ukraine|access-date=2017-05-16}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/ukraine-bans-dozens-of-russian-websites/3852930.html|title=Ukraine Bans Dozens of Russian Websites|last=News|first=VOA|work=VOA|access-date=2017-05-16|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.rt.com/business/388502-ukraine-bans-vk-yandex/|title=Ukraine bans most popular social networks because they are Russian-owned|work=RT International|access-date=2017-05-16|language=en-US}} Tanya Cooper from [[Human Rights Watch]] said: "This is yet another example of the ease with which President Poroshenko unjustifiably tries to control public discourse in Ukraine", "Poroshenko may try to justify this latest step, but it is a cynical, politically expedient attack on the right to information affecting millions of Ukrainians, and their personal and professional lives".{{cite web|title=Ukraine: Revoke Ban on Dozens of Russian Web Companies|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/05/16/ukraine-revoke-ban-dozens-russian-web-companies|date=2017-05-15}}

Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. due to profound changes in the media environment after the fall of President Viktor Yanukovych’s government in February, despite a rise in attacks on journalists during the Euromaidan protests of early 2014 and the subsequent conflict in eastern Ukraine. The level of government hostility and legal pressure faced by journalists decreased, as did political pressure on state-owned outlets. The media also benefited from improvements to the law on access to information and the increased independence of the broadcasting regulator.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -147,9 +147,11 @@
 
 In its ''Freedom on the Net'' report covering the period May 2012 through April 2013, [[Freedom House]] found the Internet in Ukraine to be "largely unhindered" and rated the Internet in Ukraine as "Free" with an overall score of 28 on a scale from 0 (most free) to 100 (least free). The report said that "there is no practice of institutionalized blocking or filtering, or a regulatory framework for censorship of content online", but "there have been attempts at creating legislation which could censor or limit content" and would "present indirect threats to freedom of information online."<ref name="FOTN-Ukraine-2013">[http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-net/2013/ukraine#.UvJZil6togE "Ukraine"], ''Freedom on the Net 2013'', Freedom House, 30 September 2013. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
 
-Access to Internet content in Ukraine remains largely unfettered. Ukraine possesses relatively liberal legislation governing the Internet and access to information. While there are no government restrictions on access to the Internet, law enforcement bodies are known to monitor the Internet, at times without appropriate legal authority. There have been occasional agitations of interference by law enforcement agencies with prominent bloggers and online publications.<ref name="USDOS-CRHRP-Ukraine-2012">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/humanrightsreport/index.htm?year=2012&dlid=204349 "Ukraine"], ''Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 2012'', Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, U.S. Department of State, 15 April 2013. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
+As of 2012, access to Internet content in Ukraine was largely unfettered. Ukraine possessed relatively liberal legislation governing the Internet and access to information. While there were no government restrictions on access to the Internet, law enforcement bodies were known to monitor the Internet, at times without appropriate legal authority. There have been occasional agitations of interference by law enforcement agencies with prominent bloggers and online publications.<ref name="USDOS-CRHRP-Ukraine-2012">[http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/humanrightsreport/index.htm?year=2012&dlid=204349 "Ukraine"], ''Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 2012'', Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, U.S. Department of State, 15 April 2013. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
 
 In 2014 it was reported that the [[Security Service of Ukraine]] (SBU) asked the [[Ukrainian Internet Association]] (UIA) to block a list of websites accused of "promote war, ethnic hatred, and violent change in the constitutional order or territorial integrity of Ukraine." Such orders should, however, come from courts of law and not security agencies.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Howell O'Neill|first1=Patrick|title=Ukraine seeks to block separatist websites and Russian blogs|url=https://www.dailydot.com/layer8/ukraine-blocks-russian-websites/|accessdate=21 April 2017|work=The Daily Dot|date=4 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Russia-Ukraine Internet Censorship War Rages On|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/the-russia-ukraine-internet-censorship-war-rages-on|accessdate=20 April 2017|work=Motherboard|date=Aug 5, 2014}}</ref>
+
+On 16 May 2017, [[Petro Poroshenko|President Poroshenko]] signed a decree requiring providers to block access to a number of Russian websites including four of the most popular websites in the Ukraine: [[VK (social networking)|VKontakte]], [[Odnoklassniki]], [[Yandex]] and [[Mail.Ru]]. The president claimed they participated in an information war against Ukraine.<ref name=guardian-20170516>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/16/ukraine-blocks-popular-russian-websites-kremlin-role-war |title=Ukraine blocks popular social networks as part of sanctions on Russia |last=Luhn |first=Alec |newspaper=The Guardian |date=16 May 2017 |accessdate=17 June 2017}}</ref>
 
 ==Self-censorship==
 In Ukraine there are tendencies toward self-censorship:<ref name="USDoS1999" /> according to Roman Shutov, programme director with Detektor Media in Kiev "the owner dictates the content and editorial policy of the media and has a real influence on how the very important topics are covered in Ukraine."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Reichardt|first1=Adam|title=Reforming Ukraine’s media. Slow progress at risk|url=http://www.neweasterneurope.eu/articles-and-commentary/2201-reforming-ukraine-s-media-slow-progress-at-risk|accessdate=17 April 2017|publisher=New Eastern Europe|date=29 November 2016}}</ref>
comment: /* Internet censorship and surveillance */ not decree blocking a number of popular Russian websites

Weaponised. The addition emphasizes Ukraine's actions against Russian influence online, framing it within the context of an "information war," which can be seen as a narrative that supports a defensive stance against perceived external threats, thus potentially weaponizing the cultural heritage narrative in the context of the ongoing conflict.

 == Attacks and threats against journalists ==
 Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0"/>  78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" /> In September 2016 [[Inter (TV channel)|Inter]] TV channel -often accused of being pro-Russia- was put to fire during a protest.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pro-Russia TV station in Kiev evacuated after fire|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/05/pro-russia-tv-inter-kiev-evacuated-fire-ukraine|accessdate=19 April 2017|work=The Guardian|date=5 September 2016}}</ref>

If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15 year prison sentence.  Press freedom had significantly improved since the [[Orange Revolution]] of 2004.<ref name=FHouse2007>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ba65SKN2I_UC&pg=PA11&lpg=PA11&dq=The+repressive+media+landscape+in+the+former+Soviet+Union+is+illuminated+by+the+fact+that+10+of+the+12+non-Baltic+post-Soviet+states+are+ranked+as+Not+Free.+The+only+two+that+enjoy+Partly+Free+status,+Georgia+and+Ukraine,+have+recently+experienced+political+upheaval+and+democratic+opening&source=bl&ots=ftIAiQ5L68&sig=pZDPbohOUOfCaBUP_xpmtOIaJDI&hl=nl&ei=hhOJTJ74GMemOO6OjYsH&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=The%20repressive%20media%20landscape%20in%20the%20former%20Soviet%20Union%20is%20illuminated%20by%20the%20fact%20that%2010%20of%20the%2012%20non-Baltic%20post-Soviet%20states%20are%20ranked%20as%20Not%20Free.%20The%20only%20two%20that%20enjoy%20Partly%20Free%20status%2C%20Georgia%20and%20Ukraine%2C%20have%20recently%20experienced%20political%20upheaval%20and%20democratic%20opening&f=false Freedom of the Press 2007: A Global Survey of Media Independence] by [[Freedom House]], [[Rowman & Littlefield]], 2007, {{ISBN|978-0-7425-5582-2}} (page 11/12)</ref><ref name=organge/><ref name=USDoS2007/> However, in 2010 Freedom House perceived "negative trends in Ukraine".<ref name="negative trends 2010">[http://www.rferl.org/content/freedom_house_freedom_in_the_world_report/2275173.html Report Says Decline In Freedom Continues Across Former Soviet Union], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (January 13, 2011)</ref>
 
 The Ukrainian legal framework on media freedom is deemed "among the most progressive in eastern Europe", although implementation has been uneven.<ref name=FH/>
 The [[Constitution of Ukraine]] and a 1991 law provide for freedom of speech.<ref name="USDoS1999">[https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/1999/367.htm 1999 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2000)</ref>
 
 Many Ukrainian journalists found themselves internally displaced due to the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]] and the [[war in Donbass]], including Donetsk-based investigative journalist Oleksiy Matsuka, Luhansk blogger Serhiy Ivanov and Donetsk ''Ostrov'' independent website editor Serhiy Harmash. The entire staff of ''Ostrov'' left the occupied Donbass areas and relocated to Kiev.<ref name=FH/>
-
-Ukraine is in 102nd place in the 2017 [[World Press Freedom Index]].<ref name="rsf201705" /> Organizations like [[Reporters Without Borders]], [[Human Rights Watch]] and [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] have condemned Poroshenko government recent bans on media.<ref name="rsf201701" /><ref name="hrw201705" /><ref name="cpj201705">{{cite web|url=https://cpj.org/2017/05/ukraine-bans-russian-media-outlets-websites.php|title=Ukraine bans Russian media outlets, websites|publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists|date=17 May 2017|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=Committee to Protect Journalists is not a reliable source.|date=June 2017}}

Events of February 18, 2014.]]Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.{{cite web|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }} The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kiev (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In 2014 restrictions to press freedom in Ukraine included police impeding access to public buildings, physical attacks on press rooms, and cyberattacks (e.g. against the ''Glavnoe'', ''Gordon'' and [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] websites); in July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''. Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media. Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too. In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication. [[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kiev government. Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view. For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey “propaganda,” and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country. -*The broadcasting regulators was mandated by courts to suspend temporarily the rebroadcasting of certain Russian channels in Ukraine. In 2014 Ukraine blocked 14 Russian television channels from its cable networks.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014. By September 2014, the number of television channels blocked from Ukrainian cable networks had risen to 15; the legal basis for this were charges of stirring hatred, threatening national security and supporting separatism. +*The broadcasting regulators was mandated by courts to suspend temporarily the rebroadcasting of certain Russian channels in Ukraine. In 2014 Ukraine blocked 14 Russian television channels from its cable networks.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014. By September 2014, the number of television channels blocked from Ukrainian cable networks had risen to 15; the legal basis for this were charges of stirring hatred, threatening national security and supporting separatism. *On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}{{#tag:ref|The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}|group=nb}} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014. * Ukrainian authorities denied entry to several Russian journalists throughout 2014, with bans on re-entry for some of up to 5 years * The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Information Policy]] was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)
{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry] , [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)

 The Ukrainian legal framework on media freedom is deemed "among the most progressive in eastern Europe", although implementation has been uneven.<ref name=FH/>

+The [[Constitution of Ukraine]] and a 1991 law provide for freedom of speech.<ref name="USDoS1999">[https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/1999/367.htm 1999 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 23, 2000)</ref>
 
 Many Ukrainian journalists found themselves internally displaced due to the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]] and the [[war in Donbass]], including Donetsk-based investigative journalist Oleksiy Matsuka, Luhansk blogger Serhiy Ivanov and Donetsk ''Ostrov'' independent website editor Serhiy Harmash. The entire staff of ''Ostrov'' left the occupied Donbass areas and relocated to Kiev.<ref name=FH/>

 After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref name="HayozLushnycky2005">{{cite book|last1=Hayoz|first1=Nicolas|last2=Lushnycky|first2=Andrej N.|editor1=Nicolas Hayoz|editor2=Andrej N.  In its ''Freedom on the Net'' report covering the period May 2012 through April 2013, [[Freedom House]] found the Internet in Ukraine to be "largely unhindered" and rated the Internet in Ukraine as "Free" with an overall score of 28 on a scale from 0 (most free) to 100 (least free). Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
 
-As of 2012, access to Internet content in Ukraine was largely unfettered. Ukraine possessed relatively liberal legislation governing the Internet and access to information. While there were no government restrictions on access to the Internet, law enforcement bodies were known to monitor the Internet, at times without appropriate legal authority. Is it the media or the country being qualified as 'free' and/or 'partly free'? Are civil liberties/human rights and press freedom being conflated?}}
 
 Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]´s [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2009|work=rsf.org|date=2009|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091022183400/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|archive-date=22 October 2009}}</ref> 87 in 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2008|work=rsf.org|date=2008|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607100340/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|archive-date=7 June 2009}}</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2002|work=rsf.org|date=October 2002|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703081345/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|archive-date=3 July 2009}}</ref> and even the 132nd spot in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2004|work=rsf.org|date=2004|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905174452/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|archivedate=5 September 2009}}</ref> In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".<ref>{{cite web|format=PDF|url=http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|title=Press Freedom Index 2013|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref> In the 2014 World Press Freedom Index Ukraine was placed 127th.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uatoday.tv/news/ukraine-takes-127th-place-in-rating-of-freedom-of-speech-402225.html|title=Ukraine takes 127th place in rating of freedom of speech|work=[[Ukraine Today]]|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>

@@ -61,7 +61,8 @@
 In 2013 there were concerns over the corrupting influence of certain political figures, connected to the government of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] on Ukrainian media.<ref>[http://www.businessinsider.com.au/understanding-euromaidan-2014-1 "A Ukrainian Explains 10 Things The West Needs To Know About The Situation In Kiev: #5 People find it hard to uncover the truth"], Taras Ilkiv, ''Business Insider'', 24 January 2014. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
 
 === Euromaidan revolution and Poroshenko presidency (2014) ===
-[[File:Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, Kyiv. Events of February 18, 2014..jpg|thumbnail|Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, [[Kiev]]. Events of February 18, 2014.]]Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]].{{weasel word|date=July 2017}}{{cn|date=July 2017}} A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kiev (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. 
+[[File:Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, Kyiv. Events of February 18, 2014..jpg|thumbnail|Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, [[Kiev]]. Events of February 18, 2014.]]
+A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kiev (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. 
 In 2014 restrictions to press freedom in Ukraine included police impeding access to public buildings, physical attacks on press rooms, and cyberattacks (e.g. against the ''Glavnoe'', ''Gordon'' and [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] websites); in July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" />
 
 Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media.<ref name="FH" /> Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too.  In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication.<ref name="FH" />

2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.|group=nb}} +[[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kiev government. +++ 
@@ -483,7 +483,7 @@
 
 In 2014 it was reported that the [[Security Service of Ukraine]] (SBU) asked the [[Ukrainian Internet Association]] (UIA) to block a list of websites accused of "promote war, ethnic hatred, and violent change in the constitutional order or territorial integrity of Ukraine." Such orders should, however, come from courts of law and not security agencies.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Howell O'Neill|first1=Patrick|title=Ukraine seeks to block separatist websites and Russian blogs|url=https://www.dailydot.com/layer8/ukraine-blocks-russian-websites/|accessdate=21 April 2017|work=The Daily Dot|date=4 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Russia-Ukraine Internet Censorship War Rages On|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/the-russia-ukraine-internet-censorship-war-rages-on|accessdate=20 April 2017|work=Motherboard|date=Aug 5, 2014}}</ref>
 
-On 16 May 2017, [[Petro Poroshenko|President Poroshenko]] signed a decree requiring providers to block access to a number of Russian websites including four of the most popular websites in the Ukraine: [[VK (social networking)|VKontakte]], [[Odnoklassniki]], [[Yandex]] and [[Mail.Ru]]. The president claimed they participated in an information war against Ukraine.<ref name=guardian-20170516>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/16/ukraine-blocks-popular-russian-websites-kremlin-role-war |title=Ukraine blocks popular social networks as part of sanctions on Russia |last=Luhn |first=Alec |newspaper=The Guardian |date=16 May 2017 |accessdate=17 June 2017}}</ref>
+On 16 May 2017, [[Petro Poroshenko|President Poroshenko]] signed a decree requiring providers to block access to a number of Russian websites including four of the most popular websites in Ukraine: [[VK (social networking)|VKontakte]], [[Odnoklassniki]], [[Yandex]] and [[Mail.Ru]]. The president claimed they participated in an information war against Ukraine.<ref name=guardian-20170516>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/16/ukraine-blocks-popular-russian-websites-kremlin-role-war |title=Ukraine blocks popular social networks as part of sanctions on Russia |last=Luhn |first=Alec |newspaper=The Guardian |date=16 May 2017 |accessdate=17 June 2017}}</ref>
 
 ==Self-censorship==
 In Ukraine there are tendencies toward self-censorship:<ref name="USDoS1999" /> according to Roman Shutov, programme director with Detektor Media in Kiev, "the owner dictates the content and editorial policy of the media and has a real influence on how the very important topics are covered in Ukraine."<ref name="ReichardtShutov">{{cite interview|last=Shutov|first=Roman|interviewer=Adam Reichardt|url=http://www.neweasterneurope.eu/articles-and-commentary/2201-reforming-ukraine-s-media-slow-progress-at-risk|title=Reforming Ukraine's media. Slow progress at risk|publisher=neweasterneurope.eu|date=29 November 2016|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>

The [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media. Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. [http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)

Events of February 18, 2014.]]Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]].{{weasel word}}{{cn}} A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kiev (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. 
+[[File:Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, Kyiv. Events of February 18, 2014..jpg|thumbnail|Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, [[Kiev]]. Events of February 18, 2014.]]Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]].{{weasel word|date=July 2017}}{{cn|date=July 2017}} A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kiev (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. 
 In 2014 restrictions to press freedom in Ukraine included police impeding access to public buildings, physical attacks on press rooms, and cyberattacks (e.g. against the ''Glavnoe'', ''Gordon'' and [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] websites); in July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" />
 
 Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media.<ref name="FH" /> Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too.  In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication.<ref name="FH" />

 ===Literature===
-The Government of Ukraine started banning books in 2016 that a special committee (State Committee for State TV and Radio Broadcasting's licensing and distribution-control department) had determined to contain anti-Ukrainian content. In January 2018, the Russian version of British historian [[Anthony Beevor]]'s ''[[Stalingrad (book)|Stalingrad]]'' was added to this list. The head of the comittee, Serhiy Oliyinyk, told [[Radio Free Europe]] that one particular reason was that Beevor had included information about Ukrainian militia killing 90 Jewish children on orders of the SS "to save the feelings of the [[Sonderkommando]]." He claimed this had never been confirmed at post-war trials and was taken from Soviet sources. Beevor strongly criticized the ban and said the source was actually German resistance fighter [[Helmuth Groscurth]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/beevor-historian-ukraine-ban-stalingrad/28980932.html Historian Beevor 'Astonished' At Ukraine Ban On Best-Selling 'Stalingrad'], ''Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty</ref> "It’s utterly outrageous. They have no reason for doing it. It’s quite clear both in the Russian edition and English edition what the source was and where it came from – this rather brave and religious officer [Groscurth] who protested strongly, despite threats he would be reported to Himmler … about this massacre of the children. There’s no way the Soviets would even have known about it."<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/jan/19/stalingrad-author-anthony-beevor-speaks-out-over-ukraine-book-ban Stalingrad author Anthony Beevor speaks out over Ukraine book ban], ''The Guardian''</ref> It was also strongly criticized by the Ukraine-based ''Human Rights in Ukraine''.<ref>[http://khpg.org/en/index.php?id=1516137187 Ukraine imposes baffling ban on work by renowned English historian & others], ''Human Rights in Ukraine''</ref>
+The Government of Ukraine started banning books in 2016 that a special committee (State Committee for State TV and Radio Broadcasting's licensing and distribution-control department) had determined to contain anti-Ukrainian content. In January 2018, the Russian version of British historian [[Anthony Beevor]]'s ''[[Stalingrad (book)|Stalingrad]]'' was added to this list. The head of the committee, Serhiy Oliyinyk, told [[Radio Free Europe]] that one particular reason was that Beevor had included information about Ukrainian militia killing 90 Jewish children on orders of the SS "to save the feelings of the [[Sonderkommando]]." He claimed this had never been confirmed at post-war trials and was taken from Soviet sources. Beevor strongly criticized the ban and said the source was actually German resistance fighter [[Helmuth Groscurth]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/beevor-historian-ukraine-ban-stalingrad/28980932.html Historian Beevor 'Astonished' At Ukraine Ban On Best-Selling 'Stalingrad'], ''Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty</ref> "It’s utterly outrageous. They have no reason for doing it. It’s quite clear both in the Russian edition and English edition what the source was and where it came from – this rather brave and religious officer [Groscurth] who protested strongly, despite threats he would be reported to Himmler … about this massacre of the children. There’s no way the Soviets would even have known about it."<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/jan/19/stalingrad-author-anthony-beevor-speaks-out-over-ukraine-book-ban Stalingrad author Anthony Beevor speaks out over Ukraine book ban], ''The Guardian''</ref> It was also strongly criticized by the Ukraine-based ''Human Rights in Ukraine''.<ref>[http://khpg.org/en/index.php?id=1516137187 Ukraine imposes baffling ban on work by renowned English historian & others], ''Human Rights in Ukraine''</ref>
 
 == Internet censorship and surveillance ==
 {{Main article|Internet in Ukraine#Internet censorship and surveillance}}In December 2010 the [[OpenNet Initiative]] found little or no evidence of Internet filtering in all four areas (political, social, conflict/security, and Internet tools) for which they test.<ref name="ONI-UkraineProfile-Dec2010">[http://opennet.net/research/profiles/ukraine "ONI Country Profile: Ukraine"], OpenNet Initiative, 21 December 2010</ref>
