(according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".<ref>{{cite web|format=PDF|url=http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|title=Press Freedom Index 2013|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref> In the 2014 World Press Freedom Index Ukraine was placed 127th.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uatoday.tv/news/ukraine-takes-127th-place-in-rating-of-freedom-of-speech-402225.html|title=Ukraine takes 127th place in rating of freedom of speech|work=[[Ukraine Today]]|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
 
 During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and [[Southeastern Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/half-of-all-ukrainians-consider-current-freedom-of-50721.html|title=Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=15 October 2009|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>

 In 2014, the [[European Commission]]'s progress report on the implementation of the [[European Neighbourhood Policy]] in Ukraine found the lack of transparency as an issue in the country and that proper legislative framework should be adopted.<ref name=COE/> To comply with its international commitment, legislation on transparency of media ownership has been reformed in 2015. On September 10, 2015, President [[Petro Poroshenko]] signed the law called "On Amendments to Several Laws of Ukraine on Ensuring the Transparency of Media Ownership and Implementing the Principles of state Policy in the Sphere of Television and Radio Broadcasting". The law entered into force on 1 October 2015.<ref name=OSCE2015>{{cite web |url=http://www.osce.org/fom/187956  |title=OSCE Representative welcomes law on transparency of media ownership in Ukraine as it comes into force |date=1 October 2015 |website= Osce.org |publisher= Organisation for Security & Co-operation in Europe |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
 
-The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts <ref name=MOM>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website= Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher= Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev)}}</ref> but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries.<ref name=OSCE2015/> These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications.<ref name=MOM/> Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine.<ref name=OSCE2015/> Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners.<ref name=LOC>{{cite web |url=http://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
+The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts <ref name=MOM>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website= Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher= Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev)}}</ref> but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries.<ref name=OSCE2015/> These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications.<ref name=MOM/> Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine.<ref name=OSCE2015/> Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners.<ref name=LOC>{{cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
 
 Specifically, the new law amends article 12 of the existing Law of Ukraine on Television and Radio Broadcasting of 1994, establishing that national and local government authorities, individuals and legal entities which are registered offline, political parties, religious organisations, professional unions, and persons that were convicted by courts and that are still serving their sentences cannot be owners of a TV or radio stations in Ukraine. Furthermore, the Law prohibits to physical or legal persons residing in a country which is recognised as an aggressor or occupier the right to own a television or a radio station in Ukraine.<ref name=LOC/> This sentence refers to the [[Russia|Russian Federation]] which [[Crimean status referendum, 2014|annexed Crimea]] in 2014.<ref name=LOC/> The Law provides a new definition of ownership which is closely connected to the exercise of a decisive influence in the management or business activity of the media outlet directly or through other persons and includes also [[final beneficiaries]].<ref name=LOC/> The Law requires that information on the ownership structure and on the individuals owning at least 10% or more of a television or radio broadcasting have to be made public on the company's website and sent to the [[National Council for Questions of Television and Radio Broadcasting]], which is the national media regulator in Ukraine. According to the Law, the Council can impose fines when information provided are insufficient or incorrect.<ref name=LOC/>

 ===Literature===
-The Government of Ukraine started banning books in 2016 that a special committee (State Committee for State TV and Radio Broadcasting's licensing and distribution-control department) had determined to contain anti-Ukrainian content. In January 2018, the Russian version of British historian [[Anthony Beevor]]'s ''[[Stalingrad (book)|Stalingrad]]'' was added to this list. The head of the committee, Serhiy Oliyinyk, told [[Radio Free Europe]] that one particular reason was that Beevor had included information about Ukrainian militia killing 90 Jewish children on orders of the SS "to save the feelings of the [[Sonderkommando]]." He claimed this had never been confirmed at post-war trials and was taken from Soviet sources. Beevor strongly criticized the ban and said the source was actually German resistance fighter [[Helmuth Groscurth]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/beevor-historian-ukraine-ban-stalingrad/28980932.html Historian Beevor 'Astonished' At Ukraine Ban On Best-Selling 'Stalingrad'], ''Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty</ref> "It’s utterly outrageous. They have no reason for doing it. It’s quite clear both in the Russian edition and English edition what the source was and where it came from – this rather brave and religious officer [Groscurth] who protested strongly, despite threats he would be reported to Himmler … about this massacre of the children. There’s no way the Soviets would even have known about it."<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/jan/19/stalingrad-author-anthony-beevor-speaks-out-over-ukraine-book-ban Stalingrad author Anthony Beevor speaks out over Ukraine book ban], ''The Guardian''</ref> It was also strongly criticized by the Ukraine-based ''Human Rights in Ukraine''.<ref>[http://khpg.org/en/index.php?id=1516137187 Ukraine imposes baffling ban on work by renowned English historian & others], ''Human Rights in Ukraine''</ref>

The head of the committee, Serhiy Oliyinyk, told [[Radio Free Europe]] that one particular reason was that Beevor had included information about Ukrainian militia killing 90 Jewish children on orders of the SS "to save the feelings of the [[Sonderkommando]]." He claimed this had never been confirmed at post-war trials and was taken from Soviet sources. Beevor strongly criticized the ban and said the source was actually German resistance fighter [[Helmuth Groscurth]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/beevor-historian-ukraine-ban-stalingrad/28980932.html Historian Beevor 'Astonished' At Ukraine Ban On Best-Selling 'Stalingrad'], ''Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty</ref> "It’s utterly outrageous.  ===Literature===
-The Government of Ukraine started banning books in 2016 that a special committee (State Committee for State TV and Radio Broadcasting's licensing and distribution-control department) had determined to contain anti-Ukrainian content. In January 2018, British historian [[Anthony Beevor]]'s ''[[Stalingrad (book)|Stalingrad]]'' was added to this list. The head of the comittee, Serhiy Oliyinyk, told [[Radio Free Europe]] that Beevor had included information about Ukrainians being coerced by the SS to kill Jews that had never been confirmed at post-war trials and was taken from Soviet sources. The portion in question was: "Ukrainian nationalists were tasked with shooting the children [in order to] spare the feelings of SS Sonderkommando. Beevor strongly criticized the ban and stated that the source was actually German resistance fighter [[Helmuth Groscurth]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/beevor-historian-ukraine-ban-stalingrad/28980932.html]</ref>
+The Government of Ukraine started banning books in 2016 that a special committee (State Committee for State TV and Radio Broadcasting's licensing and distribution-control department) had determined to contain anti-Ukrainian content. In January 2018, the Russian version of British historian [[Anthony Beevor]]'s ''[[Stalingrad (book)|Stalingrad]]'' was added to this list. The head of the comittee, Serhiy Oliyinyk, told [[Radio Free Europe]] that one particular reason was that Beevor had included information about Ukrainian militia killing 90 Jewish children on orders of the SS "to save the feelings of the [[Sonderkommando]]." He claimed this had never been confirmed at post-war trials and was taken from Soviet sources. Beevor strongly criticized the ban and said the source was actually German resistance fighter [[Helmuth Groscurth]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/beevor-historian-ukraine-ban-stalingrad/28980932.html]</ref> "It’s utterly outrageous. They have no reason for doing it. It’s quite clear both in the Russian edition and English edition what the source was and where it came from – this rather brave and religious officer [Groscurth] who protested strongly, despite threats he would be reported to Himmler … about this massacre of the children. There’s no way the Soviets would even have known about it."<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/jan/19/stalingrad-author-anthony-beevor-speaks-out-over-ukraine-book-ban]</ref> It was also strongly criticized by the Ukraine-based ''Human Rights in Ukraine''.<ref>[http://khpg.org/en/index.php?id=1516137187]</ref>
 
 == Internet censorship and surveillance ==
 {{Main article|Internet in Ukraine#Internet censorship and surveillance}}In December 2010 the [[OpenNet Initiative]] found little or no evidence of Internet filtering in all four areas (political, social, conflict/security, and Internet tools) for which they test.<ref name="ONI-UkraineProfile-Dec2010">[http://opennet.net/research/profiles/ukraine "ONI Country Profile: Ukraine"], OpenNet Initiative, 21 December 2010</ref>

 [[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist Ruslan Kotsaba and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army.  Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]s' [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2009|work=rsf.org|date=2009|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091022183400/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|archive-date=22 October 2009}}</ref> 87 in 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2008|work=rsf.org|date=2008|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607100340/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|archive-date=7 June 2009}}</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2002|work=rsf.org|date=October 2002|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703081345/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|archive-date=3 July 2009}}</ref> and even the 132nd spot in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2004|work=rsf.org|date=2004|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905174452/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|archivedate=5 September 2009}}</ref> In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|Viktor Yanukovych's election as president in February]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2010|work=rsf.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124050702/http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|archivedate=24 November 2010|df=dmy}}</ref> In 2013 Ukraine occupied the 126th spot (dropping 10 places compared with 2012); (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".<ref>{{cite web|format=PDF|url=http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|title=Press Freedom Index 2013|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|accessdate=29 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151013163532/http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|archivedate=13 October 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In the 2017 World Press Freedom Index Ukraine was placed 102th.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://rsf.org/en/ranking|title=2017 World Press Freedom Index {{!}} Reporters Without Borders|work=RSF|access-date=2017-12-09|language=en}}</ref>
 
-During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and [[Southeastern Ukraine|southeastern]] regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/half-of-all-ukrainians-consider-current-freedom-of-50721.html|title=Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=15 October 2009|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
+During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and southeastern regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/half-of-all-ukrainians-consider-current-freedom-of-50721.html|title=Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=15 October 2009|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
 
 In a late 2010 poll also conducted by the Research & Branding Group 56% of all Ukrainians trusted the media and 38.5% didn't.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/|title=Poll: More than half of Ukrainians trust the media|publisher=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=17 December 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110120213543/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/|archivedate=20 January 2011}}</ref>

Removed a line about an opinion poll regarding freedom of speech in Ukraine.

Not Weaponised – The change does not introduce or remove any language that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage. It simply removes a factual statement about public opinion without altering the narrative context.

Changed the formatting of the reflist from `{{reflist |colwidth=25em}}` to `{{reflist}}`.

Not Weaponised – The change is purely technical and does not involve any language that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage.

The change made is the **addition of a reference** to the text, specifically a citation from the Committee to Protect Journalists regarding Ukraine. 

**Weaponised**: The addition of this reference could be seen as an attempt to bolster claims about media freedom in Ukraine, which may be used to support narratives about the government's actions against Russian media. This aligns with the ongoing discourse surrounding media freedom and the portrayal of Ukraine's political landscape, potentially weaponizing the cultural narrative around press freedom in the context of the conflict with Russia.

The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.|group=nb}} The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Information Policy]] was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)

{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry] , [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014) @@ -83,7 +83,7 @@ === Press freedom scores as perceived by Freedom House === -The following table shows press freedom scores calculated each year by a foreign non-governmental organisation called [[Freedom House]]. The year is the year of issue, and data relate to the previous year. *Score 0–30 = press were free. *Score 31–60 = press were partly free. *Score 61–100 = press were not free. @@ -536,11 +536,11 @@ '''Transparency of media ownership''' refers to the public availability of accurate, comprehensive and up-to-date information about media ownership structures. A legal regime guaranteeing transparency of media ownership makes possible for the public as well as for media authorities to find out who effectively owns, controls and influences the media as well as media influence on political parties or state bodies. -The lack of transparency on media ownership has typically been a negative trait of the [[Media of Ukraine|Ukrainian media system]]. In 2005 [[Ukraine]] committed itself to the [[Council of Europe]] to introduce a law for ensuring transparency of media ownership, according to the Resolution 1466 (2005)1 of the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]].{{cite web |url=http://www.coe.int/en/web/kyiv/-/transparency-media-ownership-in-ukraine-key-issue-at-the-international-conference-of-the-european-union-and-the-council-of-europe |title=Transparency media ownership in Ukraine – key issue at the international conference of the European Union and the Council of Europe ||date=11 June 2015 |website= Coe.int |publisher= Council of Europe. Office in Ukraine |access-date=12 January 2017}} - -In 2014, the [[European Commission]]'s progress report on the implementation of the [[European Neighbourhood Policy]] in Ukraine found the lack of transparency as an issue in the country and that proper legislative framework should be adopted. To comply with its international commitment, legislation on transparency of media ownership has been reformed in 2015. On September 10 2015, President [[Petro Poroshenko]] signed the law called "On Amendments to Several Laws of Ukraine on Ensuring the Transparency of Media Ownership and Implementing the Principles of state Policy in the Sphere of Television and Radio Broadcasting". The law entered into force on 1 October 2015.{{cite web |url=http://www.osce.org/fom/187956 |title=OSCE Representative welcomes law on transparency of media ownership in Ukraine as it comes into force |date=1 October 2015 |website= Osce.org |publisher= Organisation for Security & Co-operation in Europe |access-date=12 January 2017}} - -The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts {{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website= Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher= Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev)}} but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries. These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications. Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine. Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners. {{cite web |url=http://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}} +The lack of transparency on media ownership has typically been a negative trait of the [[Media of Ukraine|Ukrainian media system]]. In 2005 [[Ukraine]] committed itself to the [[Council of Europe]] to introduce a law for ensuring transparency of media ownership, according to the Resolution 1466 (2005)1 of the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]].{{cite web |url=http://www.coe.int/en/web/kyiv/-/transparency-media-ownership-in-ukraine-key-issue-at-the-international-conference-of-the-european-union-and-the-council-of-europe |title=Transparency media ownership in Ukraine – key issue at the international conference of the European Union and the Council of Europe |date=11 June 2015 |website= Coe.int |publisher= Council of Europe. Office in Ukraine |access-date=12 January 2017}} + +In 2014, the [[European Commission]]'s progress report on the implementation of the [[European Neighbourhood Policy]] in Ukraine found the lack of transparency as an issue in the country and that proper legislative framework should be adopted. To comply with its international commitment, legislation on transparency of media ownership has been reformed in 2015. On September 10, 2015, President [[Petro Poroshenko]] signed the law called "On Amendments to Several Laws of Ukraine on Ensuring the Transparency of Media Ownership and Implementing the Principles of state Policy in the Sphere of Television and Radio Broadcasting". The law entered into force on 1 October 2015.{{cite web |url=http://www.osce.org/fom/187956 |title=OSCE Representative welcomes law on transparency of media ownership in Ukraine as it comes into force |date=1 October 2015 |website= Osce.org |publisher= Organisation for Security & Co-operation in Europe |access-date=12 January 2017}} + +The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts {{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website= Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher= Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev)}} but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries. These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications. Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine. Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners.{{cite web |url=http://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}} Specifically, the new law amends article 12 of the existing Law of Ukraine on Television and Radio Broadcasting of 1994, establishing that national and local government authorities, individuals and legal entities which are registered offline, political parties, religious organisations, professional unions, and persons that were convicted by courts and that are still serving their sentences cannot be owners of a TV or radio stations in Ukraine. Furthermore, the Law prohibits to physical or legal persons residing in a country which is recognised as an aggressor or occupier the right to own a television or a radio station in Ukraine. This sentence refers to the [[Russia|Russian Federation]] which [[Crimean status referendum, 2014|annexed Crimea]] in 2014. The Law provides a new definition of ownership which is closely connected to the exercise of a decisive influence in the management or business activity of the media outlet directly or through other persons and includes also [[final beneficiaries]]. The Law requires that information on the ownership structure and on the individuals owning at least 10% or more of a television or radio broadcasting have to be made public on the company's website and sent to the [[National Council for Questions of Television and Radio Broadcasting]], which is the national media regulator in Ukraine. According to the Law, the Council can impose fines when information provided are insufficient or incorrect. @@ -568,10 +568,10 @@ {{Europe topic|Freedom of the press in}} +{{Transparency of media ownership in Europe}} + {{DEFAULTSORT:Freedom Of The Press In Ukraine}} [[Category:Freedom of the press by country|Ukraine]] [[Category:Media in Ukraine]] [[Category:Human rights in Ukraine]] [[Category:Lists of journalists|Ukraine]] - -{{Transparency of media ownership in Europe}}

 |}
 
 == Attacks and threats against journalists ==
-Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0"/>  78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" /> In September 2016 [[Inter (TV channel)|Inter]] TV channel -often accused of being pro-Russia- was put to fire during a protest.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pro-Russia TV station in Kiev evacuated after fire|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/05/pro-russia-tv-inter-kiev-evacuated-fire-ukraine|accessdate=19 April 2017|work=The Guardian|date=5 September 2016}}</ref>
+Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0"/>  78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" /> In September 2016 [[Inter (TV channel)|Inter]] TV channel - often accused of being pro-Russia - was put to fire during a protest.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pro-Russia TV station in Kiev evacuated after fire|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/05/pro-russia-tv-inter-kiev-evacuated-fire-ukraine|accessdate=19 April 2017|work=The Guardian|date=5 September 2016}}</ref>
 
 [[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist Ruslan Kotsaba and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15 year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kiev struggles to find new fighters |publisher=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015}}</ref>|group = nb}}

changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -79,7 +79,7 @@ Freedom House reported the status of press freedom in [[Ukraine]] in 2015 as improving from Not Free to Partly Free. It justified the change as follows:[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine Ukraine 2015 Freedom of the Press] report
due to profound changes in the media environment after the fall of President Viktor Yanukovych’s government in February, despite a rise in attacks on journalists during the Euromaidan protests of early 2014 and the subsequent conflict in eastern Ukraine. The level of government hostility and legal pressure faced by journalists decreased, as did political pressure on state-owned outlets. The media also benefited from improvements to the law on access to information and the increased independence of the broadcasting regulator.

 A law on strengthening the protection of the ownership of [[mass media]] offices, [[publishing house]]s, bookshops and distributors, as well as [[creative unions]] was passed by the [[Ukrainian Parliament]] on 20 May 2010.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100523192802/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/67398/ Parliament bans forced removal of state and municipal mass media offices], [[Kyiv Post]] (21 May 2009)</ref>
 
 Since the February 2010 election of Viktor Yanukovych as President Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased.<ref name="sinceFeb2010" /> The [[International Press Institute]] addressed an open letter to President Yanukovych on 10 August 2010 urging him to address what the organisation saw as a disturbing deterioration in press freedom over the previous six months in Ukraine.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100811172630/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/ International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'signficiantly'], [[Kyiv Post]] (11 August 2010)</ref> [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] rapporteur [[Renate Wohlwend]] noticed on 6 October 2010 that "Some progress had been made in recent years but there had also been some retrograde steps".<ref name="PACE">[https://web.archive.org/web/20101007235843/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85208/ European rapporteurs note media setback in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (6 October 2010)</ref> In January 2011 [[Freedom House]] stated it had perceived "negative trends in Ukraine" during 2010; these included: curbs on press freedom, the intimidation of [[civil society]], and greater [[Government of Ukraine|government]] influence on the [[Judicial system of Ukraine|judiciary]].<ref name="negative trends 2010" />
 
-According to the [[US Department of State]] in 2009 there were no attempts by central authorities to direct media content, but there were reports of intimidation of journalists by national and local officials.<ref name="USDoS2009">[https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136063.htm 2009 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (March 11, 2010)</ref> Media at times demonstrated a tendency toward [[self‑censorship]] on matters that the government deemed sensitive.<ref name="USDoS2009" /><ref name="USDoS2008">[https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/eur/119110.htm 2008 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (February 25, 2009)</ref> Stories in the electronic and printed media (veiled advertisements and positive coverage presented as news) and participation in a television talk show can be bought.<ref name="USDoS2009" /> Media watchdog groups have express concern over the extremely high monetary damages that were demanded in [[Judicial system of Ukraine|court cases]] concerning [[libel]].<ref name="USDoS2009" />
+According to the [[US Department of State]] in 2009 there were no attempts by central authorities to direct media content, but there were reports of intimidation of journalists by national and local officials.<ref name="USDoS2009">[https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136063.htm 2009 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (11 March 2010)</ref> Media at times demonstrated a tendency toward [[self‑censorship]] on matters that the government deemed sensitive.<ref name="USDoS2009" /><ref name="USDoS2008">[https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/eur/119110.htm 2008 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (25 February 2009)</ref> Stories in the electronic and printed media (veiled advertisements and positive coverage presented as news) and participation in a television talk show can be bought.<ref name="USDoS2009" /> Media watchdog groups have express concern over the extremely high monetary damages that were demanded in [[Judicial system of Ukraine|court cases]] concerning [[libel]].<ref name="USDoS2009" />
 
 In 2013 there were concerns over the corrupting influence of certain political figures, connected to the government of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] on Ukrainian media.<ref>[http://www.businessinsider.com.au/understanding-euromaidan-2014-1 "A Ukrainian Explains 10 Things The West Needs To Know About The Situation In Kiev: #5 People find it hard to uncover the truth"], Taras Ilkiv, ''Business Insider'', 24 January 2014. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
 
 === Euromaidan revolution and Poroshenko presidency (2014) ===
 [[File:Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, Kyiv. Events of February 18, 2014..jpg|thumbnail|Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, [[Kiev]]. Events of February 18, 2014.]]
-A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = May 23, 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kiev (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. 
+A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = 23 May 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kiev (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. 
 In 2014 restrictions to press freedom in Ukraine included police impeding access to public buildings, physical attacks on press rooms, and cyberattacks (e.g. against the ''Glavnoe'', ''Gordon'' and [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] websites); in July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" />
 
 Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media.<ref name="FH" /> Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too.  In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication.<ref name="FH" />
 
-[[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kiev government.<ref name="FH" /> Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view.<ref name=":02" />  For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey “propaganda,” and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.<ref name=":02" /><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014.</ref><ref name="FH" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="hrw201705" /><ref name="hrw201705" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Two more Russian journalists denied entry to Ukraine|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1911158-two-more-russian-journalists-denied-entry-to-ukraine.html|date=2017-05-07}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for “violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity” brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].<ref name=":02">{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = September 21, 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper “Vesti”, physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website.  Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". “Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones.” Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = November 9, 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.<ref name="FH" />|group=nb}}
+[[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kiev government.<ref name="FH" /> Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view.<ref name=":02" />  For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey "propaganda," and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.<ref name=":02" /><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014.</ref><ref name="FH" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". "Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones." Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = 9 November 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.<ref name="FH" />|group=nb}}
 
 The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Information Policy]] was established on 2 December 2014.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="FLUYGIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)<br>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)<br>{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014)</ref> The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].<ref name="FLUYGIU21214" /><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)</ref> [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".<ref name="PPsbiU812">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)</ref>

 ===Literature===
-The Government of Ukraine started banning books in 2016 that a special committee (State Committee for State TV and Radio Broadcasting's licensing and distribution-control department) had determined to contain anti-Ukrainian content. In January 2018, the Russian version of British historian [[Antony Beevor]]'s ''[[Stalingrad (book)|Stalingrad]]'' was added to this list. The head of the committee, Serhiy Oliyinyk, told [[Radio Free Europe]] that one particular reason was that Beevor had included information about Ukrainian militia killing 90 Jewish children on orders of the SS "to save the feelings of the [[Sonderkommando]]." He claimed this had never been confirmed at post-war trials and was taken from Soviet sources. Beevor strongly criticized the ban and said the source was actually German resistance fighter [[Helmuth Groscurth]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/beevor-historian-ukraine-ban-stalingrad/28980932.html Historian Beevor 'Astonished' At Ukraine Ban On Best-Selling 'Stalingrad'], ''Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty</ref> "It’s utterly outrageous. They have no reason for doing it.  The lack of transparency on media ownership has typically been a negative trait of the [[Media of Ukraine|Ukrainian media system]]. In 2005 [[Ukraine]] committed itself to the [[Council of Europe]] to introduce a law for ensuring transparency of media ownership, according to the Resolution 1466 (2005)1 of the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]].<ref name=COE>{{cite web |url=http://www.coe.int/en/web/kyiv/-/transparency-media-ownership-in-ukraine-key-issue-at-the-international-conference-of-the-european-union-and-the-council-of-europe  |title=Transparency media ownership in Ukraine – key issue at the international conference of the European Union and the Council of Europe |date=11 June 2015 |website= Coe.int |publisher= Council of Europe. Office in Ukraine |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
 
-In 2014, the [[European Commission]]'s progress report on the implementation of the [[European Neighbourhood Policy]] in Ukraine found the lack of transparency as an issue in the country and that proper legislative framework should be adopted.<ref name=COE/> To comply with its international commitment, legislation on transparency of media ownership has been reformed in 2015. On September 10, 2015, President [[Petro Poroshenko]] signed the law called "On Amendments to Several Laws of Ukraine on Ensuring the Transparency of Media Ownership and Implementing the Principles of state Policy in the Sphere of Television and Radio Broadcasting". The law entered into force on 1 October 2015.<ref name=OSCE2015>{{cite web |url=http://www.osce.org/fom/187956  |title=OSCE Representative welcomes law on transparency of media ownership in Ukraine as it comes into force |date=1 October 2015 |website= Osce.org |publisher= Organisation for Security & Co-operation in Europe |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
+In 2014, the [[European Commission]]'s progress report on the implementation of the [[European Neighbourhood Policy]] in Ukraine found the lack of transparency as an issue in the country and that proper legislative framework should be adopted.<ref name=COE/> To comply with its international commitment, legislation on transparency of media ownership has been reformed in 2015. On 10 September 2015, President [[Petro Poroshenko]] signed the law called "On Amendments to Several Laws of Ukraine on Ensuring the Transparency of Media Ownership and Implementing the Principles of state Policy in the Sphere of Television and Radio Broadcasting". The law entered into force on 1 October 2015.<ref name=OSCE2015>{{cite web |url=http://www.osce.org/fom/187956  |title=OSCE Representative welcomes law on transparency of media ownership in Ukraine as it comes into force |date=1 October 2015 |website= Osce.org |publisher= Organisation for Security & Co-operation in Europe |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
 
 The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts <ref name=MOM>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website= Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher= Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev)}}</ref> but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries.<ref name=OSCE2015/> These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications.<ref name=MOM/> Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine.<ref name=OSCE2015/> Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners.<ref name=LOC>{{cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>

@@ -422,7 +422,7 @@
 == Attacks and threats against journalists ==
 Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0"/>  78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" /> In September 2016 [[Inter (TV channel)|Inter]] TV channel - often accused of being pro-Russia - was put to fire during a protest.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pro-Russia TV station in Kiev evacuated after fire|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/05/pro-russia-tv-inter-kiev-evacuated-fire-ukraine|accessdate=19 April 2017|work=The Guardian|date=5 September 2016}}</ref>
 
-[[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist Ruslan Kotsaba and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15 year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kiev struggles to find new fighters |publisher=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015}}</ref>|group = nb}}

If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15 year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kiev struggles to find new fighters |publisher=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015}}</ref>|group = nb}}
 
 The website [[Myrotvorets]] has published personal information about journalists.<ref name="ReichardtShutov" />

 In 2007, in Ukraine's provinces numerous, anonymous attacks<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900|title=Local newspaper editor badly injured in assault|publisher=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=31 March 2010|accessdate=4 October 2015|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001051756/http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900|archivedate=1 October 2015|df=dmy}}</ref> and threats persisted against journalists, who investigated or exposed corruption or other government misdeeds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-disturbing-deterioration-in-press-15-04-2010,37027.html|title=Disturbing deterioration in press freedom situation since new president took over|work=Reporters Without Borders|date=15 April 2010|accessdate=4 October 2015}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110120224057/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/64793/ Media crackdown under way?], [[Kyiv Post]] (22 April 2010)</ref> The US-based [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] concluded in 2007 that these attacks, and police reluctance in some cases to pursue the perpetrators, were "helping to foster an atmosphere of impunity against independent journalists."<ref name="HRW2007">{{cite web|url = http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|title = Ukraine: Events of 2006|work = Human Rights Watch|date = 2007|url-status = dead|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070116150453/http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|archive-date = 16 January 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.hrw.org/node/258888|title = Ukraine: Events of 2008|work = Human Rights Watch|accessdate = 3 October 2015}}</ref>
 
@@ -547,13 +547,13 @@
 
 In 2014, the [[European Commission]]'s progress report on the implementation of the [[European Neighbourhood Policy]] in Ukraine found the lack of transparency as an issue in the country and that proper legislative framework should be adopted.<ref name=COE/> To comply with its international commitment, legislation on transparency of media ownership has been reformed in 2015. On 10 September 2015, President [[Petro Poroshenko]] signed the law called "On Amendments to Several Laws of Ukraine on Ensuring the Transparency of Media Ownership and Implementing the Principles of state Policy in the Sphere of Television and Radio Broadcasting". The law entered into force on 1 October 2015.<ref name=OSCE2015>{{cite web |url=http://www.osce.org/fom/187956  |title=OSCE Representative welcomes law on transparency of media ownership in Ukraine as it comes into force |date=1 October 2015 |website= Osce.org |publisher= Organisation for Security & Co-operation in Europe |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
 
-The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts <ref name=MOM>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website= Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher= Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev)}}</ref> but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries.<ref name=OSCE2015/> These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications.<ref name=MOM/> Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine.<ref name=OSCE2015/> Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners.<ref name=LOC>{{cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
+The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts <ref name=MOM>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website=Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher=Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev) |access-date=12 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113165425/http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |archive-date=13 January 2017 |url-status=dead }}</ref> but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries.<ref name=OSCE2015/> These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications.<ref name=MOM/> Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine.<ref name=OSCE2015/> Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners.<ref name=LOC>{{cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
 
 Specifically, the new law amends article 12 of the existing Law of Ukraine on Television and Radio Broadcasting of 1994, establishing that national and local government authorities, individuals and legal entities which are registered offline, political parties, religious organisations, professional unions, and persons that were convicted by courts and that are still serving their sentences cannot be owners of a TV or radio stations in Ukraine. Furthermore, the Law prohibits to physical or legal persons residing in a country which is recognised as an aggressor or occupier the right to own a television or a radio station in Ukraine.<ref name=LOC/> This sentence refers to the [[Russia|Russian Federation]] which [[2014 Crimean status referendum|annexed Crimea]] in 2014.<ref name=LOC/> The Law provides a new definition of ownership which is closely connected to the exercise of a decisive influence in the management or business activity of the media outlet directly or through other persons and includes also [[final beneficiaries]].<ref name=LOC/> The Law requires that information on the ownership structure and on the individuals owning at least 10% or more of a television or radio broadcasting have to be made public on the company's website and sent to the [[National Council for Questions of Television and Radio Broadcasting]], which is the national media regulator in Ukraine. According to the Law, the Council can impose fines when information provided are insufficient or incorrect.<ref name=LOC/>
 
 According to some experts, one of the main weakness of the new law is that it does not exclude funding from financial sources located in [[Cyprus]] (even if it prohibits the transfer of funds from offshore territories), through which ownership of most Ukrainian TV channels is exercised. Among some commentators there are some doubts that the Law will be amended to address this issue, due to the strong lobbying efforts of TV owners.<ref name=LOC/> Other doubts have been voiced due to the lack of an effective sanctions system.<ref name="MOM" />
 
-In 2016, [[Reporters Without Borders]], together with the [[Institute of Mass Information]] (Kyev), launched the project [[Media Ownership Monitor Ukraine]] to promote transparency in media ownership and to map who owns and controls the media in Ukraine, by creating a public available and updated database listing the owners of the main media outlets, and detailing also the interests and the affilitations of owners into companies or political parties.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/about/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. About |date=2016 |website= Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher= Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev)}}</ref>
+In 2016, [[Reporters Without Borders]], together with the [[Institute of Mass Information]] (Kyev), launched the project [[Media Ownership Monitor Ukraine]] to promote transparency in media ownership and to map who owns and controls the media in Ukraine, by creating a public available and updated database listing the owners of the main media outlets, and detailing also the interests and the affilitations of owners into companies or political parties.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/about/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. About |date=2016 |website=Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher=Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev) |access-date=12 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113171717/http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/about/ |archive-date=13 January 2017 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

 ===Literature===
-The Government of Ukraine started banning books in 2016 that a special committee (State Committee for State TV and Radio Broadcasting's licensing and distribution-control department) had determined to contain anti-Ukrainian content. In January 2018, the Russian version of British historian [[Antony Beevor]]'s ''[[Stalingrad (book)|Stalingrad]]'' was added to this list. The head of the committee, Serhiy Oliyinyk, told [[Radio Free Europe]] that one particular reason was that Beevor had included information about Ukrainian militia killing 90 Jewish children on orders of the SS "to save the feelings of the [[Sonderkommando]]." He claimed this had never been confirmed at post-war trials and was taken from Soviet sources. Beevor strongly criticized the ban and said the source was actually German resistance fighter [[Helmuth Groscurth]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/beevor-historian-ukraine-ban-stalingrad/28980932.html Historian Beevor 'Astonished' At Ukraine Ban On Best-Selling 'Stalingrad'], Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty</ref> "It’s utterly outrageous. They have no reason for doing it. It’s quite clear both in the Russian edition and English edition what the source was and where it came from – this rather brave and religious officer [Groscurth] who protested strongly, despite threats he would be reported to Himmler … about this massacre of the children. There’s no way the Soviets would even have known about it."<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/jan/19/stalingrad-author-anthony-beevor-speaks-out-over-ukraine-book-ban Stalingrad author Anthony[sic] "Beevor speaks out over Ukraine book ban"], ''The Guardian''</ref> It was also strongly criticized by the Ukraine-based ''Human Rights in Ukraine''.<ref>[http://khpg.org/en/index.php?id=1516137187 "Ukraine imposes baffling ban on work by renowned English historian & others"], ''Human Rights in Ukraine''</ref>
+The Government of Ukraine started banning books in 2016 that a special committee (State Committee for State TV and Radio Broadcasting's licensing and distribution-control department) had determined to contain anti-Ukrainian content. 
+
+In January 2018, the Russian version of British historian [[Antony Beevor]]'s ''[[Stalingrad (book)|Stalingrad]]'' was added to this list. The head of the committee, Serhiy Oliyinyk, told [[Radio Free Europe]] that one particular reason was that Beevor had included information about Ukrainian militia killing 90 Jewish children on orders of the SS "to save the feelings of the [[Sonderkommando]]." He claimed this had never been confirmed at post-war trials and was taken from Soviet sources. Beevor strongly criticized the ban and said the source was actually German resistance fighter [[Helmuth Groscurth]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/beevor-historian-ukraine-ban-stalingrad/28980932.html Historian Beevor 'Astonished' At Ukraine Ban On Best-Selling 'Stalingrad'], Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty</ref> "It’s utterly outrageous. They have no reason for doing it. It’s quite clear both in the Russian edition and English edition what the source was and where it came from – this rather brave and religious officer [Groscurth] who protested strongly, despite threats he would be reported to Himmler … about this massacre of the children. There’s no way the Soviets would even have known about it."<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/jan/19/stalingrad-author-anthony-beevor-speaks-out-over-ukraine-book-ban Stalingrad author Anthony[sic] "Beevor speaks out over Ukraine book ban"], ''The Guardian''</ref> It was also strongly criticized by the Ukraine-based ''Human Rights in Ukraine''.<ref>[http://khpg.org/en/index.php?id=1516137187 "Ukraine imposes baffling ban on work by renowned English historian & others"], ''Human Rights in Ukraine''</ref>
 
 == Internet censorship and surveillance ==
 {{Main|Internet in Ukraine#Internet censorship and surveillance}}In December 2010 the [[OpenNet Initiative]] found little or no evidence of Internet filtering in all four areas (political, social, conflict/security, and Internet tools) for which they test.<ref name="ONI-UkraineProfile-Dec2010">[http://opennet.net/research/profiles/ukraine "ONI Country Profile: Ukraine"], OpenNet Initiative, 21 December 2010</ref>

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The content discusses a specific action taken by the Ukrainian government regarding literature, but it does not employ weaponisation terms or narratives that frame the situation in a way that promotes conflict or cultural oppression.

2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }} The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper "Vesti", physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". "Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones." Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = 9 November 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.|group=nb}} -The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Information Policy]] was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)

 According to some experts, one of the main weakness of the new law is that it does not exclude funding from financial sources located in [[Cyprus]] (even if it prohibits the transfer of funds from offshore territories), through which ownership of most Ukrainian TV channels is exercised. changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -421,7 +421,7 @@
 == Attacks and threats against journalists ==
 Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0"/>  78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" /> In September 2016 [[Inter (TV channel)|Inter]] TV channel - often accused of being pro-Russia - was put to fire during a protest.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pro-Russia TV station in Kyiv evacuated after fire|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/05/pro-russia-tv-inter-kiev-evacuated-fire-ukraine|accessdate=19 April 2017|work=The Guardian|date=5 September 2016}}</ref>
 
-[[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}} and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15 year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kyiv struggles to find new fighters |publisher=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015}}</ref>|group = nb}}
+[[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}} and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15 year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kyiv struggles to find new fighters |work=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015}}</ref>|group = nb}}
 
 The website [[Myrotvorets]] has published personal information about journalists.<ref name="ReichardtShutov" />
