changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -482,7 +482,7 @@
 ===Literature===
 The Government of Ukraine started banning books in 2016 that a special committee (State Committee for State TV and Radio Broadcasting's licensing and distribution-control department) had determined to contain anti-Ukrainian content. 
 
-In January 2018, the Russian version of British historian [[Antony Beevor]]'s ''[[Stalingrad (book)|Stalingrad]]'' was added to this list. The head of the committee, Serhiy Oliyinyk, told [[Radio Free Europe]] that one particular reason was that Beevor had included information about Ukrainian militia killing 90 Jewish children on orders of the SS "to save the feelings of the [[Sonderkommando]]." He claimed this had never been confirmed at post-war trials and was taken from Soviet sources. Beevor strongly criticized the ban and said the source was actually German resistance fighter [[Helmuth Groscurth]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/beevor-historian-ukraine-ban-stalingrad/28980932.html Historian Beevor 'Astonished' At Ukraine Ban On Best-Selling 'Stalingrad'], Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty</ref> "It’s utterly outrageous. They have no reason for doing it. It’s quite clear both in the Russian edition and English edition what the source was and where it came from – this rather brave and religious officer [Groscurth] who protested strongly, despite threats he would be reported to Himmler … about this massacre of the children. There’s no way the Soviets would even have known about it."<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/jan/19/stalingrad-author-anthony-beevor-speaks-out-over-ukraine-book-ban Stalingrad author Anthony[sic] "Beevor speaks out over Ukraine book ban"], ''The Guardian''</ref> It was also strongly criticized by the Ukraine-based ''Human Rights in Ukraine''.<ref>[http://khpg.org/en/index.php?id=1516137187 "Ukraine imposes baffling ban on work by renowned English historian & others"], ''Human Rights in Ukraine''</ref>
+In January 2018, the Russian version of British historian [[Antony Beevor]]'s ''[[Stalingrad (Beevor book)|Stalingrad]]'' was added to this list. The head of the committee, Serhiy Oliyinyk, told [[Radio Free Europe]] that one particular reason was that Beevor had included information about Ukrainian militia killing 90 Jewish children on orders of the SS "to save the feelings of the [[Sonderkommando]]." He claimed this had never been confirmed at post-war trials and was taken from Soviet sources. Beevor strongly criticized the ban and said the source was actually German resistance fighter [[Helmuth Groscurth]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/beevor-historian-ukraine-ban-stalingrad/28980932.html Historian Beevor 'Astonished' At Ukraine Ban On Best-Selling 'Stalingrad'], Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty</ref> "It’s utterly outrageous. They have no reason for doing it. It’s quite clear both in the Russian edition and English edition what the source was and where it came from – this rather brave and religious officer [Groscurth] who protested strongly, despite threats he would be reported to Himmler … about this massacre of the children. There’s no way the Soviets would even have known about it."<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/jan/19/stalingrad-author-anthony-beevor-speaks-out-over-ukraine-book-ban Stalingrad author Anthony[sic] "Beevor speaks out over Ukraine book ban"], ''The Guardian''</ref> It was also strongly criticized by the Ukraine-based ''Human Rights in Ukraine''.<ref>[http://khpg.org/en/index.php?id=1516137187 "Ukraine imposes baffling ban on work by renowned English historian & others"], ''Human Rights in Ukraine''</ref>
 
 == Internet censorship and surveillance ==
 {{Main|Internet in Ukraine#Internet censorship and surveillance}}In December 2010 the [[OpenNet Initiative]] found little or no evidence of Internet filtering in all four areas (political, social, conflict/security, and Internet tools) for which they test.<ref name="ONI-UkraineProfile-Dec2010">[http://opennet.net/research/profiles/ukraine "ONI Country Profile: Ukraine"], OpenNet Initiative, 21 December 2010</ref>

changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -12,7 +12,7 @@ The Ukrainian legal framework on media freedom is deemed "among the most progressive in eastern Europe", although implementation has been uneven. The [[Constitution of Ukraine]] and a 1991 law provide for freedom of speech.[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/1999/367.htm 1999 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (23 February 2000) -Many Ukrainian journalists found themselves internally displaced due to the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]] and the [[war in Donbass]], including Donetsk-based investigative journalist Oleksiy Matsuka, Luhansk blogger Serhiy Ivanov and Donetsk ''Ostrov'' independent website editor Serhiy Harmash. The entire staff of ''Ostrov'' left the occupied Donbass areas and relocated to Kiev. +Many Ukrainian journalists found themselves internally displaced due to the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]] and the [[war in Donbass]], including Donetsk-based investigative journalist Oleksiy Matsuka, Luhansk blogger Serhiy Ivanov and Donetsk ''Ostrov'' independent website editor Serhiy Harmash. Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kyiv (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In 2014 restrictions to press freedom in Ukraine included police impeding access to public buildings, physical attacks on press rooms, and cyberattacks (e.g. against the ''Glavnoe'', ''Gordon'' and [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] websites); in July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''. Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media. Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too. On 12 May 2010, the [[Ukrainian Parliament|parliamentary]] committee for freedom of speech and information called on the [[General Prosecutor of Ukraine|General Prosecutor]]'s Office to immediately investigate complaints by journalists of pressure on journalists and censorship.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110606044759/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66628/ Special committee calls to check reports of pressure on journalists], [[Kyiv Post]] (13 May 2009)</ref> Also in May 2010 the Stop Censorship movement was founded by more than 500 journalist.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Paschyn|first1=Christina Maria|title=Ukraine: Journalists Face Uncertain Future|url=http://pulitzercenter.org/reporting/ukraine-journalists-face-uncertain-future|accessdate=21 April @@ -67,11 +67,11 @@
 A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = 23 May 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kiev (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. 
 In 2014 restrictions to press freedom in Ukraine included police impeding access to public buildings, physical attacks on press rooms, and cyberattacks (e.g. against the ''Glavnoe'', ''Gordon'' and [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] websites); in July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" />
 
-Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media.<ref name="FH" /> Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too.  In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication.<ref name="FH" />
+Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media.<ref name="FH" /> Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too.  In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication.<ref name="FH" />
 
 [[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kiev government.<ref name="FH" /> Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view.<ref name=":02" />  For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey "propaganda," and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.<ref name=":02" /><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014.</ref><ref name="FH" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |accessdate=28 Ukraine|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1911158-two-more-russian-journalists-denied-entry-to-ukraine.html|date=2017-05-07}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for "violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity" brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].<ref name=":02">{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = 21 September 2014|accessdate = |website = The Christian Science Monitor|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a Kiev-based digital newspaper "Vesti", physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website.  Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". "Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones." Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = 9 November 2014|accessdate = |website = Huff Post Media|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.<ref name="FH" />|group=nb}}
 
-The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Information Policy]] was established on 2 December 2014.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="FLUYGIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)<br>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)<br>{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014)</ref> The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].<ref name="FLUYGIU21214" /><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)</ref> [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".<ref name="PPsbiU812">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)</ref>
+The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Information Policy]] was established on 2 December 2014.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="FLUYGIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)<br />[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)<br />{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014)</ref> The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].<ref name="FLUYGIU21214" /><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)</ref> [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".<ref name="PPsbiU812">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)</ref>
 
 On 16 May 2017 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning various Russian internet service providers and news sources, among others, [[VK (social networking)|VKontakte]], [[Odnoklassniki]], [[Yandex]], [[Rossiya Segodnya]], [[RBC Information Systems|RBC]], [[All-Russia State Television and Radio Broadcasting Company|VGTRK]], but also a number of independent stations such as the RBC, claiming this was done for "security reasons".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/421954.html|title=All of Ukrainian president's official pages on Russian social media sites being closed|work=Interfax-Ukraine|access-date=2017-05-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/ukraine-bans-dozens-of-russian-websites/3852930.html|title=Ukraine Bans Dozens of Russian Websites|last=News|first=VOA|work=VOA|access-date=2017-05-16|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rt.com/business/388502-ukraine-bans-vk-yandex/|title=Ukraine bans most popular social networks because they are Russian-owned|work=RT International|access-date=2017-05-16|language=en-US}}</ref> Tanya Cooper from [[Human Rights Watch]] called the decree: "a cynical, politically expedient attack on the right to information affecting millions of Ukrainians, and their personal and professional lives".<ref name="hrw201705">{{cite web|title=Ukraine: Revoke Ban on Dozens of Russian Web Companies|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/05/16/ukraine-revoke-ban-dozens-russian-web-companies|date=2017-05-15}}</ref> [[Reporters Without Borders]] (RSF) also condemned the ban imposed on Russian social networks.<ref name="rsf201705">{{cite web|title=RSF urges Ukraine to scrap ban on Russian social media sites |publisher=Reporters without borders |url=https://rsf.org/en/news/rsf-urges-ukraine-scrap-ban-russian-social-media-sites |date=23 May 2017 |accessdate=26 October 2017}}</ref></ref>
 
@@ -480,7 +480,7 @@
 The Government of Ukraine started banning books in 2016 that a special committee (State Committee for State TV and Radio Broadcasting's licensing and distribution-control department) had determined to contain anti-Ukrainian content. In January 2018, the Russian version of British historian [[Antony Beevor]]'s ''[[Stalingrad (book)|Stalingrad]]'' was added to this list. The head of the committee, Serhiy Oliyinyk, told [[Radio Free Europe]] that one particular reason was that Beevor had included information about Ukrainian militia killing 90 Jewish children on orders of the SS "to save the feelings of the [[Sonderkommando]]." He claimed this had never been confirmed at post-war trials and was taken from Soviet sources. Beevor strongly criticized the ban and said the source was actually German resistance fighter [[Helmuth Groscurth]].<ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/beevor-historian-ukraine-ban-stalingrad/28980932.html Historian Beevor 'Astonished' At Ukraine Ban On Best-Selling 'Stalingrad'], Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty</ref> "It’s utterly outrageous. They have no reason for doing it. It’s quite clear both in the Russian edition and English edition what the source was and where it came from – this rather brave and religious officer [Groscurth] who protested strongly, despite threats he would be reported to Himmler … about this massacre of the children. There’s no way the Soviets would even have known about it."<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/jan/19/stalingrad-author-anthony-beevor-speaks-out-over-ukraine-book-ban Stalingrad author Anthony[sic] "Beevor speaks out over Ukraine book ban"], ''The Guardian''</ref> It was also strongly criticized by the Ukraine-based ''Human Rights in Ukraine''.<ref>[http://khpg.org/en/index.php?id=1516137187 "Ukraine imposes baffling ban on work by renowned English historian & others"], ''Human Rights in Ukraine''</ref>
 
 == Internet censorship and surveillance ==

+{{Main|Internet in Ukraine#Internet censorship and surveillance}}In December 2010 the [[OpenNet Initiative]] found little or no evidence of Internet filtering in all four areas (political, social, conflict/security, and Internet tools) for which they test.<ref name="ONI-UkraineProfile-Dec2010">[http://opennet.net/research/profiles/ukraine "ONI Country Profile: Ukraine"], OpenNet Initiative, 21 December 2010</ref>
 
 In its ''Freedom on the Net'' report covering the period May 2012 through April 2013, [[Freedom House]] found the Internet in Ukraine to be "largely unhindered" and rated the Internet in Ukraine as "Free" with an overall score of 28 on a scale from 0 (most free) to 100 (least free). The report said that "there is no practice of institutionalized blocking or filtering, or a regulatory framework for censorship of content online", but "there have been attempts at creating legislation which could censor or limit content" and would "present indirect threats to freedom of information online."<ref name="FOTN-Ukraine-2013">[http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-net/2013/ukraine#.UvJZil6togE "Ukraine"], ''Freedom on the Net 2013'', Freedom House, 30 September 2013. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
 
@@ -524,7 +524,7 @@
 
 === Repression of Crimean Tatar media ===
 [[Crimean Tatars|Crimean Tatar]] media were particularly targeted by Russian repression.  [[ATR (TV channel)|ATR]], ''Avdet'' and the QHA news agency remained among the last independent media operating in Crimea by the end of 2014.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
-* In June 2014 Shevket Kaybullayev, editor of the ''Avdet'' newspaper, was questioned and warned by the prosecutor over "extremist contents" due to the paper's coverage of an opposition activities and the use of the term "occupation". In September 2014 the premises of the ''Avdet'' newspaper were raided and searched  by unidentified security forces, without a warrant. The newspaper was closed down and its bank accounts seized. Kaybullayev was officially warned that he would be prosecuted and risked up to 5 years in jail if ''Avdet'' had continued reporting on calls for a boycott of the [[Crimean legislative election, 2014]].<ref name=FHcrimea/>
+* In June 2014 Shevket Kaybullayev, editor of the ''Avdet'' newspaper, was questioned and warned by the prosecutor over "extremist contents" due to the paper's coverage of an opposition activities and the use of the term "occupation". In September 2014 the premises of the ''Avdet'' newspaper were raided and searched  by unidentified security forces, without a warrant. The newspaper was closed down and its bank accounts seized. Kaybullayev was officially warned that he would be prosecuted and risked up to 5 years in jail if ''Avdet'' had continued reporting on calls for a boycott of the [[2014 Crimean legislative election]].<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 * The Crimean Tatar TV channel [[ATR (TV channel)|ATR]] received a warning in May 2015 after covering a Tatar protest. It was subject to an inspection in September 2014 by the Interior Ministry, as suspect of inciting "extremism" and "distrust towards the authorities". KGB agents regularly called the station and applied pressures, threatening it with closure.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 
 == Situation in the occupied regions of Donetsk and Luhansk ==
@@ -547,7 +547,7 @@
 
 The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts <ref name=MOM>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website= Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher= Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev)}}</ref> but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries.<ref name=OSCE2015/> These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications.<ref name=MOM/> Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine.<ref name=OSCE2015/> Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners.<ref name=LOC>{{cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
 
-Specifically, the new law amends article 12 of the existing Law of Ukraine on Television and Radio Broadcasting of 1994, establishing that national and local government authorities, individuals and legal entities which are registered offline, political parties, religious organisations, professional unions, and persons that were convicted by courts and that are still serving their sentences cannot be owners of a TV or radio stations in Ukraine. Furthermore, the Law prohibits to physical or legal persons residing in a country which is recognised as an aggressor or occupier the right to own a television or a radio station in Ukraine.<ref name=LOC/> This sentence refers to the [[Russia|Russian Federation]] which [[Crimean status referendum, 2014|annexed Crimea]] in 2014.<ref name=LOC/> The Law provides a new definition of ownership which is closely connected to the exercise of a decisive influence in the management or business activity of the media outlet directly or through other persons and includes also [[final beneficiaries]].<ref name=LOC/> The Law requires that information on the ownership structure and on the individuals owning at least 10% or more of a television or radio broadcasting have to be made public on the company's website and sent to the [[National Council for Questions of Television and Radio Broadcasting]], which is the national media regulator in Ukraine. According to the Law, the Council can impose fines when information provided are insufficient or incorrect.<ref name=LOC/>
+Specifically, the new law amends article 12 of the existing Law of Ukraine on Television and Radio Broadcasting of 1994, establishing that national and local government authorities, individuals and legal entities which are registered offline, political parties, religious organisations, professional unions, and persons that were convicted by courts and that are still serving their sentences cannot be owners of a TV or radio stations in Ukraine. Furthermore, the Law prohibits to physical or legal persons residing in a country which is recognised as an aggressor or occupier the right to own a television or a radio station in Ukraine.<ref name=LOC/> This sentence refers to the [[Russia|Russian Federation]] which [[2014 Crimean status referendum|annexed Crimea]] in 2014.<ref name=LOC/> The Law provides a new definition of ownership which is closely connected to the exercise of a decisive influence in the management or business activity of the media outlet directly or through other persons and includes also [[final beneficiaries]].<ref name=LOC/> The Law requires that information on the ownership structure and on the individuals owning at least 10% or more of a television or radio broadcasting have to be made public on the company's website and sent to the [[National Council for Questions of Television and Radio Broadcasting]], which is the national media regulator in Ukraine. According to the Law, the Council can impose fines when information provided are insufficient or incorrect.<ref name=LOC/>
 
 According to some experts, one of the main weakness of the new law is that it does not exclude funding from financial sources located in [[Cyprus]] (even if it prohibits the transfer of funds from offshore territories), through which ownership of most Ukrainian TV channels is exercised. Among some commentators there are some doubts that the Law will be amended to address this issue, due to the strong lobbying efforts of TV owners.<ref name=LOC/> Other doubts have been voiced due to the lack of an effective sanctions system.<ref name="MOM" />

The change made is the addition of a sentence: "However, in 2010 and again in 2021 Freedom House perceived 'negative trends in Ukraine'." 

Weaponised. The phrase "negative trends in Ukraine" can imply a critical perspective on Ukraine's governance and media freedom, which may be used to support narratives that undermine Ukraine's sovereignty or legitimacy, especially in the context of ongoing geopolitical tensions.

--- +++ @@ -66,12 +66,12 @@ === Euromaidan revolution and Poroshenko presidency (2014) === [[File:Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, Kyiv. Events of February 18, 2014..jpg|thumbnail|Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, [[Kyiv]]. Events of February 18, 2014.]] -A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.{{cite web|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = 23 May 2014|website = Reuters}} The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kyiv (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. +A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.{{cite web|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = 23 May 2014|website = Reuters}} The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kyiv (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In 2014 restrictions to press freedom in Ukraine included police impeding access to public buildings, physical attacks on press rooms, and cyberattacks (e.g. against the ''Glavnoe'', ''Gordon'' and [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] websites); in July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''. Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media. Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too. In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication. -[[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kyiv government. Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view. For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey "propaganda," and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/19/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014.{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|access-date=17 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|access-date=17 September 2015}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |access-date=28 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Two more Russian journalists denied entry to Ukraine|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1911158-two-more-russian-journalists-denied-entry-to-ukraine.html|date=2017-05-07}}{{#tag:ref|On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for "violating Ukraine’s territorial integrity" brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = 21 September 2014|website = The Christian Science Monitor}} The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a [[Kyiv]]-based digital newspaper "Vesti", physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". "Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones." Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = 9 November 2014|website = Huff Post Media}} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.|group=nb}} +[[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kyiv government. Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view. For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey "propaganda," and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". "Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones." Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break Into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = 9 November 2014|website = Huff Post Media}} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.|group=nb}} The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Information Policy]] was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | access-date=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)
{{in lang|uk}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)

+++ 
@@ -16,7 +16,7 @@
 Many Ukrainian journalists found themselves internally displaced due to the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]] and the [[war in Donbass]], including Donetsk-based investigative journalist Oleksiy Matsuka, Luhansk blogger Serhiy Ivanov and Donetsk ''Ostrov'' independent website editor Serhiy Harmash. The entire staff of ''Ostrov'' left the occupied Donbass areas and relocated to Kyiv.<ref name=FH/>
 
 ==History==
-[[File:RWB-PressFreedomIndex-WorldMap.svg|400px|thumb|right|'''2014 [[Press Freedom Index]]'''<ref name=RWBPFIndex>{{cite web|url=https://rsf.org/en/ranking/2014|title=World Press Freedom Index 2014|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|accessdate=11 May 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140214120404/http://rsf.org/index2014/en-index2014.php|archivedate=14 February 2014}}</ref>
+[[File:RWB-PressFreedomIndex-WorldMap.svg|400px|thumb|right|'''2014 [[Press Freedom Index]]'''<ref name=RWBPFIndex>{{cite web|url=https://rsf.org/en/ranking/2014|title=World Press Freedom Index 2014|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|access-date=11 May 2014|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140214120404/http://rsf.org/index2014/en-index2014.php|archive-date=14 February 2014}}</ref>
 {{columns|width=auto
 |col1=
 {{legend|#F9D|Very serious situation}}

 {{legend|#e0e0e0|Not classified / No data}}
 }}
 Ukraine moved its class without noticeable borders to say the least at in the form of editing its place to do so from "noticeable problems" (89th place) in 2009 to "difficult situation" (127th place) in 2014 in the [[Press Freedom Index]] by [[Reporters Without Borders]].]]
-The ''[[Freedom in the World]]'' report by [[Freedom House]] rated Ukraine "partly free" from 1992<ref name="Kuchma" /> until 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2003?page=251&year=2003|title=Freedom of the Press 2003|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2003|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> After 2005, it was rated "partly free" again.<ref name="RFH2010">{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2010?page=251&year=2010|title=Freedom of the Press 2010|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="RFH2009">{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2009?page=251&year=2009|title=Freedom of the Press 2009|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2009|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> According to Freedom House [[internet in Ukraine]] is "Free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] is "Partly Free".<ref name="FHUkraine" />{{clarify|date=June 2017|reason=Convoluted. Is it the media or the country being qualified as 'free' and/or 'partly free'? Are civil liberties/human rights and press freedom being conflated?}}
-
-Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]s' [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2009|work=rsf.org|date=2009|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091022183400/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|archive-date=22 October 2009}}</ref> 87 in 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2008|work=rsf.org|date=2008|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607100340/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|archive-date=7 June 2009}}</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2002|work=rsf.org|date=October 2002|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703081345/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|archive-date=3 July 2009}}</ref> and even the 132nd spot in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2004|work=rsf.org|date=2004|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905174452/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|archivedate=5 September 2009}}</ref> In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[2010 Ukrainian presidential election|Viktor Yanukovych's election as president in February]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2010|work=rsf.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124050702/http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|archivedate=24 November 2010|df=dmy}}</ref> In 2013 Ukraine occupied the 126th spot (dropping 10 places compared with 2012); (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|title=Press Freedom Index 2013|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|accessdate=29 September 2015|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151013163532/http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|archivedate=13 October 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In the 2017 World Press Freedom Index Ukraine was placed 102nd.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://rsf.org/en/ranking|title=2017 World Press Freedom Index {{!}} Reporters Without Borders|work=RSF|access-date=2017-12-09|language=en}}</ref>
-
-During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and southeastern regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/half-of-all-ukrainians-consider-current-freedom-of-50721.html|title=Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=15 October 2009|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>
-
-In a late 2010 poll also conducted by the Research & Branding Group 56% of all Ukrainians trusted the media and 38.5% didn't.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/|title=Poll: More than half of Ukrainians trust the media|publisher=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=17 December 2010|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110120213543/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/|archivedate=20 January 2011}}</ref>
+The ''[[Freedom in the World]]'' report by [[Freedom House]] rated Ukraine "partly free" from 1992<ref name="Kuchma" /> until 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2003?page=251&year=2003|title=Freedom of the Press 2003|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2003|access-date=28 September 2015}}</ref> After 2005, it was rated "partly free" again.<ref name="RFH2010">{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2010?page=251&year=2010|title=Freedom of the Press 2010|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2010|access-date=28 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="RFH2009">{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2009?page=251&year=2009|title=Freedom of the Press 2009|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2009|access-date=28 September 2015}}</ref> According to Freedom House [[internet in Ukraine]] is "Free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] is "Partly Free".<ref name="FHUkraine" />{{clarify|date=June 2017|reason=Convoluted. Is it the media or the country being qualified as 'free' and/or 'partly free'? Are civil liberties/human rights and press freedom being conflated?}}
+
+Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]s' [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2009|work=rsf.org|date=2009|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091022183400/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|archive-date=22 October 2009}}</ref> 87 in 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2008|work=rsf.org|date=2008|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607100340/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|archive-date=7 June 2009}}</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2002|work=rsf.org|date=October 2002|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703081345/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|archive-date=3 July 2009}}</ref> and even the 132nd spot in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2004|work=rsf.org|date=2004|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905174452/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|archive-date=5 September 2009}}</ref> In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[2010 Ukrainian presidential election|Viktor Yanukovych's election as president in February]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2010|work=rsf.org|date=2010|access-date=28 September 2015|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124050702/http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|archive-date=24 November 2010|df=dmy}}</ref> In 2013 Ukraine occupied the 126th spot (dropping 10 places compared with 2012); (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|title=Press Freedom Index 2013|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|access-date=29 September 2015|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151013163532/http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|archive-date=13 October 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In the 2017 World Press Freedom Index Ukraine was placed 102nd.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://rsf.org/en/ranking|title=2017 World Press Freedom Index {{!}} Reporters Without Borders|work=RSF|access-date=2017-12-09|language=en}}</ref>
+
+During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and southeastern regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/half-of-all-ukrainians-consider-current-freedom-of-50721.html|title=Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=15 October 2009|access-date=29 September 2015}}</ref>
+
+In a late 2010 poll also conducted by the Research & Branding Group 56% of all Ukrainians trusted the media and 38.5% didn't.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/|title=Poll: More than half of Ukrainians trust the media|publisher=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=17 December 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110120213543/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/|archive-date=20 January 2011}}</ref>
 
 === Kuchma presidencies (1994-2004) ===
 [[File:Georgi gongadse.jpg|thumbnail|[[Georgiy Gongadze]], [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] journalist, founder of a popular Internet newspaper [[Ukrayinska Pravda]], who was kidnapped and murdered in 2000.]]
 
-After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref name="HayozLushnycky2005">{{cite book|last1=Hayoz|first1=Nicolas|last2=Lushnycky|first2=Andrej N.|editor1=Nicolas Hayoz|editor2=Andrej N. Lushnycky|title=Ukraine at a Crossroads|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC|accessdate=19 June 2017|year=2005|publisher=[[Peter Lang (publisher)|Peter Lang]]|isbn=978-3-03910-468-0|page=21|chapter=Prologue: Ukraine's New Deal}}</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name="Kuchma" /> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemies of the press.<ref name="Kuchma">{{cite book|editor1=Adrian Karatnycky|editor2=Alexander J. Motyl|editor2-link=Alexander J. Motyl|editor3=Amanda Schnetzer|title=Nations in Transit, 2001: Civil Society, Democracy, and Markets in East Central Europe and the Newly Independent States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397|year=2001|publisher=[[Transaction Publishers]]|isbn=978-0-7658-0897-4|page=397}}</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|title=Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=11 March 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905041903/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|archivedate=5 September 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (12 March 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name="USDoS1999" /> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name="USDoS2003" /><ref name="USDoS2004" /> Toward the very end of the [[2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name="USDoS2004" />
+After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref name="HayozLushnycky2005">{{cite book|last1=Hayoz|first1=Nicolas|last2=Lushnycky|first2=Andrej N.|editor1=Nicolas Hayoz|editor2=Andrej N. Lushnycky|title=Ukraine at a Crossroads|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC|access-date=19 June 2017|year=2005|publisher=[[Peter Lang (publisher)|Peter Lang]]|isbn=978-3-03910-468-0|page=21|chapter=Prologue: Ukraine's New Deal}}</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name="Kuchma" /> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemies of the press.<ref name="Kuchma">{{cite book|editor1=Adrian Karatnycky|editor2=Alexander J. Motyl|editor2-link=Alexander J. Motyl|editor3=Amanda Schnetzer|title=Nations in Transit, 2001: Civil Society, Democracy, and Markets in East Central Europe and the Newly Independent States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397|year=2001|publisher=[[Transaction Publishers]]|isbn=978-0-7658-0897-4|page=397}}</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|title=Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=11 March 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905041903/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|archive-date=5 September 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (12 March 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name="USDoS1999" /> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name="USDoS2003" /><ref name="USDoS2004" /> Toward the very end of the [[2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name="USDoS2004" />
 
 === Orange revolution and Yushchenko presidency (2004-2010) ===
 Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media has become more pluralistic and independent.<ref name="FHouse2007" /><ref name="organge">[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (28 April 2006 )</ref><ref name="USDoS2007">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (6 March 2007)</ref> For instance, attempts by authorities to limit freedom of the press through tax inspections have ceased.<ref name="USDoS2003">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (25 February 2004)</ref><ref name="USDoS2004">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (28 February 2005)</ref><ref name="USDoS2000">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (23 February 2001)</ref><ref name="USDoS2001">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (4 March 2002)</ref><ref name="USDoS2002">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (31 March 2003)</ref><ref name="USDoS2005">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (8 March 2006)</ref> Since then the Ukrainian press is considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]] (only the [[Baltic states]] are considered "free").<ref name="RFH2009" /><ref name=PoSoStatN1>[https://books.google.com/books?id=1CcQj3DjrHAC&pg=PA39&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=-Jd1TOTTJOGkOJzD5KwG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CFsQ6AEwBzge#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Ukraine (Country Guide)] by [[Sarah Johnstone]] and [[Greg Bloom]], [[Lonely Planet]], 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-74104-481-2}} (page 39)</ref><ref name="FHouse2007" />
 
 After the 2005 [[Orange Revolution]], Ukrainian television became more free.<ref>[http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160911232022/http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews |date=11 September 2016 }} [tt_news]=30800 UKRAINIAN PARTIES SCRAMBLE FOR MEDIA, FOREIGN ALLIES, AHEAD OF PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS], [[The Jamestown Foundation]] (17 August 2005)</ref> In February 2009 the National Council for Television and Radio Broadcasting claimed that "political pressure on mass media increased in recent times through amending laws and other normative acts to strengthen influence on mass media and regulatory bodies in this sphere".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/179018.html|title=National TV Council Claims Harder Political Pressure On Mass Media|publisher=[[Ukrainian News Agency]]|date=6 February 2009}}{{dead link|date=April 2017}}{{cbignore}}</ref>
 
-In 2007, in Ukraine's provinces numerous, anonymous attacks<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900|title=Local newspaper editor badly injured in assault|publisher=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=31 March 2010|accessdate=4 October 2015|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001051756/http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900|archivedate=1 October 2015|df=dmy}}</ref> and threats persisted against journalists, who investigated or exposed corruption or other government misdeeds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-disturbing-deterioration-in-press-15-04-2010,37027.html|title=Disturbing deterioration in press freedom situation since new president took over|work=Reporters Without Borders|date=15 April 2010|accessdate=4 October 2015}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110120224057/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/64793/ Media crackdown under way?], [[Kyiv Post]] (22 April 2010)</ref> The US-based [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] concluded in 2007 that these attacks, and police reluctance in some cases to pursue the perpetrators, were "helping to foster an atmosphere of impunity against independent journalists."<ref name="HRW2007">{{cite web|url = http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|title = Ukraine: Events of 2006|work = Human Rights Watch|date = 2007|url-status = dead|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070116150453/http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|archive-date = 16 January 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.hrw.org/node/258888|title = Ukraine: Events of 2008|work = Human Rights Watch|accessdate = 3 October 2015}}</ref>
+In 2007, in Ukraine's provinces numerous, anonymous attacks<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900|title=Local newspaper editor badly injured in assault|publisher=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=31 March 2010|access-date=4 October 2015|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001051756/http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900|archive-date=1 October 2015|df=dmy}}</ref> and threats persisted against journalists, who investigated or exposed corruption or other government misdeeds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-disturbing-deterioration-in-press-15-04-2010,37027.html|title=Disturbing deterioration in press freedom situation since new president took over|work=Reporters Without Borders|date=15 April 2010|access-date=4 October 2015}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110120224057/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/64793/ Media crackdown under way?], [[Kyiv Post]] (22 April 2010)</ref> The US-based [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] concluded in 2007 that these attacks, and police reluctance in some cases to pursue the perpetrators, were "helping to foster an atmosphere of impunity against independent journalists."<ref name="HRW2007">{{cite web|url = http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|title = Ukraine: Events of 2006|work = Human Rights Watch|date = 2007|url-status = dead|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070116150453/http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|archive-date = 16 January 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.hrw.org/node/258888|title = Ukraine: Events of 2008|work = Human Rights Watch|access-date = 3 October 2015}}</ref>
 
 In Ukraine's provinces numerous, anonymous attacks<ref name="USDoS2007" /><ref name="USDoS2009" /><ref name="USDoS2008" /><ref>[http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900 Local newspaper editor badly injured in assault] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001051756/http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900 |date=1 October 2015 }}, [[Reporters Without Borders]] (31 March 2010)</ref> and threats persisted against journalists, who investigated or exposed corruption or other government misdeeds.<ref>[http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-disturbing-deterioration-in-press-15-04-2010,37027.html Disturbing deterioration in press freedom situation since new president took over], [[Reporters Without Borders]] (15 April 2010)</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100424113640/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/64793/ Media crackdown under way?], [[Kyiv Post]] (22 April 2010)</ref> The US-based [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] concluded in 2007 that these attacks, and police reluctance in some cases to pursue the perpetrators, were "helping to foster an atmosphere of impunity against independent journalists."<ref name="hrw.org">{{cite web|url=http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|title=Ukraine: Events of 2006|work=hrw.org|date=2007|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070704194735/http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|archive-date=4 July 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/en/node/79345|title=Ukraine:Events of 2008|work=hrw.org|url-status=dead|date=2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090117073609/http://www.hrw.org/en/node/79345|archive-date=17 January 2009}}</ref> Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased since the [[2010 Ukrainian presidential election|February 2010 election]] of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] as [[Ukrainian President|President]].<ref name="sinceFeb2010">[http://www.rferl.org/content/Concerns_Mount_About_Press_Freedom_In_Ukraine_As_Journalist_Attacked/2164350.html Concerns Mount About Press Freedom In Ukraine As Journalist Attacked], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (21 September 2010)</ref>
 
 In December 2009, and during the [[2010 Ukrainian presidential election]], campaign incumbent [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] and presidential candidate<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110201024403/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/54511/ More women than men support Tymoshenko, poll shows], [[Kyiv Post]] (7 December 2009)</ref> [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] complained Ukrainian TV channels are manipulating the consciousness of citizens in favor of financial and [[oligarchic]] groups.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20091212093435/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/54545/ Tymoshenko accuses central TV channels of manipulating people's consciousness in favor of oligarchs], [[Kyiv Post]] (8 December 2009)</ref> As of January 2009, [[Ukrainian Prime Minister]], [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] refused to appear in Inter TV-programmes "until journalists, management and owners of the TV channel stop destroying the freedom of speech and until they remember the essence of their profession - honesty, objectiveness, and unbiased stand".<ref name="owner">{{cite news|url=http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/175978.html|title=Inter TV Channel Denies Businessman Firtash's Being Among Shareholders Of Company|website=[[Ukrainian News Agency]]|date=23 January 2009}}{{Dead link|date=October 2017}}{{cbignore}}</ref>
 
 ===Yanukovych presidency (2010-2013)===

+A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = 23 May 2014|website = Reuters}}</ref> The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kyiv (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. 
 In 2014 restrictions to press freedom in Ukraine included police impeding access to public buildings, physical attacks on press rooms, and cyberattacks (e.g. against the ''Glavnoe'', ''Gordon'' and [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] websites); in July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" />
 
 Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media.<ref name="FH" /> Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too.  In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication.<ref name="FH" />

"Vesti", physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". "Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones." Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors.  Since November 2015 Ukrainian authorities, state agencies and local government authorities are forbidden to act as founders (or cofounders) of printed media outlets.<ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/306311.html Ukrainian state authorities can not be founders, cofounders of printed media from now on], [[Interfax Ukraine]] (24 November 2015)</ref>
 
 Freedom House reported the status of press freedom in [[Ukraine]] in 2015 as improving from Not Free to Partly Free. It justified the change as follows:<ref name=FH>[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine Ukraine 2015 Freedom of the Press] report</ref>
 <blockquote>due to profound changes in the media environment after the fall of President Viktor Yanukovych’s government in February, despite a rise in attacks on journalists during the Euromaidan protests of early 2014 and the subsequent conflict in eastern Ukraine. The level of government hostility and legal pressure faced by journalists decreased, as did political pressure on state-owned outlets. The media also benefited from improvements to the law on access to information and the increased independence of the broadcasting regulator.</blockquote>

 == Attacks and threats against journalists ==
-Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. -[[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}} and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kyiv struggles to find new fighters |work=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |accessdate=4 October 2015}}</ref>|group = nb}}

Ukraine (Country Guide)] by [[Sarah Johnstone]] and [[Greg Bloom]], [[Lonely Planet]], 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-74104-481-2}} (page 39)</ref><ref name="FHouse2007" />
 
-After the 2005 [[Orange Revolution]], Ukrainian television became more free.<ref>[http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160911232022/http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews |date=11 September 2016 }} [tt_news]=30800 UKRAINIAN PARTIES SCRAMBLE FOR MEDIA, FOREIGN ALLIES, AHEAD OF PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS], [[The Jamestown Foundation]] (17 August 2005)</ref> In February 2009 the National Council for Television and Radio Broadcasting claimed that "political pressure on mass media increased in recent times through amending laws and other normative acts to strengthen influence on mass media and regulatory bodies in this sphere".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/179018.html|title=National TV Council Claims Harder Political Pressure on Mass Media|publisher=[[Ukrainian News Agency]]|date=6 February 2009}}{{dead link|date=April 2017}}{{cbignore}}</ref>
+After the 2005 [[Orange Revolution]], Ukrainian television became more free.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://jamestown.org/program/ukrainian-parties-scramble-for-media-foreign-allies-ahead-of-parliamentary-elections/ |date=August 17, 2005 |publisher=[[The Jamestown Foundation]]}}</ref> In February 2009 the National Council for Television and Radio Broadcasting claimed that "political pressure on mass media increased in recent times through amending laws and other normative acts to strengthen influence on mass media and regulatory bodies in this sphere".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/179018.html|title=National TV Council Claims Harder Political Pressure on Mass Media|publisher=[[Ukrainian News Agency]]|date=6 February 2009}}{{dead link|date=April 2017}}{{cbignore}}</ref>
 
 In 2007, in Ukraine's provinces numerous, anonymous attacks<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900|title=Local newspaper editor badly injured in assault|publisher=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=31 March 2010|access-date=4 October 2015|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001051756/http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-local-newspaper-editor-badly-31-03-2010,36900|archive-date=1 October 2015}}</ref> and threats persisted against journalists, who investigated or exposed corruption or other government misdeeds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/ukraine-disturbing-deterioration-in-press-15-04-2010,37027.html|title=Disturbing deterioration in press freedom situation since new president took over|work=Reporters Without Borders|date=15 April 2010|access-date=4 October 2015}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110120224057/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/64793/ Media crackdown under way?], [[Kyiv Post]] (22 April 2010)</ref> The US-based [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] concluded in 2007 that these attacks, and police reluctance in some cases to pursue the perpetrators, were "helping to foster an atmosphere of impunity against independent journalists."<ref name="HRW2007">{{cite web|url = http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|title = Ukraine: Events of 2006|work = Human Rights Watch|date = 2007|url-status = dead|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070116150453/http://hrw.org/englishwr2k7/docs/2007/01/11/ukrain14835.htm|archive-date = 16 January 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.hrw.org/node/258888|title = Ukraine: Events of 2008|work = Human Rights Watch|access-date = 3 October 2015}}</ref>

{{in lang|uk}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014) @@ -80,7 +80,7 @@ Since November 2015 Ukrainian authorities, state agencies and local government authorities are forbidden to act as founders (or cofounders) of printed media outlets.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/306311.html Ukrainian state authorities can not be founders, cofounders of printed media from now on], [[Interfax Ukraine]] (24 November 2015) Freedom House reported the status of press freedom in [[Ukraine]] in 2015 as improving from Not Free to Partly Free. due to profound changes in the media environment after the fall of President Viktor Yanukovych’s government in February, despite a rise in attacks on journalists during the Euromaidan protests of early 2014 and the subsequent conflict in eastern Ukraine. The level of government hostility and legal pressure faced by journalists decreased, as did political pressure on state-owned outlets.
