+
due to profound changes in the media environment after the fall of President Viktor Yanukovych's government in February, despite a rise in attacks on journalists during the Euromaidan protests of early 2014 and the subsequent conflict in eastern Ukraine. The level of government hostility and legal pressure faced by journalists decreased, as did political pressure on state-owned outlets. The media also benefited from improvements to the law on access to information and the increased independence of the broadcasting regulator.
In 2015 the main concerns about media freedom in Ukraine concern the handling of pro-Russian propaganda, the [[concentration of media ownership]], and the high risks of violence against journalists, especially in the conflict areas in the east. In September 2015 Freedom House classified the [[Internet in Ukraine]] as "partly free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] as "partly free".{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/country/ukraine|title=Ukraine|work=freedomhouse.org|access-date=28 September 2015}} Ukraine was in 102nd place out of 180 countries listed in the 2017 [[World Press Freedom Index]]. In 2017 organizations like [[Reporters Without Borders]], [[Human Rights Watch]] and [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] condemned then Poroshenko's government recent bans on media.{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans independent Russian TV channel Dozhd|url=https://rsf.org/en/news/ukraine-bans-independent-russian-tv-channel-dozhd|date=2017-01-13}}{{cite web|url=https://cpj.org/2017/05/ukraine-bans-russian-media-outlets-websites.php|title=Ukraine bans Russian media outlets, websites|publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists|date=17 May 2017|access-date=19 June 2017}}{{Cite web|url=https://cpj.org/europe/ukraine/|title=Ukraine|website=cpj.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-11}} === Press freedom scores as perceived by Freedom House === @@ -482,7 +482,7 @@ ===Literature=== The Government of Ukraine started banning books in 2016 that a special committee (State Committee for State TV and Radio Broadcasting's licensing and distribution-control department) had determined to contain anti-Ukrainian content. -In January 2018, the Russian version of British historian [[Antony Beevor]]'s ''[[Stalingrad (Beevor book)|Stalingrad]]'' was added to this list. The head of the committee, Serhiy Oliyinyk, told [[Radio Free Europe]] that one particular reason was that Beevor had included information about Ukrainian militia killing 90 Jewish children on orders of the SS "to save the feelings of the [[Sonderkommando]]." @@ -492,11 +492,6 @@
 
 On 16 May 2017, [[Petro Poroshenko|President Poroshenko]] signed a decree requiring providers to block access to a number of Russian websites including four of the most popular websites in Ukraine: [[VK (social networking)|VKontakte]], [[Odnoklassniki]], [[Yandex]] and [[Mail.Ru]]. The president claimed they participated in an information war against Ukraine.<ref name=guardian-20170516>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/16/ukraine-blocks-popular-russian-websites-kremlin-role-war |title=Ukraine blocks popular social networks as part of sanctions on Russia |last=Luhn |first=Alec |newspaper=The Guardian |date=16 May 2017 |access-date=17 June 2017}}</ref>
 
-==Self-censorship==
-In Ukraine there are tendencies toward self-censorship:<ref name="USDoS1999" /> according to Roman Shutov, programme director with Detektor Media in Kiev, "the owner dictates the content and editorial policy of the media and has a real influence on how the very important topics are covered in Ukraine."<ref name="ReichardtShutov">{{cite interview|last=Shutov|first=Roman|interviewer=Adam Reichardt|url=http://www.neweasterneurope.eu/articles-and-commentary/2201-reforming-ukraine-s-media-slow-progress-at-risk|title=Reforming Ukraine's media. Slow progress at risk|publisher=neweasterneurope.eu|date=29 November 2016|access-date=19 June 2017}}</ref>
-
-This trend has been noted by the US Department of State in particular regarding matters sensitive to the Government, that pushes toward self-censorship through "tax inspections, libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists".<ref name="USDoS1999" />
-
 == Situation in the Russian-annexed Crimea ==
 
 The media environment in [[Crimea]] was completely transformed by the March 2014 Russian [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexation]] of the peninsula, after the ejection of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] from power in [[Ukraine]] following the [[euromaidan]] protests. Russian authorities engineered an annexation referendum to Russia, and restrictive Russian media laws started to be enacted in the Black Sea peninsula too. Media conditions in Crimea in 2014 were worse than in [[Russia]] itself, due to the effort of Russia-imposed authorities to rein in a previously relatively pluralistic media landscape. Media outlets were shut down, broadcasts of Ukrainian channels were suspended, and journalists fled the region due to fears of harassment, violence, and arrests. The situation of press freedom in Crimea in 2014 was identified by [[Freedom House]] as the worst in the European continent.<ref name=FHcrimea>[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/crimea Crimea 2015 Press Freedom] report</ref>

http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = 21 September 2014|website = The Christian Science Monitor}} The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a [[Kyiv]]-based digital newspaper "Vesti", physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". "Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones." Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = 9 November 2014|website = Huff Post Media}} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.|group=nb}} +[[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kyiv government. Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view. For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey "propaganda," and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014.{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|date=16 September 2015 |access-date=17 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|access-date=17 September 2015}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |access-date=28 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Two more Russian journalists denied entry to Ukraine|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1911158-two-more-russian-journalists-denied-entry-to-ukraine.html|date=2017-05-07}}{{#tag:ref|On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for "violating Ukraine's territorial integrity" brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = 21 September 2014|website = The Christian Science Monitor}} The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a [[Kyiv]]-based digital newspaper "Vesti", physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". "Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones." Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = 9 November 2014|website = Huff Post Media}} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.|group=nb}} The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Information Policy]] was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | access-date=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)
{{in lang|uk}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)
comment: Alter: template type. Add: date, title. | [[WP:UCB|Use this bot]]. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs]]. | Suggested by BrownHairedGirl | #UCB_webform 3037/3603
llm_output:
The change made is the addition of text regarding the media landscape in Ukraine post-Orange Revolution, specifically focusing on the freedom of the press and the challenges faced by journalists. 

**Added**: Text discussing the increased freedom of Ukrainian television after the Orange Revolution, the claims of political pressure on mass media, and the persistence of threats against journalists.

**Weaponised**: Not Weaponised. The content primarily discusses media freedom and challenges in Ukraine without employing weaponisation terms or narratives that could be seen as promoting a specific political agenda or cultural oppression.

 According to the [[US Department of State]] in 2009 there were no attempts by central authorities to direct media content, but there were reports of intimidation of journalists by national and local officials.<ref name="USDoS2009">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136063.htm 2009 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (11 March 2010)</ref> Media at times demonstrated a tendency toward [[self‑censorship]] on matters that the government deemed sensitive.<ref name="USDoS2009" /><ref name="USDoS2008">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/eur/119110.htm 2008 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (25 February 2009)</ref> Stories in the electronic and printed media (veiled advertisements and positive coverage presented as news) and participation in a television talk show can be bought.<ref name="USDoS2009" /> Media watchdog groups have express concern over the extremely high monetary damages that were demanded in [[Judicial system of Ukraine|court cases]] concerning [[libel]].<ref name="USDoS2009" />
 
@@ -422,7 +422,7 @@
 == Attacks and threats against journalists ==
 Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0"/> 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" /> In September 2016 [[Inter (TV channel)|Inter]] TV channel - often accused of being pro-Russia - was put to fire during a protest.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pro-Russia TV station in Kyiv evacuated after fire|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/05/pro-russia-tv-inter-kiev-evacuated-fire-ukraine|access-date=19 April 2017|work=The Guardian|date=5 September 2016}}</ref>
 
-[[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}} and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15 year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kyiv struggles to find new fighters |work=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |access-date=4 October 2015}}</ref>|group = nb}}
+[[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}} and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15-year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kyiv struggles to find new fighters |work=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |access-date=4 October 2015}}</ref>|group = nb}}
 
 The website [[Myrotvorets]] has published personal information about journalists.<ref name="ReichardtShutov" />
 
@@ -434,7 +434,6 @@
 * [[Sergei Dolgov]], a newspaper editor from Mariupol, went missing in June 2014 during the [[War in Donbass]] and is presumed dead by some mostly pro-Russian sources.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ria.ru/world/20140716/1016243602.html|title=Newspaper workers don't know chief editor's whereabouts|work=ria.ru}}</ref>
 
 == Banned journalists, media, websites ==
-
 The Ukrainian government and President [[Petro Poroshenko]] have banned journalists, media and websites.<ref name="cpj201705" /> The new sanctions in May 2017 targeted 1,228 people and 468 companies.<ref name="rsf201705" /> The decision was condemned by [[Reporters Without Borders]], [[Human Rights Watch]] and [[Committee to Protect Journalists]].<ref name="rsf201701" /><ref name="hrw201705" /><ref name="cpj201705" /> The most well known included:

comment: v2.04 - Fix errors for [[WP:WCW|CW project]] (Template parameter with a problem - Spelling and typography)
llm_output:
**Change Description:** Removed a sentence regarding the Ukrainian government and President Petro Poroshenko banning journalists, media, and websites.

**Analysis:** The removal of this sentence could be seen as an attempt to downplay or obscure the actions taken by the Ukrainian government against media freedom, which is a significant aspect of the narrative surrounding press freedom in Ukraine. This could potentially align with a narrative that seeks to portray the Ukrainian government in a more favorable light, thus weaponizing the cultural heritage of media freedom and journalistic integrity.

**Conclusion:** Weaponised. The change reflects a selective omission that could influence perceptions of media freedom in Ukraine, aligning with narratives that may serve specific political agendas.

changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -81,7 +81,7 @@ Since November 2015 Ukrainian authorities, state agencies and local government authorities are forbidden to act as founders (or cofounders) of printed media outlets.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/306311.html Ukrainian state authorities can not be founders, cofounders of printed media from now on], [[Interfax Ukraine]] (24 November 2015) -Freedom House reported the status of press freedom in [[Ukraine]] in 2015 as improving from Not Free to Partly Free. It justified the change as follows:[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine Ukraine 2015 Freedom of the Press] report +Freedom House reported the status of press freedom in [[Ukraine]] in 2015 as improving from Not Free to Partly Free. It justified the change as follows:[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine Ukraine 2015 Freedom of the Press] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181116115122/https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine |date=16 November 2018 }} report
due to profound changes in the media environment after the fall of President Viktor Yanukovych's government in February, despite a rise in attacks on journalists during the Euromaidan protests of early 2014 and the subsequent conflict in eastern Ukraine. The level of government hostility and legal pressure faced by journalists decreased, as did political pressure on state-owned outlets. The media also benefited from improvements to the law on access to information and the increased independence of the broadcasting regulator.
In 2015 the main concerns about media freedom in Ukraine concern the handling of pro-Russian propaganda, the [[concentration of media ownership]], and the high risks of violence against journalists, especially in the conflict areas in the east. In September 2015 Freedom House classified the [[Internet in Ukraine]] as "partly free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] as "partly free".{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/country/ukraine|title=Ukraine|work=freedomhouse.org|access-date=28 September 2015}} Ukraine was in 102nd place out of 180 countries listed in the 2017 [[World Press Freedom Index]]. In 2017 organizations like [[Reporters Without Borders]], [[Human Rights Watch]] and [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] condemned then Poroshenko's government recent bans on media.{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans independent Russian TV channel Dozhd|url=https://rsf.org/en/news/ukraine-bans-independent-russian-tv-channel-dozhd|date=2017-01-13}}{{cite web|url=https://cpj.org/2017/05/ukraine-bans-russian-media-outlets-websites.php|title=Ukraine bans Russian media outlets, websites|publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists|date=17 May 2017|access-date=19 June 2017}}{{Cite web|url=https://cpj.org/europe/ukraine/|title=Ukraine|website=cpj.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-11}}

 After the 2005 [[Orange Revolution]], Ukrainian television became more free.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://jamestown.org/program/ukrainian-parties-scramble-for-media-foreign-allies-ahead-of-parliamentary-elections/ |date=August 17, 2005 |publisher=[[The Jamestown Foundation]]|title=Ukrainian Parties Scramble for Media, Foreign Allies, Ahead of Parliamentary Elections }}</ref> In February 2009 the National Council for Television and Radio Broadcasting claimed that "political pressure on mass media increased in recent times through amending laws and other normative acts to strengthen influence on mass media and regulatory bodies in this sphere".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/179018.html|title=National TV Council Claims Harder Political Pressure on Mass Media|publisher=[[Ukrainian News Agency]]|date=6 February 2009}}{{dead link|date=April 2017}}{{cbignore}}</ref>

 In December 2009, and during the [[2010 Ukrainian presidential election]], campaign incumbent [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] and presidential candidate<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110201024403/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/54511/ More women than men support Tymoshenko, poll shows], [[Kyiv Post]] (7 December 2009)</ref> [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] complained Ukrainian TV channels are manipulating the consciousness of citizens in favor of financial and [[oligarchic]] groups.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20091212093435/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/54545/ Tymoshenko accuses central TV channels of manipulating people's consciousness in favor of oligarchs], [[Kyiv Post]] (8 December 2009)</ref> As of January 2009, [[Ukrainian Prime Minister]], [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] refused to appear in Inter TV-programmes "until journalists, management and owners of the TV channel stop destroying the freedom of speech and until they remember the essence of their profession - honesty, objectiveness, and unbiased stand".<ref name="owner">{{cite news|url=http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/175978.html|title=Inter TV Channel Denies Businessman Firtash's Being Among Shareholders of Company|website=[[Ukrainian News Agency]]|date=23 January 2009}}{{Dead link|date=October 2017}}{{cbignore}}</ref>

-Since the February 2010 election of Viktor Yanukovych as President Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased.<ref name="sinceFeb2010" /> The [[International Press Institute]] addressed an open letter to President Yanukovych on 10 August 2010 urging him to address what the organisation saw as a disturbing deterioration in press freedom over the previous six months in Ukraine.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100811172630/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/ International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'significantly'], [[Kyiv Post]] (11 August 2010)</ref> [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] rapporteur [[Renate Wohlwend]] noticed on 6 October 2010 that "Some progress had been made in recent years but there had also been some retrograde steps".<ref name="PACE">[https://web.archive.org/web/20101007235843/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85208/ European rapporteurs note media setback in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (6 October 2010)</ref> In January 2011 [[Freedom House]] stated it had perceived "negative trends in Ukraine" during 2010; these included: curbs on press freedom, the intimidation of [[civil society]], and greater [[Government of Ukraine|government]] influence on the [[Judicial system of Ukraine|judiciary]].<ref name="negative trends 2010" />
-
-According to the [[US Department of State]] in 2009 there were no attempts by central authorities to direct media content, but there were reports of intimidation of journalists by national and local officials.<ref name="USDoS2009">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136063.htm 2009 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (11 March 2010)</ref> Media at times demonstrated a tendency toward [[self‑censorship]] on matters that the government deemed sensitive.<ref name="USDoS2009" /><ref name="USDoS2008">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/eur/119110.htm 2008 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (25 February 2009)</ref> Stories in the electronic and printed media (veiled advertisements and positive coverage presented as news) and participation in a television talk show can be bought.<ref name="USDoS2009" /> Media watchdog groups have express concern over the extremely high monetary damages that were demanded in [[Judicial system of Ukraine|court cases]] concerning [[libel]].<ref name="USDoS2009" />
+Since the February 2010 election of Viktor Yanukovych as President Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased.<ref name="sinceFeb2010" /> The [[International Press Institute]] addressed an open letter to President Yanukovych on 10 August 2010 urging him to address what the organisation saw as a disturbing deterioration in press freedom over the previous six months in Ukraine.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100811172630/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/ International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'significantly'], [[Kyiv Post]] (11 August 2010)</ref> [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] rapporteur Renate Wohlwend noticed on 6 October 2010 that "Some progress had been made in recent years but there had also been some retrograde steps".<ref name="PACE">[https://web.archive.org/web/20101007235843/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85208/ European rapporteurs note media setback in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (6 October 2010)</ref> In January 2011 [[Freedom House]] stated it had perceived "negative trends in Ukraine" during 2010; these included: curbs on press freedom, the intimidation of [[civil society]], and greater [[Government of Ukraine|government]] influence on the [[Judicial system of Ukraine|judiciary]].<ref name="negative trends 2010" />
+
+According to the [[US Department of State]] in 2009 there were no attempts by central authorities to direct media content, but there were reports of intimidation of journalists by national and local officials.<ref name="USDoS2009">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136063.htm 2009 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (11 March 2010)</ref> Media at times demonstrated a tendency toward self‑censorship on matters that the government deemed sensitive.<ref name="USDoS2009" /><ref name="USDoS2008">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/eur/119110.htm 2008 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (25 February 2009)</ref> Stories in the electronic and printed media (veiled advertisements and positive coverage presented as news) and participation in a television talk show can be bought.<ref name="USDoS2009" /> Media watchdog groups have express concern over the extremely high monetary damages that were demanded in [[Judicial system of Ukraine|court cases]] concerning [[libel]].<ref name="USDoS2009" />
 
 In 2013 there were concerns over the corrupting influence of certain political figures, connected to the government of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] on Ukrainian media.<ref>[http://www.businessinsider.com.au/understanding-euromaidan-2014-1 "A Ukrainian Explains 10 Things The West Needs To Know About The Situation In Kiev: #5 People find it hard to uncover the truth"], Taras Ilkiv, ''Business Insider'', 24 January 2014. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
 
 === Euromaidan revolution and Poroshenko presidency (2014) ===
 [[File:Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, Kyiv. Events of February 18, 2014..jpg|thumbnail|Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, [[Kyiv]]. Events of 18 February 2014.]]
-A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = 23 May 2014|website = Reuters}}</ref> The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kyiv (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. 
+A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = 23 May 2014|website = Reuters}}</ref> The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kyiv (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. 
 In 2014 restrictions to press freedom in Ukraine included police impeding access to public buildings, physical attacks on press rooms, and cyberattacks (e.g. against the ''Glavnoe'', ''Gordon'' and [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] websites); in July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" />
 
 Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media.<ref name="FH" /> Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too.  In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication.<ref name="FH" />
 
-[[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kyiv government.<ref name="FH" /> Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view.<ref name=":02" /> For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey "propaganda," and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.<ref name=":02" /><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014.</ref><ref name="FH" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|date=16 September 2015 |access-date=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|access-date=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |access-date=28 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="hrw201705" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Two more Russian journalists denied entry to Ukraine|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1911158-two-more-russian-journalists-denied-entry-to-ukraine.html|date=2017-05-07}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for "violating Ukraine's territorial integrity" brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].<ref name=":02">{{cite web|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = 21 September 2014|website = The Christian Science Monitor}}</ref> The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a [[Kyiv]]-based digital newspaper "Vesti", physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". "Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones." Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = 9 November 2014|website = Huff Post Media}}</ref> ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.<ref name="FH" />|group=nb}}
-
-The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Information Policy]] was established on 2 December 2014.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | access-date=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="FLUYGIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)<br />[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)<br />{{in lang|uk}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014)</ref> The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].<ref name="FLUYGIU21214" /><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)</ref> [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".<ref name="PPsbiU812">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)</ref>
+[[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kyiv government.<ref name="FH" /> Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view.<ref name=":02" /> For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey "propaganda," and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.<ref name=":02" /><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014.</ref><ref name="FH" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|date=16 September 2015 |access-date=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite Ukraine|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1911158-two-more-russian-journalists-denied-entry-to-ukraine.html|date=2017-05-07}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for "violating Ukraine's territorial integrity" brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].<ref name=":02">{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = 21 September 2014|website = The Christian Science Monitor}}</ref> The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a [[Kyiv]]-based digital newspaper "Vesti", physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". "Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones." Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = 9 November 2014|website = Huff Post Media}}</ref> ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.<ref name="FH" />|group=nb}}

+The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Information Policy]] was established on 2 December 2014.<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | access-date=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="FLUYGIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)<br />[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)<br />{{in lang|uk}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014)</ref> The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].<ref name="FLUYGIU21214" /><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)</ref> [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".<ref name="PPsbiU812">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)</ref>
 
 On 16 May 2017 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning various Russian internet service providers and news sources, among others, [[VK (social networking)|VKontakte]], [[Odnoklassniki]], [[Yandex]], [[Rossiya Segodnya]], [[RBC Information Systems|RBC]], [[All-Russia State Television and Radio Broadcasting Company|VGTRK]], but also a number of independent stations such as the RBC, claiming this was done for "security reasons".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/421954.html|title=All of Ukrainian president's official pages on Russian social media sites being closed|work=Interfax-Ukraine|access-date=2017-05-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/ukraine-bans-dozens-of-russian-websites/3852930.html|title=Ukraine Bans Dozens of Russian Websites|last=News|first=VOA|work=VOA|access-date=2017-05-16|language=en}}</ref> Tanya Cooper from [[Human Rights Watch]] called the decree: "a cynical, politically expedient attack on the right to information affecting millions of Ukrainians, and their personal and professional lives".<ref name="hrw201705">{{cite web|title=Ukraine: Revoke Ban on Dozens of Russian Web Companies|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/05/16/ukraine-revoke-ban-dozens-russian-web-companies|date=2017-05-15}}</ref> [[Reporters Without Borders]] (RSF) also condemned the ban imposed on Russian social networks.<ref name="rsf201705">{{cite web|title=RSF urges Ukraine to scrap ban on Russian social media sites |publisher=Reporters without borders |url=https://rsf.org/en/news/rsf-urges-ukraine-scrap-ban-russian-social-media-sites |date=23 May 2017 |access-date=26 October 2017}}</ref>

 == Attacks and threats against journalists ==
 Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0"/> 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" /> In September 2016 [[Inter (TV channel)|Inter]] TV channel - often accused of being pro-Russia - was put to fire during a protest.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pro-Russia TV station in Kyiv evacuated after fire|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/05/pro-russia-tv-inter-kiev-evacuated-fire-ukraine|access-date=19 April 2017|work=The Guardian|date=5 September 2016}}</ref>
 
-[[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}} and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15-year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kyiv struggles to find new fighters |work=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |access-date=4 October 2015}}</ref>|group = nb}}
+[[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}} and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15-year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kyiv struggles to find new fighters |work=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |access-date=4 October 2015}}</ref>| nb}}
 
 The website [[Myrotvorets]] has published personal information about journalists.<ref name="ReichardtShutov">{{cite interview|last=Shutov|first=Roman|interviewer=Adam Reichardt|url=http://www.neweasterneurope.eu/articles-and-commentary/2201-reforming-ukraine-s-media-slow-progress-at-risk|title=Reforming Ukraine's media.  === Legal framework ===
 After the annexation, Russian authorities passed a local constitution on the Russian model and started imposing Russian legislation. Despite guarantees for freedom of speech and freedom of the press in the Russian legislation, politicised judiciary and restrictive laws devoid them of actual contents, leaving broad discretion to federal regulators in media registration and licensing.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 
-All media in Crimea, including online ones, were afforded until January 2015 to register with the Russian federal media regulator [[Rozkomnadzor]] and get a license. Officials warned editors that registration would be denied to media that spread "extremist" contents. A December 2013 Russian law against separatism (carrying sanctions of up to 5 years in prison) was used to repress criticism of the annexation and calls for a return of the territory to Ukraine.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
+All media in Crimea, including online ones, were afforded until January 2015 to register with the Russian federal media regulator Rozkomnadzor and get a license. Officials warned editors that registration would be denied to media that spread "extremist" contents. A December 2013 Russian law against separatism (carrying sanctions of up to 5 years in prison) was used to repress criticism of the annexation and calls for a return of the territory to Ukraine.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 
 NGOs, journalists' associations and citizen groups in Crimea became subject to restrictive Russian laws, including measures limiting foreign funding.
 Russian authorities failed to protect journalists, activists and citizens from abuses by paramilitaries and security forces. Cases of unlawful detentions and physical assaults were reported throughout 2014 in Crimea.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
@@ -517,21 +517,21 @@
 
 Since the annexation, Russian authorities threatened and harassed pro-Ukrainian or simply independent media in Crimea. Media professionals - including foreign ones - have been obstructed, detained, questioned, and have had their equipment seized or destroyed. "Self-defence" paramilitary units have enjoyed impunity for their punitive actions against non-aligned journalists.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 * In June 2014 paramilitaries stopped Sergey Mokrushin and Vladen Melnikov (of the [[Centre for Investigative Journalism]]) on the streets of [[Simferopol]] for singing an anti-Putin song. The two were detained and badly beaten, then passed to the police, who released them.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
-* [[Ruslan Yugosh]], among the founders of the ''[[Sobytiya Kryma]]'' (Crimean Events) news website, was summoned by the police in June 2014. In his absence from Crimea, the police interrogated his 73-years-old mother, threatening her with repercussions related to Yugosh' work.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
+* Ruslan Yugosh, among the founders of the ''Sobytiya Kryma'' (Crimean Events) news website, was summoned by the police in June 2014. In his absence from Crimea, the police interrogated his 73-years-old mother, threatening her with repercussions related to Yugosh' work.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 
 Several human rights and civic activists chose to relocate to mainland Ukraine to escape restrictions, intimidation and harassment, providing information to the Crimean public via the internet.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
-*The independent TV and radio station ''[[Chornomorska]]'' moved to the mainland after being forced off-air in March 2014 and having its equipment seized under the pretext of failure to pay fees.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
-*The anti-annexation blogger [[Yelizaveta Bohutskaya]] left Crimea in September 2014 after a police raid at her home. She had been questioned for six hours and had had her equipment seized.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
+*The independent TV and radio station ''Chornomorska'' moved to the mainland after being forced off-air in March 2014 and having its equipment seized under the pretext of failure to pay fees.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
+*The anti-annexation blogger Yelizaveta Bohutskaya left Crimea in September 2014 after a police raid at her home. She had been questioned for six hours and had had her equipment seized.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 * [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] created a Crimean news service in Russian, Ukrainian and Tatar languages.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 
 === Repression of Crimean Tatar media ===
 [[Crimean Tatars|Crimean Tatar]] media were particularly targeted by Russian repression.  [[ATR (TV channel)|ATR]], ''Avdet'' and the QHA news agency remained among the last independent media operating in Crimea by the end of 2014.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
-* In June 2014 Shevket Kaybullayev, editor of the ''Avdet'' newspaper, was questioned and warned by the prosecutor over "extremist contents" due to the paper's coverage of an opposition activities and the use of the term "occupation". In September 2014 the premises of the ''Avdet'' newspaper were raided and searched by unidentified security forces, without a warrant. The newspaper was closed down and its bank accounts seized. Kaybullayev was officially warned that he would be prosecuted and risked up to 5 years in jail if ''Avdet'' had continued reporting on calls for a boycott of the [[2014 Crimean legislative election]].<ref name=FHcrimea/>
+* In June 2014 Shevket Kaybullayev, editor of the ''Avdet'' newspaper, was questioned and warned by the prosecutor over "extremist contents" due to the paper's coverage of an opposition activities and the use of the term "occupation". In September 2014 the premises of the ''Avdet'' newspaper were raided and searched by unidentified security forces, without a warrant. The newspaper was closed down and its bank accounts seized. Kaybullayev was officially warned that he would be prosecuted and risked up to 5 years in jail if ''Avdet'' had continued reporting on calls for a boycott of the 2014 Crimean legislative election.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 * The Crimean Tatar TV channel [[ATR (TV channel)|ATR]] received a warning in May 2015 after covering a Tatar protest. It was subject to an inspection in September 2014 by the Interior Ministry, as suspect of inciting "extremism" and "distrust towards the authorities". KGB agents regularly called the station and applied pressures, threatening it with closure.<ref name=FHcrimea/>
 
 == Situation in the occupied regions of Donetsk and Luhansk ==
 {{See also|Humanitarian situation during the war in Donbass}}
-Seven journalists and media workers were killed in Ukraine in 2014. One of them, [[Vyacheslav Veremiy]] of ''[[Vesti (Ukrainian newspaper)|Vesti]]'', was shot in Kyiv in February 2014.  The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts<ref name=MOM>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website=Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher=Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev) |access-date=12 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113165425/http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |archive-date=13 January 2017 |url-status=dead }}</ref> but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries.<ref name=OSCE2015/> These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications.<ref name=MOM/> Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine.<ref name=OSCE2015/> Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners.<ref name=LOC>{{cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
 
-Specifically, the new law amends article 12 of the existing Law of Ukraine on Television and Radio Broadcasting of 1994, establishing that national and local government authorities, individuals and legal entities which are registered offline, political parties, religious organisations, professional unions, and persons that were convicted by courts and that are still serving their sentences cannot be owners of a TV or radio stations in Ukraine. Furthermore, the Law prohibits to physical or legal persons residing in a country which is recognised as an aggressor or occupier the right to own a television or a radio station in Ukraine.<ref name=LOC/> This sentence refers to the [[Russia|Russian Federation]] which [[2014 Crimean status referendum|annexed Crimea]] in 2014.<ref name=LOC/> The Law provides a new definition of ownership which is closely connected to the exercise of a decisive influence in the management or business activity of the media outlet directly or through other persons and includes also [[final beneficiaries]].<ref name=LOC/> The Law requires that information on the ownership structure and on the individuals owning at least 10% or more of a television or radio broadcasting have to be made public on the company's website and sent to the [[National Council for Questions of Television and Radio Broadcasting]], which is the national media regulator in Ukraine. According to the law, the council can impose fines when information provided are insufficient or incorrect.<ref name=LOC/>
+Specifically, the new law amends article 12 of the existing Law of Ukraine on Television and Radio Broadcasting of 1994, establishing that national and local government authorities, individuals and legal entities which are registered offline, political parties, religious organisations, professional unions, and persons that were convicted by courts and that are still serving their sentences cannot be owners of a TV or radio stations in Ukraine. Furthermore, the Law prohibits to physical or legal persons residing in a country which is recognised as an aggressor or occupier the right to own a television or a radio station in Ukraine.<ref name=LOC/> This sentence refers to the [[Russia|Russian Federation]] which [[2014 Crimean status referendum|annexed Crimea]] in 2014.<ref name=LOC/> The Law provides a new definition of ownership which is closely connected to the exercise of a decisive influence in the management or business activity of the media outlet directly or through other persons and includes also final beneficiaries.<ref name=LOC/> The Law requires that information on the ownership structure and on the individuals owning at least 10% or more of a television or radio broadcasting have to be made public on the company's website and sent to the National Council for Questions of Television and Radio Broadcasting, which is the national media regulator in Ukraine. According to the law, the council can impose fines when information provided are insufficient or incorrect.<ref name=LOC/>
 
 According to some experts, one of the main weakness of the new law is that it does not exclude funding from financial sources located in [[Cyprus]] (even if it prohibits the transfer of funds from offshore territories), through which ownership of most Ukrainian TV channels is exercised. Among some commentators there are some doubts that the Law will be amended to address this issue, due to the strong lobbying efforts of TV owners.<ref name=LOC/> Other doubts have been voiced due to the lack of an effective sanctions system.<ref name="MOM" />
 
-In 2016, [[Reporters Without Borders]], together with the [[Institute of Mass Information]] ([[Kyiv]]), launched the project [[Media Ownership Monitor Ukraine]] to promote transparency in media ownership and to map who owns and controls the media in Ukraine, by creating a public available and updated database listing the owners of the main media outlets, and detailing also the interests and the affilitations of owners into companies or political parties.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/about/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine.  == Attacks and threats against journalists ==
 Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)|war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0"/> 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" /> In September 2016 [[Inter (TV channel)|Inter]] TV channel - often accused of being pro-Russia - was put to fire during a protest.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pro-Russia TV station in Kyiv evacuated after fire|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/05/pro-russia-tv-inter-kiev-evacuated-fire-ukraine|access-date=19 April 2017|work=The Guardian|date=5 September 2016}}</ref>
 
-[[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist [[Ruslan Kotsaba]] and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15-year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kyiv struggles to find new fighters |work=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |access-date=4 October 2015}}</ref>| nb}}

 === Orange revolution and Yushchenko presidency (2004-2010) ===
 Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media has become more pluralistic and independent.<ref name="FHouse2007" /><ref name="organge">[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html The report said that "there is no practice of institutionalized blocking or filtering, or a regulatory framework for censorship of content online", but "there have been attempts at creating legislation which could censor or limit content" and would "present indirect threats to freedom of information online."<ref name="FOTN-Ukraine-2013">[http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-net/2013/ukraine#.UvJZil6togE "Ukraine"], ''Freedom on the Net 2013'', Freedom House, 30 September 2013. The report said that "there is no practice of institutionalized blocking or filtering, or a regulatory framework for censorship of content online", but "there have been attempts at creating legislation which could censor or limit content" and would "present indirect threats to freedom of information online."<ref name="FOTN-Ukraine-2013">[http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-net/2013/ukraine#.UvJZil6togE "Ukraine"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180926085818/https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-net/2013/ukraine#.UvJZil6togE |date=26 September 2018 }}, ''Freedom on the Net 2013'', Freedom House, 30 September 2013. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
 
 As of 2012, access to Internet content in Ukraine was largely unfettered. Ukraine possessed relatively liberal legislation governing the Internet and access to information. While there were no government restrictions on access to the Internet, law enforcement bodies were known to monitor the Internet, at times without appropriate legal authority. There have been occasional agitations of interference by law enforcement agencies with prominent bloggers and online publications.<ref name="USDOS-CRHRP-Ukraine-2012">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/humanrightsreport/index.htm?year=2012&dlid=204349 "Ukraine"], ''Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 2012'', Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, U.S. Department of State, 15 April 2013. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>

September 2015}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |access-date=28 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Two more Russian journalists denied entry to Ukraine|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1911158-two-more-russian-journalists-denied-entry-to-ukraine.html|date=2017-05-07}}{{#tag:ref|On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for "violating Ukraine's territorial integrity" brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = 21 September 2014|website = The Christian Science Monitor}} The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a [[Kyiv]]-based digital newspaper "Vesti", physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". "Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones." Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = 9 November 2014|website = Huff Post Media}} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.|group=nb}} -The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Information Policy]] was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release |url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | access-date=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)
{{in lang|uk}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbass|war in the Donbass region]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014) +The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Information Policy]] was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release |url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | access-date=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)
{{in lang|uk}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)|war in the Donbass region]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014) On 16 May 2017 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning various Russian internet service providers and news sources, among others, [[VK (social networking)|VKontakte]], [[Odnoklassniki]], [[Yandex]], [[Rossiya Segodnya]], [[RBC Information Systems|RBC]], [[All-Russia State Television and Radio Broadcasting Company|VGTRK]], but also a number of independent stations such as the RBC, claiming this was done for "security reasons".{{Cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/421954.html|title=All of Ukrainian president's official pages on Russian social media sites being closed|work=Interfax-Ukraine|access-date=2017-05-16}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/ukraine-bans-dozens-of-russian-websites/3852930.html|title=Ukraine Bans Dozens of Russian Websites|last=News|first=VOA|work=VOA|access-date=2017-05-16|language=en}} Tanya Cooper from [[Human Rights Watch]] called the decree: "a cynical, politically expedient attack on the right to information affecting millions of Ukrainians, and their personal and professional lives".{{cite web|title=Ukraine: Revoke Ban on Dozens of Russian Web Companies|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/05/16/ukraine-revoke-ban-dozens-russian-web-companies|date=2017-05-15}} [[Reporters Without Borders]] (RSF) also condemned the ban imposed on Russian social |url=https://rsf.org/en/news/rsf-urges-ukraine-scrap-ban-russian-social-media-sites |date=23 May 2017 |access-date=26 October 2017}} @@ -422,7 +422,7 @@ |} == Attacks and threats against journalists == -Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013. 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''. In September 2016 [[Inter (TV channel)|Inter]] TV channel - often accused of being pro-Russia - was put to fire during a protest.{{cite news|title=Pro-Russia TV station in Kyiv evacuated after fire|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/05/pro-russia-tv-inter-kiev-evacuated-fire-ukraine|access-date=19 April 2017|work=The Guardian|date=5 September 2016}} +Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)|war in Donbass]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013. 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''. In September 2016 [[Inter (TV channel)|Inter]] TV channel - often accused of being pro-Russia - was put to fire during a protest.{{cite news|title=Pro-Russia TV station in Kyiv evacuated after fire|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/05/pro-russia-tv-inter-kiev-evacuated-fire-ukraine|access-date=19 April 2017|work=The Guardian|date=5 September 2016}} [[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}} and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ruslan Kotsaba|WD=Q19326727}}, was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15-year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kyiv struggles to find new fighters |work=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |access-date=4 October 2015}}| nb}} @@ -434,7 +434,7 @@ {{Timeline of reporters killed in Ukraine}} ==Missing reporters== -* [[Sergei Dolgov]], a newspaper editor from Mariupol, went missing in June 2014 during the [[War in Donbass]] and is presumed dead by some mostly pro-Russian sources.{{cite news|url=http://ria.ru/world/20140716/1016243602.html|title=Newspaper workers don't know chief editor's whereabouts|work=ria.ru}} +* [[Sergei Dolgov]], a newspaper editor from Mariupol, went missing in June 2014 during the [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)|War in Donbass]] and is presumed dead by some mostly pro-Russian sources.{{cite news|url=http://ria.ru/world/20140716/1016243602.html|title=Newspaper workers don't know chief editor's whereabouts|work=ria.ru}} == Banned journalists, media, websites == The Ukrainian government and President [[Petro Poroshenko]] have banned journalists, media and websites. The new sanctions in May 2017 targeted 1,228 people and 468 companies. The decision was condemned by [[Reporters Without Borders]], [[Human Rights Watch]] and [[Committee to Protect Journalists]].  After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref name="HayozLushnycky2005">{{cite book|last1=Hayoz|first1=Nicolas|last2=Lushnycky|first2=Andrej N.|editor1=Nicolas Hayoz|editor2=Andrej N.
