+In 2014, the [[European Commission]]'s progress report on the implementation of the [[European Neighbourhood Policy]] in Ukraine found the lack of transparency as an issue in the country and that proper legislative framework should be adopted.<ref name=COE/> To comply with its international commitment, legislation on transparency of media ownership has been reformed in 2015. On 10 September 2015, President [[Petro Poroshenko]] signed the law called "On Amendments to Several Laws of Ukraine on Ensuring the Transparency of Media Ownership and Implementing the Principles of state Policy in the Sphere of Television and Radio Broadcasting". The law entered into force on 1 October 2015.<ref name=OSCE2015>{{cite web |url=http://www.osce.org/fom/187956  |title=OSCE Representative welcomes law on transparency of media ownership in Ukraine as it comes into force |date=1 October 2015 |website= [[Osce.org]] |publisher= Organisation for Security & Co-operation in Europe |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
 
 The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts<ref name=MOM>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website=Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher=Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev) |access-date=12 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113165425/http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |archive-date=13 January 2017 |url-status=dead }}</ref> but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries.<ref name=OSCE2015/> These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications.<ref name=MOM/> Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine.<ref name=OSCE2015/> Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners.<ref name=LOC>{{cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>

 == Situation in the Russian-annexed Crimea ==
 
-The media environment in [[Crimea]] was completely transformed by the March 2014 Russian [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexation]] of the peninsula, after the ejection of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] from power in [[Ukraine]] following the [[euromaidan]] protests. Russian authorities engineered an annexation referendum to Russia, and restrictive Russian media laws started to be enacted in the Black Sea peninsula too. Media conditions in Crimea in 2014 were worse than in [[Russia]] itself, due to the effort of Russia-imposed authorities to rein in a previously relatively pluralistic media landscape. Media outlets were shut down, broadcasts of Ukrainian channels were suspended, and journalists fled the region due to fears of harassment, violence, and arrests. The situation of press freedom in Crimea in 2014 was identified by [[Freedom House]] as the worst in the European continent.<ref name=FHcrimea>[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/crimea Crimea 2015 Press Freedom] report</ref>

Russian authorities engineered an annexation referendum to Russia, and restrictive Russian media laws started to be enacted in the Black Sea peninsula too. Media conditions in Crimea in 2014 were worse than in [[Russia]] itself, due to the effort of Russia-imposed authorities to rein in a previously relatively pluralistic media landscape. Media outlets were shut down, broadcasts of Ukrainian channels were suspended, and journalists fled the region due to fears of harassment, violence, and arrests. The situation of press freedom in Crimea in 2014 was identified by [[Freedom House]] as the worst in the European continent.<ref name=FHcrimea>[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/crimea Crimea 2015 Press Freedom] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160328201106/https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/crimea |date=28 March 2016 }} report</ref>
 
 Russian outlets, particularly state-owned ones, enjoy a dominant position in post-annexation Crimea. The distribution of Ukrainian print media has been obstructed by Russian officials, and even the Ukrainian Postal Agency had to stop deliveries in the peninsula. Widespread and irregular expropriations by Russian authorities have also affected the Crimean media landscape<ref name=FHcrimea/>

Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kyiv (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In 2014 restrictions to press freedom in Ukraine included police impeding access to public buildings, physical attacks on press rooms, and cyberattacks (e.g. against the ''Glavnoe'', ''Gordon'' and [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] websites); in July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''. @@ -82,6 +82,11 @@ Freedom House reported the status of press freedom in [[Ukraine]] in 2015 as improving from Not Free to Partly Free. It justified the change as follows:[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine Ukraine 2015 Freedom of the Press] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181116115122/https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine |date=16 November 2018 }} report
due to profound changes in the media environment after the fall of President Viktor Yanukovych's government in February, despite a rise in attacks on journalists during the Euromaidan protests of early 2014 and the subsequent conflict in eastern Ukraine. The level of government hostility and legal pressure faced by journalists decreased, as did political pressure on state-owned outlets. The media also benefited from improvements to the law on access to information and the increased independence of the broadcasting regulator.
In 2015 the main concerns about media freedom in Ukraine concern the handling of pro-Russian propaganda, the [[concentration of media ownership]], and the high risks of violence against journalists, especially in the conflict areas in the east. +On December 30, 2022, President [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy|Volodymyr Zelensky]] signed into law a bill that would expand the power of government to regulate media outlets and journalists in the country, over the objections of journalists and international press freedom groups.<ref name="Dress 2023">{{cite web | last=Dress | first=Brad | title=Zelensky signs controversial law expanding government power to regulate media | website=The Hill | date=2023-01-02 | url=https://thehill.com/homenews/3795160-zelensky-signs-controversial-law-expanding-government-power-to-regulate-media/ | access-date=2024-01-17 | archive-date=17 January 2024 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240117004225/https://thehill.com/homenews/3795160-zelensky-signs-controversial-law-expanding-government-power-to-regulate-media/ | url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="Patil 2022">{{cite web | last=Patil | first=Anushka | title=Zelensky Signs Controversial News Media Regulation | website=The New York Times | date=2022-12-30 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/30/world/europe/zelensky-journalism-law-free-speech.html | access-date=2024-01-17 | archive-date=17 January 2024 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240117004226/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/30/world/europe/zelensky-journalism-law-free-speech.html | url-status=live }}</ref>
 
 According to a [[State Department]] report published in 2023 restrictions were placed on media freedoms enabling "an unprecedented level of control over primetime television news." Some speakers who criticised the government were blacklisted from government-directed news. The outlets and journalists who were considered a threat to the national security and who undermined the country's sovereignty and territorial integrity according to the authorities were blocked, banned or sanctioned.<ref>{{cite web |title=2023 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine |url=https://www.state.gov/reports/2023-country-reports-on-human-rights-practices/ukraine/ |website=U.S. Department of State |access-date=28 April 2024 |archive-date=24 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240424192004/https://www.state.gov/reports/2023-country-reports-on-human-rights-practices/ukraine/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[2010 Ukrainian presidential election|Viktor Yanukovych's election as president in February]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2010|work=rsf.org|date=2010|access-date=28 September 2015|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124050702/http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|archive-date=24 November 2010}}</ref> In 2013 Ukraine occupied the 126th spot (dropping 10 places compared with 2012); According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and southeastern regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/half-of-all-ukrainians-consider-current-freedom-of-50721.html|title=Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=15 October 2009|access-date=29 September 2015}}</ref>
+The ''[[Freedom in the World]]'' report by Freedom House rated Ukraine "partly free" from 1992<ref name="Kuchma" /> until 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2003?page=251&year=2003|title=Freedom of the Press 2003|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2003|access-date=28 September 2015|archive-date=29 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929200559/https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2003?page=251&year=2003|url-status=dead}}</ref> After 2005, it was rated "partly free" again.<ref name="RFH2010">{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2010?page=251&year=2010|title=Freedom of the Press 2010|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2010|access-date=28 September 2015|archive-date=18 September 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180918231053/https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2010?page=251&year=2010|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name="RFH2009">{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2009?page=251&year=2009|title=Freedom of the Press 2009|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2009|access-date=28 September 2015|archive-date=30 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150930080450/https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2009?page=251&year=2009|url-status=dead}}</ref> According to Freedom House [[internet in Ukraine]] is "Free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] is "Partly Free".<ref name="FHUkraine" />{{clarify|date=June 2017|reason=Convoluted. Is it the media or the country being qualified as 'free' and/or 'partly free'? Are civil liberties/human rights and press freedom being conflated?}}
+
+Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]s' [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2009|work=rsf.org|date=2009|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091022183400/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|archive-date=22 October 2009}}</ref> 87 in 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2008|work=rsf.org|date=2008|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607100340/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|archive-date=7 June 2009}}</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2002|work=rsf.org|date=October 2002|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703081345/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|archive-date=3 July 2009}}</ref> and even the 132nd spot in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2004|work=rsf.org|date=2004|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905174452/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|archive-date=5 September 2009}}</ref> In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[2010 Ukrainian presidential election|Viktor Yanukovych's election as president in February]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2010|work=rsf.org|date=2010|access-date=28 September 2015|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124050702/http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|archive-date=24 November 2010}}</ref> In 2013 Ukraine occupied the 126th spot (dropping 10 places compared with 2012); (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|title=Press Freedom Index 2013|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|access-date=29 September 2015|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151013163532/http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|archive-date=13 October 2015}}</ref> In the 2017 World Press Freedom Index Ukraine was placed 102nd.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://rsf.org/en/ranking|title=2017 World Press Freedom Index {{!}} Reporters Without Borders|work=RSF|access-date=2017-12-09|language=en|archive-date=3 October 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201003131858/https://rsf.org/en/ranking|url-status=live}}</ref>
+
+During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and southeastern regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/half-of-all-ukrainians-consider-current-freedom-of-50721.html|title=Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=15 October 2009|access-date=29 September 2015|archive-date=30 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150930031002/http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/half-of-all-ukrainians-consider-current-freedom-of-50721.html|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 In a late 2010 poll also conducted by the Research & Branding Group 56% of all Ukrainians trusted the media and 38.5% didn't.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/|title=Poll: More than half of Ukrainians trust the media|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=17 December 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110120213543/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/93128/|archive-date=20 January 2011}}</ref>
 
 === Kuchma presidencies (1994–2004) ===
 [[File:Georgi gongadse.jpg|thumbnail|[[Georgiy Gongadze]], [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] journalist, founder of the popular Internet newspaper ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]'', who was kidnapped and murdered in 2000.]]
 
-After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref name="HayozLushnycky2005">{{cite book|last1=Hayoz|first1=Nicolas|last2=Lushnycky|first2=Andrej N.|editor1=Nicolas Hayoz|editor2=Andrej N. Lushnycky|title=Ukraine at a Crossroads|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC|access-date=19 June 2017|year=2005|publisher=[[Peter Lang (publisher)|Peter Lang]]|isbn=978-3-03910-468-0|page=21|chapter=Prologue: Ukraine's New Deal}}</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to him were forcefully closed.<ref name="Kuchma" /> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemies of the press.<ref name="Kuchma">{{cite book|editor1=Adrian Karatnycky|editor2=Alexander J. Motyl|editor2-link=Alexander J. Motyl|editor3=Amanda Schnetzer|title=Nations in Transit, 2001: Civil Society, Democracy, and Markets in East Central Europe and the Newly Independent States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397|year=2001|publisher=[[Transaction Publishers]]|isbn=978-0-7658-0897-4|page=397}}</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|title=Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=11 March 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905041903/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|archive-date=5 September 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (12 March 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name="USDoS1999" /> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name="USDoS2003" /><ref name="USDoS2004" /> Toward the very end of the [[2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name="USDoS2004" />
+After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref name="HayozLushnycky2005">{{cite book|last1=Hayoz|first1=Nicolas|last2=Lushnycky|first2=Andrej N.|editor1=Nicolas Hayoz|editor2=Andrej N. Lushnycky|title=Ukraine at a Crossroads|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC|access-date=19 June 2017|year=2005|publisher=[[Peter Lang (publisher)|Peter Lang]]|isbn=978-3-03910-468-0|page=21|chapter=Prologue: Ukraine's New Deal|archive-date=21 September 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230921120347/https://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC|url-status=live}}</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to him were forcefully closed.<ref name="Kuchma" /> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemies of the press.<ref name="Kuchma">{{cite book|editor1=Adrian Karatnycky|editor2=Alexander J. Motyl|editor2-link=Alexander J. Motyl|editor3=Amanda Schnetzer|title=Nations in Transit, 2001: Civil Society, Democracy, and Markets in East Central Europe and the Newly Independent States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397|year=2001|publisher=[[Transaction Publishers]]|isbn=978-0-7658-0897-4|page=397}}</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|title=Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=11 March 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905041903/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|archive-date=5 September 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100314215451/http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html |date=14 March 2010 }}, [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (12 March 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name="USDoS1999" /> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name="USDoS2003" /><ref name="USDoS2004" /> Toward the very end of the [[2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name="USDoS2004" />
 
 === Orange revolution and Yushchenko presidency (2004–2010) ===
-Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media have become more pluralistic and independent.<ref name="FHouse2007" /><ref name="organge">[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (28 April 2006 )</ref><ref name="USDoS2007">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (6 March 2007)</ref> For instance, attempts by authorities to limit freedom of the press through tax inspections have ceased.<ref name="USDoS2003">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (25 February  ===Yanukovych presidency (2010-2013)===
-Since [[Viktor Yanukovych]] was elected [[President of Ukraine]] in February 2010 Ukrainian journalists and international journalistic watchdogs (including the [[European Federation of Journalists]] and [[Reporters Without Borders]]) have complained about a deterioration of press freedom in Ukraine.<ref name="YanFP2">{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66011/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101114182039/https://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66011/|archive-date = 2010-11-14|title = 1+1 TV journalists claim censorship of news reports|work = [[Kyiv Post]]|date = 6 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66119/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100511155833/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66119/|archive-date = 2010-05-11|title = STB TV channel journalists claim imposing of censorship on STB|work = [[Kyiv Post]]|date = 8 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66353/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101111043811/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66353/|archive-date =11 November 2010|title = European journalists call on Ukrainian authorities, media owners to respect press freedom|work = [[Kyiv Post]]|agency = Interfax-Ukraine|date = 11 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author = Anthony Mills|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101123070848/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/|archive-date =23 November 2010|title = International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'significantly'|work = [[Kyiv Post]]|date = 11 August 2010}}</ref> Yanukovych responded (in May 2010) that he "deeply values press freedom" and that "free, independent media that must ensure society's unimpeded access to information".<ref name="YanFP2" /> Anonymous journalists stated early May 2010 that they were voluntarily tailoring their coverage so as not to offend the Yanukovych administration and the [[First Azarov government|Azarov Government]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100510052659/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66009/ Journalists, in defensive crouch, swing news coverage to Yanukovych's favor], [[Kyiv Post]] (6 May 2009)</ref> The Azarov Government denies censoring the media,<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110606044659/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66616/ Semynozhenko: No examples of censorship on Ukrainian TV channels], [[Kyiv Post]] (13 May 2009)</ref> so did the [[Presidential Administration of Ukraine|Presidential Administration]]<ref Post]] (13 May 2009)</ref> and President Yanukovych himself.<ref>{{in lang|uk}} [http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/ukraine/2010/05/100513_yanukovych_marta_oh.shtml Янукович: Україна готова, якщо Європа готова], [[BBC Ukrainian]] (10 May 2010)</ref> [[Presidential Administration of Ukraine|Presidential Administration]] Deputy Head [[Hanna Herman]] stated on 13 May 2010 that the opposition benefited from discussions about the freedom of the press in Ukraine and also suggested that the recent reaction of foreign journalists organizations had been provoked by the opposition.<ref name="AHer134" /> On 12 May 2010, the [[Ukrainian Parliament|parliamentary]] committee for freedom of speech and information called on the [[General Prosecutor of Ukraine|General Prosecutor]]'s Office to immediately investigate complaints by journalists of pressure on journalists and censorship.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110606044759/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66628/ Special committee calls to check reports of pressure on journalists], [[Kyiv Post]] (13 May 2009)</ref> Also in May 2010 the Stop Censorship movement was founded by more than 500 journalist.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Paschyn|first1=Christina Maria|title=Ukraine: Journalists Face Uncertain Future|url=http://pulitzercenter.org/reporting/ukraine-journalists-face-uncertain-future|access-date=21 April 2017|work=Pulitzer Center|date=28 October 2010}}</ref>
+Since [[Viktor Yanukovych]] was elected [[President of Ukraine]] in February 2010 Ukrainian journalists and international journalistic watchdogs (including the [[European Federation of Journalists]] and [[Reporters Without Borders]]) have complained about a deterioration of press freedom in Ukraine.<ref name="YanFP2">{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66011/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101114182039/https://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66011/|archive-date = 2010-11-14|title = 1+1 TV journalists claim censorship of news reports|work = [[Kyiv Post]]|date = 6 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66119/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100511155833/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66119/|archive-date = 2010-05-11|title = STB TV channel journalists claim imposing of censorship on STB|work = [[Kyiv Post]]|date = 8 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66353/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101111043811/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66353/|archive-date =11 November 2010|title = European journalists call on Ukrainian authorities, media owners to respect press freedom|work = [[Kyiv Post]]|agency = Interfax-Ukraine|date = 11 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author = Anthony Mills|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101123070848/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/|archive-date =23 November 2010|title = International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'significantly'|work = [[Kyiv Post]]|date = 11 August 2010}}</ref> Yanukovych responded (in May 2010) that he "deeply values press freedom" and that "free, independent media that must ensure society's unimpeded access to information".<ref name="YanFP2" /> Anonymous journalists stated early May 2010 Government]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100510052659/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66009/ Journalists, in defensive crouch, swing news coverage to Yanukovych's favor], [[Kyiv Post]] (13 May 2009)</ref> and President Yanukovych himself.<ref>{{in lang|uk}} [http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/ukraine/2010/05/100513_yanukovych_marta_oh.shtml Янукович: Україна готова, якщо Європа 2010)</ref> [[Presidential Administration of Ukraine|Presidential Administration]] Deputy Head [[Hanna Herman]] stated on 13 May 2010 that the opposition benefited from discussions about the freedom  A law on strengthening the protection of the ownership of [[mass media]] offices, [[publishing house]]s, bookshops and distributors, as well as [[creative unions]] was passed by the [[Ukrainian Parliament]] on 20 May 2010.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100523192802/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/67398/ Parliament bans forced removal of state and municipal mass media offices], [[Kyiv Post]] (21 May 2009)</ref>
 
 Since the February 2010 election of Viktor Yanukovych as President Media watchdogs have stated attacks and pressure on journalists have increased.<ref name="sinceFeb2010" /> The [[International Press Institute]] addressed an open letter to President Yanukovych on 10 August 2010 urging him to address what the organisation saw as a disturbing deterioration in press freedom over the previous six months in Ukraine.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100811172630/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77815/ International Press Institute: Ukraine's press freedom environment has deteriorated 'significantly'], [[Kyiv Post]] (11 August 2010)</ref> [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe|PACE]] rapporteur Renate Wohlwend noticed on 6 October 2010 that "Some progress had been made in recent years but there had also been some retrograde steps".<ref name="PACE">[https://web.archive.org/web/20101007235843/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/85208/ European rapporteurs note media setback in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (6 October 2010)</ref> In January 2011 [[Freedom House]] stated it had perceived "negative trends in Ukraine" during 2010; these included: curbs on press freedom, the intimidation of [[civil society]], and greater [[Government of Ukraine|government]] influence on the [[Judicial system of Ukraine|judiciary]].<ref name="negative trends 2010" />
 
-According to the [[US Department of State]] in 2009 there were no attempts by central authorities to direct media content, but there were reports of intimidation of journalists by national and local officials.<ref name="USDoS2009">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136063.htm 2009 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (11 March 2010)</ref> Media at times demonstrated a tendency toward self‑censorship on matters that the government deemed sensitive.<ref name="USDoS2009" /><ref name="USDoS2008">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/eur/119110.htm 2008 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (25 February 2009)</ref> Stories in the electronic and printed media (veiled advertisements and positive coverage presented as news) and participation in a television talk show can be bought.<ref name="USDoS2009" /> Media watchdog groups have express concern over the extremely high monetary damages that were demanded in [[Judicial system of Ukraine|court cases]] concerning [[libel]].<ref name="USDoS2009" />
-
-In 2013 there were concerns over the corrupting influence of certain political figures, connected to the government of [[Viktor Yanukovych]] on Ukrainian media.<ref>[http://www.businessinsider.com.au/understanding-euromaidan-2014-1 "A Ukrainian Explains 10 Things The West Needs To Know About The Situation In Kyiv: #5 People find it hard to uncover the truth"], Taras Ilkiv, ''Business Insider'', 24 January 2014. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>

 === Euromaidan revolution and Poroshenko presidency (2014) ===
 [[File:Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, Kyiv. Events of February 18, 2014..jpg|thumbnail|Journalist documenting events at the Independence square. Clashes in Ukraine, [[Kyiv]]. Events of 18 February 2014.]]
-A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = 23 May 2014|website = Reuters}}</ref> The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kyiv (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. 
+A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|title = Ukraine media freedom under attack: OSCE|date = 23 May 2014|website = Reuters|access-date = 5 July 2021|archive-date = 23 June 2022|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20220623035015/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-media-idUSBREA4M0IB20140523|url-status = live}}</ref> The Ukrainian NGO [[Institute of Mass Information]] recorded at least 995 violations of free speech in 2014 - the double than in 2013 (496) and triple than in 2012 (324). Most attacks on journalists happened during the [[euromaidan]] period in Kyiv (82 in January, 70 in February 2014). 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. 
 In 2014 restrictions to press freedom in Ukraine included police impeding access to public buildings, physical attacks on press rooms, and cyberattacks (e.g. against the ''Glavnoe'', ''Gordon'' and [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]] websites); in July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" />
 
 Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media.<ref name="FH" /> Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too.  In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication.<ref name="FH" />
 
-[[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbas]] and discredit the Kyiv government.<ref name="FH" /> Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view.<ref name=":02" /> For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey "propaganda," and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.<ref name=":02" /><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014.</ref><ref name="FH" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|date=16 September 2015 |access-date=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|access-date=17 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |access-date=28 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="hrw201705" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Two more Russian journalists denied entry to Ukraine|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1911158-two-more-russian-journalists-denied-entry-to-ukraine.html|date=2017-05-07}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for "violating Ukraine's territorial integrity" brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].<ref name=":02">{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = 21 September 2014|website = The Christian Science Monitor}}</ref> The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a [[Kyiv]]-based digital newspaper "Vesti", physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". "Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones." Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = 9 November 2014|website = Huff Post Media}}</ref> ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.<ref name="FH" />|group=nb}}
-
-The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Information Policy]] was established on 2 December 2014.<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | access-date=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="FLUYGIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)<br />[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)<br />{{in lang|uk}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014)</ref> The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)|war in the Donbas region]].<ref name="FLUYGIU21214" /><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)</ref> [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".<ref name="PPsbiU812">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)</ref>
-
-On 16 May 2017 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning various Russian internet service providers and news sources, among others, [[VK (social networking)|VKontakte]], [[Odnoklassniki]], [[Yandex]], [[Rossiya Segodnya]], [[RBC Information Systems|RBC]], [[All-Russia State Television and Radio Broadcasting Company|VGTRK]], but also a number of independent stations such as the RBC, claiming this was done for "security reasons".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/421954.html|title=All of Ukrainian president's official pages on Russian social media sites being closed|work=Interfax-Ukraine|access-date=2017-05-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/ukraine-bans-dozens-of-russian-websites/3852930.html|title=Ukraine Bans Dozens of Russian Websites|last=News|first=VOA|work=VOA|access-date=2017-05-16|language=en}}</ref> Tanya Cooper from [[Human Rights Watch]] called the decree: "a cynical, politically expedient attack on the right to information affecting millions of Ukrainians, and their personal and professional lives".<ref name="hrw201705">{{cite web|title=Ukraine: Revoke Ban on Dozens of Russian Web Companies|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/05/16/ukraine-revoke-ban-dozens-russian-web-companies|date=2017-05-15}}</ref> [[Reporters Without Borders]] (RSF) also condemned the ban imposed on Russian social networks.<ref name="rsf201705">{{cite web|title=RSF urges Ukraine to scrap ban on Russian social media sites |publisher=Reporters without borders |url=https://rsf.org/en/news/rsf-urges-ukraine-scrap-ban-russian-social-media-sites |date=23 May 2017 |access-date=26 October 2017}}</ref>
-
-Since November 2015 Ukrainian authorities, state agencies and local government authorities are forbidden to act as founders (or cofounders) of printed media outlets.<ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/306311.html Ukrainian state authorities can not be founders, cofounders of printed media from now on], [[Interfax Ukraine]] (24 November 2015)</ref>

+The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Information Policy]] was established on 2 December 2014.<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | access-date=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="FLUYGIU21214">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160312042607/http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html |date=12 March 2016 }}, [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)<br />[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151121045056/http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html |date=21 November 2015 }}, [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)<br />{{in lang|uk}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141210114547/http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ |date=10 December 2014 }}, [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014)</ref> The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)|war in the Donbas region]].<ref name="FLUYGIU21214" /><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)</ref> [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".<ref name="PPsbiU812">[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141211115628/http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html |date=11 December 2014 }}, [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014)</ref>
+

+Since November 2015 Ukrainian authorities, state agencies and local government authorities are forbidden to act as founders (or cofounders) of printed media outlets.<ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/306311.html Ukrainian state authorities can not be founders, cofounders of printed media from now on] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125040807/http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/306311.html |date=25 November 2015 }}, [[Interfax Ukraine]] (24 November 2015)</ref>
 
 Freedom House reported the status of press freedom in [[Ukraine]] in 2015 as improving from Not Free to Partly Free. It justified the change as follows:<ref name=FH>[[Freedom House]], [https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine Ukraine 2015 Freedom of the Press] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181116115122/https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2015/ukraine |date=16 November 2018 }} report</ref>
 <blockquote>due to profound changes in the media environment after the fall of President Viktor Yanukovych's government in February, despite a rise in attacks on journalists during the Euromaidan protests of early 2014 and the subsequent conflict in eastern Ukraine. The level of government hostility and legal pressure faced by journalists decreased, as did political pressure on state-owned outlets. The media also benefited from improvements to the law on access to information and the increased independence of the broadcasting regulator.</blockquote>

 == Attacks and threats against journalists ==
-Ukraine was one of the most dangerous places for journalists in the world during the [[euromaidan]] demonstrations and the [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)|war in Donbas]]. A May 2014 report from the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] found approximately 300 instances of perceived violent attacks on the media in Ukraine since November 2013.<ref name=":0"/> 78 journalists were abducted and illegally detained by various groups in 2014 - a new category of professional risk; 20 such cases happened in Donetsk in April 2014. In July 2014 a firebomb was thrown at the TV channel ''[[112 Ukraine]]''.<ref name="FH" /> In September 2016 [[Inter (TV channel)|Inter]] TV channel - often accused of being pro-Russia - was put to fire during a protest.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pro-Russia TV station in Kyiv evacuated after fire|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/05/pro-russia-tv-inter-kiev-evacuated-fire-ukraine|access-date=19 April 2017|work=The Guardian|date=5 September 2016}}</ref>
-
-[[Amnesty International]] has appealed for the release of Ukrainian journalist [[Ruslan Kotsaba]] and declared him a [[prisoner of conscience]].{{#tag:ref|On 10 February 2015, [[Amnesty International]] reported that a Ukrainian journalist, [[Ruslan Kotsaba]], was accused and arrested by Ukrainian authorities for "treason and obstructing the military" in reaction to his statement that he would rather go to prison than be drafted by the Ukrainian Army. If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15-year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.<ref>{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kyiv struggles to find new fighters |work=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |access-date=4 October 2015}}</ref>| nb}}

 The Government of Ukraine started banning books in 2016 that a special committee (State Committee for State TV and Radio Broadcasting's licensing and distribution-control department) had determined to contain anti-Ukrainian content.
 
-In January 2018, the Russian version of British historian [[Antony Beevor]]'s ''[[Stalingrad (Beevor book)|Stalingrad]]'' was added to this list. The head of the committee, Serhiy Oliyinyk, told [[Radio Free Europe]] that one particular reason was that Beevor had included information about Ukrainian militia killing 90 Jewish children on orders of the SS "to save the feelings of the [[Sonderkommando]]." He claimed this had never been confirmed at post-war trials and was taken from Soviet sources.  == Internet censorship and surveillance ==
-{{Main|Internet in Ukraine#Internet censorship and surveillance}}In December 2010 the [[OpenNet Initiative]] found little or no evidence of Internet filtering in all four areas (political, social, conflict/security, and Internet tools) for which they test.<ref name="ONI-UkraineProfile-Dec2010">[http://opennet.net/research/profiles/ukraine "ONI Country Profile: Ukraine"], OpenNet Initiative, 21 December 2010</ref>
+{{Main|Internet in Ukraine#Internet censorship and surveillance}}In December 2010 the [[OpenNet Initiative]] found little or no evidence of Internet filtering in all four areas (political, social, conflict/security, and Internet tools) for which they test.<ref name="ONI-UkraineProfile-Dec2010">[http://opennet.net/research/profiles/ukraine "ONI Country Profile: Ukraine"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105224145/https://opennet.net/research/profiles/ukraine |date=5 November 2013 }}, OpenNet Initiative, 21 December 2010</ref>
 
 In its ''Freedom on the Net'' report covering the period May 2012 through April 2013, [[Freedom House]] found the Internet in Ukraine to be "largely unhindered" and rated the Internet in Ukraine as "Free" with an overall score of 28 on a scale from 0 (most free) to 100 (least free). The report said that "there is no practice of institutionalized blocking or filtering, or a regulatory framework for censorship of content online", but "there have been attempts at creating legislation which could censor or limit content" and would "present indirect threats to freedom of information online."<ref name="FOTN-Ukraine-2013">[http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-net/2013/ukraine#.UvJZil6togE "Ukraine"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180926085818/https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-net/2013/ukraine#.UvJZil6togE |date=26 September 2018 }}, ''Freedom on the Net 2013'', Freedom House, 30 September 2013. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
 
-As of 2012, access to Internet content in Ukraine was largely unfettered. Ukraine possessed relatively liberal legislation governing the Internet and access to information. While there were no government restrictions on access to the Internet, law enforcement bodies were known to monitor the Internet, at times without appropriate legal authority. There have been occasional agitations of interference by law enforcement agencies with prominent bloggers and online publications.<ref name="USDOS-CRHRP-Ukraine-2012">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/humanrightsreport/index.htm?year=2012&dlid=204349 "Ukraine"], ''Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 2012'', Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, U.S. Department of State, 15 April 2013. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>

-In 2014 it was reported that the [[Security Service of Ukraine]] (SBU) asked the [[Ukrainian Internet Association]] (UIA) to block a list of websites accused of "promote war, ethnic hatred, and violent change in the constitutional order or territorial integrity of Ukraine." Such orders should, however, come from courts of law and not security agencies.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Howell O'Neill|first1=Patrick|title=Ukraine seeks to block separatist websites and Russian blogs|url=https://www.dailydot.com/layer8/ukraine-blocks-russian-websites/|access-date=21 April 2017|work=The Daily Dot|date=4 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Russia-Ukraine Internet Censorship War Rages On|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/the-russia-ukraine-internet-censorship-war-rages-on|access-date=20 April 2017|work=Motherboard|date=5 August 2014}}</ref>

-On 16 May 2017, [[Petro Poroshenko|President Poroshenko]] signed a decree requiring providers to block access to a number of Russian websites including four of the most popular websites in Ukraine: [[VK (social networking)|VKontakte]], [[Odnoklassniki]], [[Yandex]] and [[Mail.Ru]]. The president claimed they participated in an information war against Ukraine.<ref name=guardian-20170516>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/16/ukraine-blocks-popular-russian-websites-kremlin-role-war |title=Ukraine blocks popular social networks as part of sanctions on Russia |last=Luhn |first=Alec |newspaper=The Guardian |date=16 May 2017 |access-date=17 June 2017}}</ref>
+As of 2012, access to Internet content in Ukraine was largely unfettered. Ukraine possessed relatively liberal legislation governing the Internet and access to information. While there were no government restrictions on access to the Internet, law enforcement bodies were known to monitor the Internet, at times without appropriate legal authority. There have been occasional agitations of interference by law enforcement agencies with prominent bloggers and online publications.<ref name="USDOS-CRHRP-Ukraine-2012">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/humanrightsreport/index.htm?year=2012&dlid=204349 "Ukraine"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210331104539/https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/humanrightsreport/index.htm?year=2012&dlid=204349 |date=31 March 2021 }}, ''Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 2012'', Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, U.S. Department of State, 15 April 2013. Retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref>
+
+In 2014 it was reported that the [[Security Service of Ukraine]] (SBU) asked the [[Ukrainian Internet Association]] (UIA) to block a list of websites accused of "promote war, ethnic hatred, and violent change in the constitutional order or territorial integrity of Ukraine." Such orders should, however, come from courts of law and not security agencies.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Howell O'Neill|first1=Patrick|title=Ukraine seeks to block separatist websites and Russian blogs|url=https://www.dailydot.com/layer8/ukraine-blocks-russian-websites/|access-date=21 April 2017|work=The Daily Dot|date=4 August 2014|archive-date=21 April 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170421194618/https://www.dailydot.com/layer8/ukraine-blocks-russian-websites/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Russia-Ukraine Internet Censorship War Rages On|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/the-russia-ukraine-internet-censorship-war-rages-on|access-date=20 April 2017|work=Motherboard|date=5 August 2014|archive-date=22 April 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170422032937/https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/the-russia-ukraine-internet-censorship-war-rages-on|url-status=live}}</ref>
+
+On 16 May 2017, [[Petro Poroshenko|President Poroshenko]] signed a decree requiring providers to block access to a number of Russian websites including four of the most popular websites in Ukraine: [[VK (social networking)|VKontakte]], [[Odnoklassniki]], [[Yandex]] and [[Mail.Ru]]. The president claimed they participated in an information war against Ukraine.<ref name=guardian-20170516>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/16/ukraine-blocks-popular-russian-websites-kremlin-role-war |title=Ukraine blocks popular social networks as part of sanctions on Russia |last=Luhn |first=Alec |newspaper=The Guardian |date=16 May 2017 |access-date=17 June 2017 |archive-date=23 May 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170523092549/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/16/ukraine-blocks-popular-russian-websites-kremlin-role-war |url-status=live }}</ref>

 '''Transparency of media ownership''' refers to the public availability of accurate, comprehensive and up-to-date information about media ownership structures. A legal regime guaranteeing transparency of media ownership makes possible for the public as well as for media authorities to find out who effectively owns, controls and influences the media as well as media influence on political parties or state bodies.
 
-The lack of transparency on media ownership has typically been a negative trait of the [[Media of Ukraine|Ukrainian media system]]. The law entered into force on 1 October 2015.<ref name=OSCE2015>{{cite web |url=http://www.osce.org/fom/187956  |title=OSCE Representative welcomes law on transparency of media ownership in Ukraine as it comes into force |date=1 October 2015 |website= [[Osce.org]] |publisher= Organisation for Security & Co-operation in Europe |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>

Legal framework |date=2016 |website=Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher=Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev) |access-date=12 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113165425/http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |archive-date=13 January 2017 |url-status=dead }}</ref> but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries.<ref name=OSCE2015/> These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications.<ref name=MOM/> Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine.<ref name=OSCE2015/> Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners.<ref name=LOC>{{cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website= Loc.gov |publisher= Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017}}</ref>
+The lack of transparency on media ownership has typically been a negative trait of the [[Media of Ukraine|Ukrainian media system]]. In 2005 [[Ukraine]] committed itself to the [[Council of Europe]] to introduce a law for ensuring transparency of media ownership, according to the Resolution 1466 (2005)1 of the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]].<ref name=COE>{{cite web |url=http://www.coe.int/en/web/kyiv/-/transparency-media-ownership-in-ukraine-key-issue-at-the-international-conference-of-the-european-union-and-the-council-of-europe |title=Transparency media ownership in Ukraine – key issue at the international conference of the European Union and the Council of Europe |date=11 June 2015 |website=Coe.int |publisher=Council of Europe. Office in Ukraine |access-date=12 January 2017 |archive-date=13 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113151107/http://www.coe.int/en/web/kyiv/-/transparency-media-ownership-in-ukraine-key-issue-at-the-international-conference-of-the-european-union-and-the-council-of-europe |url-status=live }}</ref>
+
+In 2014, the [[European Commission]]'s progress report on the implementation of the [[European Neighbourhood Policy]] in Ukraine found the lack of transparency as an issue in the country and that proper legislative framework should be adopted.<ref name=COE/> To comply with its international commitment, legislation on transparency of media ownership has been reformed in 2015. On 10 September 2015, President [[Petro Poroshenko]] signed the law called "On Amendments to Several Laws of Ukraine on Ensuring the Transparency of Media Ownership and Implementing the Principles of state Policy in the Sphere of Television and Radio Broadcasting". The law entered into force on 1 October 2015.<ref name=OSCE2015>{{cite web |url=http://www.osce.org/fom/187956 |title=OSCE Representative welcomes law on transparency of media ownership in Ukraine as it comes into force |date=1 October 2015 |website=[[Osce.org]] |publisher=Organisation for Security & Co-operation in Europe |access-date=12 January 2017 |archive-date=1 April 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160401182540/http://www.osce.org/fom/187956 |url-status=live }}</ref>
+
+The new legal system regulating transparency of media ownership, which establishes a detailed system for guaranteeing transparency, has been appraised for its level of innovation by many international organisations and experts<ref name=MOM>{{cite web |url=http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |title=Media ownership monitor Ukraine. Legal framework |date=2016 |website=Ukraine.mom-rsf.org |publisher=Reporters Without Borders; Institute of Mass Information (Kyev) |access-date=12 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113165425/http://ukraine.mom-rsf.org/en/ukraine/context/law/ |archive-date=13 January 2017 |url-status=dead }}</ref> but still the effectiveness of its implementation remains to be seen. In general terms, the new regulation obliges broadcasts and program service providers to make public detailed information about their ownership structures and final beneficiaries.<ref name=OSCE2015/> These requirements apply to the audiovisual sector (TV and radio), print and information agencies but not to online publications.<ref name=MOM/> Also, the amendments prevent businesses and individuals registered offshore from establishing and owning broadcast companies and program service providers in Ukraine.<ref name=OSCE2015/> Moreover, the new law sets forth new financial disclosure rules for owners.<ref name=LOC>{{cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |title=Ukraine: New Law on TV Ownership |date=7 October 2015 |website=Loc.gov |publisher=Library of Congress |access-date=12 January 2017 |archive-date=13 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113133222/http://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/ukraine-new-law-on-tv-ownership/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
 
 Specifically, the new law amends article 12 of the existing Law of Ukraine on Television and Radio Broadcasting of 1994, establishing that national and local government authorities, individuals and legal entities which are registered offline, political parties, religious organisations, professional unions, and persons that were convicted by courts and that are still serving their sentences cannot be owners of a TV or radio stations in Ukraine. Furthermore, the Law prohibits to physical or legal persons residing in a country which is recognised as an aggressor or occupier the right to own a television or a radio station in Ukraine.<ref name=LOC/> This sentence refers to the [[Russia|Russian Federation]] which [[2014 Crimean status referendum|annexed Crimea]] in 2014.<ref name=LOC/> The Law provides a new definition of ownership which is closely connected to the exercise of a decisive influence in the management or business activity of the media outlet directly or through other persons and includes also final beneficiaries.<ref name=LOC/> The Law requires that information on the ownership structure and on the individuals owning at least 10% or more of a television or radio broadcasting have to be made public on the company's website and sent to the National Council for Questions of Television and Radio Broadcasting, which is the national media regulator in Ukraine. According to the law, the council can impose fines when information provided are insufficient or incorrect.<ref name=LOC/>

The entire staff of ''Ostrov'' left the occupied Donbass areas and relocated to Kyiv. +Many Ukrainian journalists found themselves internally displaced due to the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]] and the [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)|war in Donbas]], including Donetsk-based investigative journalist Oleksiy Matsuka, Luhansk blogger Serhiy Ivanov and Donetsk ''Ostrov'' independent website editor Serhiy Harmash. The entire staff of ''Ostrov'' left the occupied Donbas areas and relocated to Kyiv. ==History== [[File:RWB-PressFreedomIndex-WorldMap.svg|400px|thumb|right|'''2014 [[Press Freedom Index]]'''{{cite web|url=https://rsf.org/en/ranking/2014|title=World Press Freedom Index 2014|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|access-date=11 May 2014|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140214120404/http://rsf.org/index2014/en-index2014.php|archive-date=14 February 2014}} @@ -73,9 +73,9 @@ Political interference in the media sector greatly diminished after the flight of [[Yanukovych]] from Ukraine, with media outlets almost immediately starting to openly discuss the events of the previous months, including the moments of violence, which had previously been censored or self-censored through pressures on owners and managers. The [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media. Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too. In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication. -[[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbass]] and discredit the Kyiv government. Creating some concern among Western human rights monitors was that under the impact of war and perceived extreme social polarization the Ukrainian government has been accused of cracking down on pro-separatist points of view. For example, Ukraine also shut down most Russia-based television stations on the grounds that they purvey "propaganda," and barred a growing list of Russian journalists from entering the country.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August 2014.{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans journalists who 'threaten national interests' from country|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/16/ukraine-president-bans-journalists-from-country|website=The Guardian|date=16 September 2015 |access-date=17 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans dozens of foreign journalists as 'threats to national security|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11871144/Ukraine-bans-dozens-of-foreign-journalists-as-threats-to-national-security.html|website=The Telegraph|access-date=17 September 2015}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34282136 |title=Ukraine removes BBC journalists from banned list |agency=Bbc.com |date=17 September 2015 |access-date=28 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Two more Russian journalists denied entry to Ukraine|url=https://www.unian.info/society/1911158-two-more-russian-journalists-denied-entry-to-ukraine.html|date=2017-05-07}}{{#tag:ref|On 11 September 2014 the Russian-language newspaper ''Vesti'' was raided by the [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], which seized equipment and temporarily shut off its website, for "violating Ukraine's territorial integrity" brought swift condemnation from the international [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] and the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|OSCE]].{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = 21 September 2014|website = The Christian Science Monitor}} The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a [[Kyiv]]-based digital newspaper "Vesti", physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". "Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones." Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. He added that he is unsure of the reason for the raid, but suspects that it might have to do with a story the website recently published on the SBU chief's daughter.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/11/ukraine-news-raid-vesti-kiev-website-media_n_5805642.html|title = Ukraine Security Services Break into Newspaper Office, Shut Down Website|date = 9 November 2014|website = Huff Post Media}} ''Vesti'' had already been searched for money-laundering in May 2014.|group=nb}} - -The [[Ministry of Information Policy (Ukraine)|Ministry of Information Policy]] was established on 2 December 2014.{{cite press release |url=http://www.kmu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=247789675&cat_id=247077361 | title=Міністр інформаційної політики України | publisher=Supreme Council of Ukraine | date=2 December 2014 | access-date=2 December 2014}}[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/237576.html Rada supports coalition-proposed government lineup], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (2 December 2014)
[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/rada-approves-new-cabinet-with-three-former-foreigners-in-it-373861.html Rada approves new Cabinet with three foreigners], [[Kyiv Post]] (2 December 2014)
{{in lang|uk}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/12/2/7046214/ Rada voted the new Cabinet], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (2 December 2014) The ministry oversees information policy in Ukraine. According to the first Minister of Information, [[Yuriy Stets]], one of the goals of its formation was to counteract "[[Media portrayal of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|Russian information aggression]]" amidst [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest across Ukraine]], and the ongoing [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)|war in the Donbass region]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20141202151021/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/584095/ Ukraine must establish Information Policy Ministry], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (2 December 2014) [[Ukrainian president]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] said that the main function of the ministry is to stop "the spreading of biased information about Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014) +[[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbas]] and discredit the Kyiv government. country.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-television-idUSKBN0GJ1QM20140819 "Ukraine bans Russian TV channels for airing war 'propaganda' "], Natalia Zinets, Reuters, 19 August web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2014/0921/Crackdown-in-Ukraine-sullies-its-democratic-aspirations|title = Crackdown in Ukraine sullies its democratic aspirations|date = 21 September 2014|website = The Christian Science Monitor}} The Ukrainian Security Service (SBU) broke into the office of a [[Kyiv]]-based digital newspaper "Vesti", physically trapping reporters and ultimately shutting down the website. Vesti News's editor-in-chief Igor Guzhva wrote on his Facebook page that the news outlet had been raided by SBU. The SBU reportedly took all servers, kept staffers in a "hot corridor" and shut down the website completely. Guzhva said that the purpose of the raid was "to block our work.". "Journalists are not being let into their office," Guzhva wrote. "Those who were already inside at the moment of the raid are being kept in the building and are not allowed to use cell phones." Guzhva said that this is the second time in just six months that the SBU has tried to "intimidate" its editors. Ukraine".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/238615.html Poroshenko: Information Ministry's main task is to repel information attacks against Ukraine], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 December 2014) On 16 May 2017 president Poroshenko signed a decree banning various Russian internet service providers and news sources, among others, [[VK (social networking)|VKontakte]], [[Odnoklassniki]], closed|work=Interfax-Ukraine|access-date=2017-05-16}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/ukraine-bans-dozens-of-russian-websites/3852930.html|title=Ukraine Bans Dozens of Russian Websites|last=News|first=VOA|work=VOA|access-date=2017-05-16|language=en}} Tanya Cooper from [[Human Rights Watch]] called the decree: "a cynical, politically expedient attack on the right to |url=https://rsf.org/en/news/rsf-urges-ukraine-scrap-ban-russian-social-media-sites |date=23 May 2017 |access-date=26 October 2017}} @@ -422,7 +422,7 @@ |} == Attacks and threats against journalists
