+! 14 December 2003
+| '''[[Volodymyr Karachevtsev]]''', 47, deputy editor-in-chief of [[Kuryer newspaper]], was found dead in his home in [[Melitopol]]. He was discovered hanging from the handle of his refrigerator. Karachevtsev was also chairman of the regional independent union of journalists and a correspondent for the online publication, Vlasti.net. Police did not rule out the possibility of murder.<ref name="killed" />
+|-
+! 3 March 2004
+| '''[[Yuriy Chechyk]]''', director of [[Radio Yuta]] in [[Poltava]], died under suspicious circumstances in a car crash. He was on the way to meet with executives of [[Radio Liberty]]'s Ukrainian Service, which is often critical of the [[Ukrainian government]], to hold talks on rebroadcasting the station's programmes on the more accessible FM band.<ref name="killed" /> 
+|-
+!data-sort-value="2010-08-01" |  August 2010
+| '''[[Vasyl Klymentyev]]''', a Ukrainian investigative journalist, editor-in-chief of the newspaper [[Novy Stil]] based in [[Kharkiv]]. He went missing in August and is presumed dead. He had been investigating local corruption.<ref name=Guard>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/sep/08/ukraine-press-freedom ''Missing, presumed dead: disappearance of Ukrainian journalist deepens media fears''], Guardian</ref> 
+|-
+! 20 February 2014
+| '''[[Ihor Kostenko]]''', a 22-year-old Ukrainian journalist from the newspaper Sportanalytic, also a geography student and contributor to the [[Ukrainian Wikipedia]]. He died during [[Euromaidan]].<ref name="wiki-ukr">{{cite web|url=http://wikimediaukraine.wordpress.com/2014/02/23/in-memoriam-of-ihor-kostenko/ |publisher=Wikimedia Ukraine |title=In memoriam of Ihor Kostenko|date=23 February 2014}} {{in lang|uk}}</ref> 
+|-
+! 24 May 2014
+| '''[[Andrea Rocchelli]]''', Italian photojournalist killed in unclear circumstances while covering the [[Siege of Sloviansk]].<ref name="Ronchelli">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/may/25/italian-journalist-andrea-ronchelli-believed-killed-ukraine|title=Italian journalist Andrea Ronchelli killed in Ukraine|publisher=The Guardian|date=2014-05-25|access-date=2014-05-29}}{{dead link|date=December 2014}}</ref> Ronchelli's Russian interpreter, Andrey Mironov, was also killed.<ref name=Ronchelli/> French photographer [[William Roguelon]] told Russian television that Rocchelli and Mironov were killed while trying to escape mortar fire, and that he himself was wounded in the incident.<ref name=Ronchelli/>  <!-- THE CORRECT SPELLING IS "ROCCHELLI"; CF. ON IT:WIKI. "RONCHELLI" IS A WIDESPREAD MISTAKE -->
+|-
+! 17 June 2014
+| '''[[Killing of Igor Kornelyuk and Anton Voloshin|Igor Kornelyuk]]''', Russian reporter died in hospital of wounds. According to a spokesperson of the [[Luhansk People's Republic]], previously he was caught in a mortar firefight staged by Ukrainian forces and his fate along with Voloshin and other 15 rebels who were with them was not known.<ref name="Kornelyuk">{{cite news|url=https://uk.news.yahoo.com/russian-reporter-dies-wounds-east-ukraine-115549647.html#zGWVy1o|title=Russian reporter 'dies of wounds' in east Ukraine|publisher=Yahoo! News UK|date=2014-06-17|access-date=2014-06-17}}</ref> 
+'''[[Killing of Igor Kornelyuk and Anton Voloshin|Anton Voloshin]]''', sound engineer, killed in same incident. <ref>http://www.svoboda.org/content/article/25425897.html</ref>
+|-
+! 29 June 2014
+| '''[[Anatoly Klyan]]''', Russian cameraman for Russia's [[Channel One Russia|Channel One]] was shot in the stomach as the bus he was riding in came under fire by Ukrainian forces near the entrance to a military base in Donetsk, according to [[Moscow Times]]. Klyan was in a bus with mothers of soldiers who reportedly wanted to negotiate with the Ukrainian troops. Klyan died shortly afterwards. Ukrainian officials promised to investigate the incident.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/anatoly-klyan-death-russian-cameraman-fatally-shot-in-ukraine-by-government-forces-9574289.html|title=Anatoly Klyan death: Russian cameraman fatally shot in Ukraine 'by government forces'|publisher=The Independent|date=2014-06-30|access-date=2014-06-29}}</ref>
+|-
+!data-sort-value="2014-11-01" |  November 2014
+| '''[[Aleksandr Kuchinsky]]''', prominent crime reporter, and his wife were murdered.<ref>[http://obozrevatel.com/politics/40852-v-slavyanskom-rajone-ubityi-izvestnyij-zhurnalist-i-ego-zhena.htm Obozrevatel], ''На Донбассе убили журналиста. Вместе с женой [Journalist killed in Donbas. Together with his wife]'', 29 November 2014.</ref>
+|-
+! 28 February 2014
+| '''[[Serhiy Nikolayev]]''', photojournalist for ''Segodnya'' in Kyiv, Ukraine, killed by shelling crossfire.<ref name=theguardian>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/01/ukrainian-photographer-killed-in-fighting|title=Ukrainian photographer killed in fighting|work=The Guardian}}</ref>
+|-
+!data-sort-value="2015-04-01" |  April 2015
+| '''[[Olga Moroz (journalist)|Olga Moroz]]''', editor of the ''Neteshinsky Vestnik''<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.novinite.com/articles/167954/Another+Ukrainian+Journalist+Found+Dead%2C+Murder+Suspected|title=Another Ukrainian Journalist Found Dead, Murder Suspected|work=Novinte|location=Sofia, Bulgaria|date=17 April 2022|access-date=31 January 2022}}</ref>
+|-
+! 16 April 2015
+| '''[[Oles Buzina]]''', journalist and writer.<ref>[http://www.france24.com/en/20150416-ukraine-prominent-journalist-oles-buzina-shot-dead-kiev/ Prominent Pro-Russian Ukrainian journalist killed in Kiev]</ref>
+|-
+! 20 July 2016
+|'''[[Pavel Sheremet]]''' Belarusian journalist, who was a critic of [[Media freedom in Russia|Russian censorship]], killed by a car bomb.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/21/world/europe/pavel-sheremet-kiev-car-bomb.html?_r=0</ref><ref>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/20/ukraine-journalist-pavel-sheremet-killed-kiev-car-bombing</ref><ref>http://www.dw.com/en/journalist-pavel-sheremets-murder-shocks-ukraine/a-19414665</ref>
+|-
+! 13 March 2022
+|'''[[Brent Renaud]]''', an American journalist, was killed in Ukraine. He was shot by Russian soldiers.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/13/world/europe/brent-renaud-irpin.html</ref>
+|-
+! 15 March 2022
+| '''[[Pierre Zakrzewski]]''' had been travelling in a vehicle near Kyiv; he was killed by Russian soldiers.<ref>http://news.sky.com/story/ukraine-war-fox-news-cameraman-killed-by-incoming-fire-outside-of-kyiv-12566885</ref>
+|-
+|}
 
 ==Missing reporters==
 * [[Sergei Dolgov]], a newspaper editor from Mariupol, went missing in June 2014 during the [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)|war in Donbas]] and is presumed dead by some mostly pro-Russian sources.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ria.ru/world/20140716/1016243602.html|title=Newspaper workers don't know chief editor's whereabouts|work=ria.ru|access-date=15 July 2016|archive-date=18 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160918115931/https://ria.ru/world/20140716/1016243602.html|url-status=live}}</ref>
llm_output:
The change made is the addition of a detailed timeline of reporters killed in Ukraine, which includes specific names, dates, and circumstances surrounding their deaths. 

Weaponised. The inclusion of this timeline emphasizes the violence against journalists in Ukraine, which can be interpreted as a critique of the situation in the country, potentially framing it within a narrative of oppression and danger, particularly in the context of the ongoing conflict.

In September 2015 Freedom House classified the [[Internet in Ukraine]] as "partly free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] as "partly free".{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/country/ukraine|title=Ukraine|work=freedomhouse.org|access-date=28 September 2015|archive-date=10 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150910040040/https://freedomhouse.org/country/ukraine|url-status=live}} Ukraine was in 102nd place out of 180 countries listed in the 2017 [[World Press Freedom Index]]. In 2017 organizations like [[Reporters Without Borders]], [[Human Rights Watch]] and [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] condemned then Poroshenko's government recent bans on media.{{cite web|title=Ukraine bans independent Russian TV channel Dozhd|url=https://rsf.org/en/news/ukraine-bans-independent-russian-tv-channel-dozhd|date=2017-01-13|access-date=16 June 2017|archive-date=26 October 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171026162752/https://rsf.org/en/news/ukraine-bans-independent-russian-tv-channel-dozhd|url-status=live}}{{cite web|url=https://cpj.org/2017/05/ukraine-bans-russian-media-outlets-websites.php|title=Ukraine bans Russian media outlets, websites|publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists|date=17 May 2017|access-date=19 June 2017|archive-date=29 June 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170629223050/https://cpj.org/2017/05/ukraine-bans-russian-media-outlets-websites.php|url-status=live}}{{Cite web|url=https://cpj.org/europe/ukraine/|title=Ukraine|website=cpj.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-11|archive-date=15 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180515101415/https://cpj.org/europe/ukraine/|url-status=live}} === Russian invasion and Zelensky presidency (2019-present) === -On March 3, 2022, the Criminal Code of Ukraine was supplemented by Article 436-2, titled "Justification, recognition as legitimate, denial of the armed aggression of the Russian Federation against Ukraine, glorification of its participants". The article, which has been criticized by the [[OHCHR]] and other human rights groups,{{cite web |title=Report On The Human Rights Situation In Ukraine |url=https://www.ohchr.org/en/documents/country-reports/report-human-rights-situation-ukraine-1-august-2022-31-january-2023 |publisher=OHCHR |language=English |access-date=2023-09-21 |archive-date=2023-09-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230925201134/https://www.ohchr.org/en/documents/country-reports/report-human-rights-situation-ukraine-1-august-2022-31-january-2023 |url-status=live }}{{cite web |title=Criminal liability for collaborationism: analysis of current legislation, practice of its application, and proposals for amendments |date=23 December 2022 |url=https://zmina.ua/en/publication-en/criminal-liability-for-collaborationism-analysis-of-current-legislation-practice-of-its-application-and-proposals-for-amendments/ |publisher=ZMINA |language=English |access-date=21 September 2023 |archive-date=25 July 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230725131437/https://zmina.ua/en/publication-en/criminal-liability-for-collaborationism-analysis-of-current-legislation-practice-of-its-application-and-proposals-for-amendments/ |url-status=live }} states punishment by correctional labor up to two years or imprisonment up to eight years for such speech.{{cite web |title=Criminal Code of Ukraine - Amendments |url=https://zakon-rada-gov-ua.translate.goog/laws/show/2110-20/print?_x_tr_sl=auto&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=wapp |publisher=Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine |language=English |access-date=1 February 2024 |archive-date=22 August 2023 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20230822214703/https://zakon-rada-gov-ua.translate.goog/laws/show/2110-20/print?_x_tr_sl=auto&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=wapp |url-status=bot: unknown }} [[Gonzalo Lira]], an American pro-Russia blogger living in Ukraine, was among those arrested under this law.{{cite web | last=Shoaib | first=Alia | title=Tucker Carlson and Elon Musk have rallied behind an American 'red pill' dating coach turned Russian propagandist detained in Ukraine | website=Business Insider | date=2023-12-17 | url=https://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musk-tucker-carlson-us-red-pill-youtuber-detained-ukraine-2023-12 | access-date=2024-01-17}} - -On December 30, 2022, President [[Volodymyr Zelensky]] signed into law a bill that would expand the power of government to regulate media outlets and journalists in the country, over the objections of journalists and international press freedom groups.{{cite web | last=Dress | first=Brad | title=Zelensky signs controversial law expanding government power to regulate media | website=The Hill | date=2023-01-02 | url=https://thehill.com/homenews/3795160-zelensky-signs-controversial-law-expanding-government-power-to-regulate-media/ | access-date=2024-01-17}}{{cite web | last=Patil | first=Anushka | title=Zelensky Signs Controversial News Media Regulation | website=The New York Times | date=2022-12-30 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/30/world/europe/zelensky-journalism-law-free-speech.html | access-date=2024-01-17}} - If found guilty he could potentially can face up to 15-year prison sentence. [[Amnesty International]] has appealed to Ukrainian authorities to free him immediately and declared Kotsaba a [[prisoner of conscience]]. Tetiana Mazur, director of Amnesty International in Ukraine stated that "the Ukrainian authorities are violating the key human right of freedom of thought, which Ukrainians stood up for on the Maidan." In response the [[Ukrainian Security Service]] (SBU) declared that they have found "evidence of serious crimes" but declined to elaborate.{{cite news |author=Shaun Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |title=Ukraine: draft dodgers face jail as Kyiv struggles to find new fighters |work=The Guardian |date=11 February 2015 |access-date=4 October 2015 |archive-date=17 February 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150217074651/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/10/ukraine-draft-dodgers-jail-kiev-struggle-new-fighters |url-status=live }}| nb}} -The website [[Myrotvorets]] has published personal information about journalists.{{cite interview|last=Shutov|first=Roman|interviewer=Adam Reichardt|url=http://www.neweasterneurope.eu/articles-and-commentary/2201-reforming-ukraine-s-media-slow-progress-at-risk|title=Reforming Ukraine's media. comment: Rescuing 7 sources and tagging 0 as dead.) #IABot (v2.0.9.5
llm_output:
**Change Description:** Removed a citation and rephrased the text regarding the establishment of the Ministry of Information Policy in Ukraine, including updates to the references.

**Analysis:** The revision maintains a focus on the Ministry of Information Policy and its role in regulating media, which is a sensitive topic in the context of Ukraine's ongoing conflict with Russia. The changes do not introduce overtly weaponized language but rather update references and clarify the ministry's purpose. However, the context of media regulation in a conflict zone can be interpreted as a means of controlling narratives, which may have implications for cultural heritage and freedom of expression.

**Conclusion:** Not Weaponised – The changes are primarily administrative and do not introduce weaponized language or narratives.

 After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref name="HayozLushnycky2005">{{cite book|last1=Hayoz|first1=Nicolas|last2=Lushnycky|first2=Andrej N.|editor1=Nicolas Hayoz|editor2=Andrej N. llm_output:
Removed the phrase "post-Soviet states" from the context of discussing the freedom of the press in Ukraine.

Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a clarification or correction regarding the classification of countries, rather than an attempt to manipulate cultural narratives or heritage.

 Many Ukrainian journalists found themselves internally displaced due to the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]] and the [[war in Donbass]], including Donetsk-based investigative journalist Oleksiy Matsuka, Luhansk blogger Serhiy Ivanov and Donetsk ''Ostrov'' independent website editor Serhiy Harmash. The entire staff of ''Ostrov'' left the occupied Donbass areas and relocated to Kiev.<ref name=FH/>

 Ukraine moved its class without noticeable borders to say the least at in the form of editing its place to do so from "noticeable problems" (89th place) in 2009 to "difficult situation" (127th place) in 2014 in the [[Press Freedom Index]] by [[Reporters Without Borders]].]]
 The ''[[Freedom in the World]]'' report by [[Freedom House]] rated Ukraine "partly free" from 1992<ref name="Kuchma" /> until 2003, when it was rated "not free".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2003?page=251&year=2003|title=Freedom of the Press 2003|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2003|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> After 2005, it was rated "partly free" again.<ref name="RFH2010">{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2010?page=251&year=2010|title=Freedom of the Press 2010|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="RFH2009">{{cite web|url=https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/freedom-press-2009?page=251&year=2009|title=Freedom of the Press 2009|work=freedomhouse.org|date=2009|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> According to Freedom House [[internet in Ukraine]] is "Free" and [[Press in Ukraine|the press]] is "Partly Free".<ref name="FHUkraine" />{{clarify|date=June 2017|reason=Convoluted. Is it the media or the country being qualified as 'free' and/or 'partly free'? Are civil liberties/human rights and press freedom being conflated?}}
 
-Ukraine's ranking in [[Reporters Without Borders]]s' [[Press Freedom Index]] has long been around the 90th spot (89 in 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2009|work=rsf.org|date=2009|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091022183400/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement1003-2009.html|archive-date=22 October 2009}}</ref> 87 in 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2008|work=rsf.org|date=2008|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090607100340/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement794-2008.html|archive-date=7 June 2009}}</ref>), while it occupied the 112th spot in 2002<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2002|work=rsf.org|date=October 2002|dead-url=y|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703081345/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement298-2002.html|archive-date=3 July 2009}}</ref> and even the 132nd spot in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2004|work=rsf.org|date=2004|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905174452/http://www.rsf.org/en-classement450-2004.html|archivedate=5 September 2009}}</ref> In 2010 it fell to the 131st place; according to Reporters Without Borders this was the result of "the slow and steady deterioration in press freedom since [[2010 Ukrainian presidential election|Viktor Yanukovych's election as president in February]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|title=Press Freedom Index 2010|work=rsf.org|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124050702/http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html|archivedate=24 November 2010|df=dmy}}</ref> In 2013 Ukraine occupied the 126th spot (dropping 10 places compared with 2012); (according to Reporters Without Borders) "the worst record for the media since the [[Orange Revolution]] in 2004".<ref>{{cite web|format=PDF|url=http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|title=Press Freedom Index 2013|work=[[Reporters Without Borders]]|date=2014|accessdate=29 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151013163532/http://fr.rsf.org/IMG/pdf/classement_2013_gb-bd.pdf|archivedate=13 October 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In the 2017 World Press Freedom Index Ukraine was placed 102th.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://rsf.org/en/ranking|title=2017 World Press Freedom Index {{!}} Reporters Without Borders|work=RSF|access-date=2017-12-09|language=en}}</ref>

 During an opinion poll by [[Research & Branding Group]] in October 2009 49.2% of the respondents stated that Ukraine's level of freedom of speech was sufficient, and 19.6% said the opposite. Another 24.2% said that there was too much of freedom of speech in Ukraine. According to the data, 62% of respondents in [[western Ukraine]] considered the level of freedom of speech sufficient, and in the [[Central Ukraine|central]] and southeastern regions the figures were 44% and 47%, respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/half-of-all-ukrainians-consider-current-freedom-of-50721.html|title=Half of all Ukrainians consider current freedom of speech level sufficient|work=[[Kyiv Post]]|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=15 October 2009|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref>

 === Kuchma presidencies (1994-2004) ===
 [[File:Georgi gongadse.jpg|thumbnail|[[Georgiy Gongadze]], [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] journalist, founder of a popular Internet newspaper [[Ukrayinska Pravda]], who was kidnapped and murdered in 2000.]]
 
-After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref name="HayozLushnycky2005">{{cite book|last1=Hayoz|first1=Nicolas|last2=Lushnycky|first2=Andrej N.|editor1=Nicolas Hayoz|editor2=Andrej N. Lushnycky|title=Ukraine at a Crossroads|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC|accessdate=19 June 2017|year=2005|publisher=[[Peter Lang (publisher)|Peter Lang]]|isbn=978-3-03910-468-0|page=21|chapter=Prologue: Ukraine's New Deal}}</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name="Kuchma" /> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemies of the press.<ref name="Kuchma">{{cite book|editor1=Adrian Karatnycky|editor2=Alexander J. Motyl|editor2-link=Alexander J. Motyl|editor3=Amanda Schnetzer|title=Nations in Transit, 2001: Civil Society, Democracy, and Markets in East Central Europe and the Newly Independent States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397|year=2001|publisher=[[Transaction Publishers]]|isbn=978-0-7658-0897-4|page=397}}</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|title=Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=11 March 2010|deadurl=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905041903/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|archivedate=5 September 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (12 March 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name="USDoS1999" /> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name="USDoS2003" /><ref name="USDoS2004" /> Toward the very end of the [[2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name="USDoS2004" />
+After the (only) [[term of office]] of the first [[Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] ended in 1994, the freedom of the press worsened.<ref name="HayozLushnycky2005">{{cite book|last1=Hayoz|first1=Nicolas|last2=Lushnycky|first2=Andrej N.|editor1=Nicolas Hayoz|editor2=Andrej N. Lushnycky|title=Ukraine at a Crossroads|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GYfXtvCujQMC|accessdate=19 June 2017|year=2005|publisher=[[Peter Lang (publisher)|Peter Lang]]|isbn=978-3-03910-468-0|page=21|chapter=Prologue: Ukraine's New Deal}}</ref> During the presidency of [[Leonid Kuchma]] (1994–2004) several news-outlets critical to the him were forcefully closed.<ref name="Kuchma" /> In 1999 the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] placed Kuchma on the list of worst enemies of the press.<ref name="Kuchma">{{cite book|editor1=Adrian Karatnycky|editor2=Alexander J. Motyl|editor2-link=Alexander J. Motyl|editor3=Amanda Schnetzer|title=Nations in Transit, 2001: Civil Society, Democracy, and Markets in East Central Europe and the Newly Independent States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397|year=2001|publisher=[[Transaction Publishers]]|isbn=978-0-7658-0897-4|page=397}}</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|title=Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=11 March 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905041903/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|archivedate=5 September 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (12 March 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name="USDoS1999" /> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name="USDoS2003" /><ref name="USDoS2004" /> Toward the very end of the [[2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name="USDoS2004" />
 
 === Orange revolution and Yushchenko presidency (2004-2010) ===
 Since the [[Orange Revolution]] (of 2004) Ukrainian media has become more pluralistic and independent.<ref name="FHouse2007" /><ref name="organge">[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1068034.html CIS: Press Freedom In Former Soviet Union Under Assault], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (28 April 2006 )</ref><ref name="USDoS2007">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2006/78846.htm 2006 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (6 March 2007)</ref> For instance, attempts by authorities to limit freedom of the press through tax inspections have ceased.<ref name="USDoS2003">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27871.htm 2003 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (25 February 2004)</ref><ref name="USDoS2004">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41715.htm 2004 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (28 February 2005)</ref><ref name="USDoS2000">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/eur/854.htm 2000 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (23 February 2001)</ref><ref name="USDoS2001">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2001/eur/8361.htm 2001 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (4 March 2002)</ref><ref name="USDoS2002">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18398.htm 2002 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (31 March 2003)</ref><ref name="USDoS2005">[https://2009-2017.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2005/61682.htm 2005 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine], [[US Department of State]] (8 March 2006)</ref> Since then the Ukrainian press is considered to be among the freest of all [[post-Soviet states]] (only the [[Baltic states]] are considered "free").<ref name="RFH2009" /><ref name=PoSoStatN1>[https://books.google.com/books?id=1CcQj3DjrHAC&pg=PA39&dq=press+freedom+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=-Jd1TOTTJOGkOJzD5KwG&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CFsQ6AEwBzge#v=onepage&q=press%20freedom%20Ukraine&f=false Ukraine (Country Guide)] by [[Sarah Johnstone]] and [[Greg Bloom]], [[Lonely Planet]], 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-74104-481-2}} (page 39)</ref><ref name="FHouse2007" />
 
 After the 2005 [[Orange Revolution]], Ukrainian television became more free.<ref>[http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews [tt_news]=30800 UKRAINIAN PARTIES SCRAMBLE FOR MEDIA, FOREIGN ALLIES, AHEAD OF PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS], [[The Jamestown Foundation]] (17 August 2005)</ref> In February 2009 the National Council for Television and Radio Broadcasting claimed that "political pressure on mass media increased in recent times through amending laws and other normative acts to strengthen influence on mass media and regulatory bodies in this sphere".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/179018.html|title=National TV Council Claims Harder Political Pressure On Mass Media|publisher=[[Ukrainian News Agency]]|date=6 February 2009}}{{dead link|date=April 2017}}{{cbignore}}</ref>

 On December 30, 2022, President [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy|Volodymyr Zelensky]] signed into law a bill that would expand the power of government to regulate media outlets and journalists in the country, over the objections of journalists and international press freedom groups.<ref name="Dress 2023">{{cite web | last=Dress | first=Brad | title=Zelensky signs controversial law expanding government power to regulate media | website=The Hill | date=2023-01-02 | url=https://thehill.com/homenews/3795160-zelensky-signs-controversial-law-expanding-government-power-to-regulate-media/ | access-date=2024-01-17 | archive-date=17 January 2024 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240117004225/https://thehill.com/homenews/3795160-zelensky-signs-controversial-law-expanding-government-power-to-regulate-media/ | url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="Patil 2022">{{cite web | last=Patil | first=Anushka | title=Zelensky Signs Controversial News Media Regulation | website=The New York Times | date=2022-12-30 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/30/world/europe/zelensky-journalism-law-free-speech.html | access-date=2024-01-17 | archive-date=17 January 2024 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240117004226/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/30/world/europe/zelensky-journalism-law-free-speech.html | url-status=live }}</ref>
 
-According to a [[State Department]] report published in 2023 restrictions were placed on media freedoms enabling "an unprecedented level of control over primetime television news." Some speakers who criticised the government were blacklisted from government-directed news. The outlets and journalists who were considered a threat to the national security and who undermined the country's sovereignty and territorial integrity according to the authorities were blocked, banned or sanctioned.<ref>{{cite web |title=2023 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine |url=https://www.state.gov/reports/2023-country-reports-on-human-rights-practices/ukraine/ |website=U.S. Department of State |access-date=28 April 2024 |archive-date=24 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240424192004/https://www.state.gov/reports/2023-country-reports-on-human-rights-practices/ukraine/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
+According to a [[United States Department of State|State Department]] report published in 2023 restrictions were placed on media freedoms enabling "an unprecedented level of control over primetime television news." Some speakers who criticised the government were blacklisted from government-directed news. The outlets and journalists who were considered a threat to the national security and who undermined the country's sovereignty and territorial integrity according to the authorities were blocked, banned or sanctioned.<ref>{{cite web |title=2023 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices: Ukraine |url=https://www.state.gov/reports/2023-country-reports-on-human-rights-practices/ukraine/ |website=U.S. Department of State |access-date=28 April 2024 |archive-date=24 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240424192004/https://www.state.gov/reports/2023-country-reports-on-human-rights-practices/ukraine/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
 
 === Press freedom scores as perceived by Freedom House ===

 == Opinions ==
 === Independent experts opinions ===
 
-In 2016, an [[Reporters Without Borders|RWB]] member Gemma Pörzgen expressed opinion that "Ukrainian television became a battleground for information warfare and conflicts between oligarchs, and journalists became oligarchs' puppets".  === Intimidation ===

According to the newspaper's statement, Ukrainian officials "block" their contacts with government's speakers and intimidate business to stop cooperative advertising with the newspaper.<ref name="v180">{{Cite web|url=https://meduza.io/news/2024/10/09/redaktsiya-ukrainskoy-pravdy-zayavila-o-sistemnom-davlenii-so-storony-ofisa-prezidenta-ukrainy|title=Редакция «Украинской правды» заявила о «системном давлении» со стороны Офиса президента Украины|lang=ru|website=Meduza|access-date=2024-10-10}}</ref>

Motyl|editor3=Amanda Schnetzer|title=Nations in Transit, 2001: Civil Society, Democracy, and Markets in East Central Europe and the Newly Independent States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R6v0RN-KUUgC&pg=PA397|year=2001|publisher=[[Transaction Publishers]]|isbn=978-0-7658-0897-4|page=397}}</ref> In that year the [[Ukrainian Government]] partially limited freedom of the press through tax inspections ([[Mykola Azarov]], who later became [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], headed the tax authority during Kuchma's presidency<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|title=Biography of new Ukrainian Prime Minister Mykola Azarov|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=11 March 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905041903/http://en.rian.ru/exsoviet/20100311/158161844.html|archive-date=5 September 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html Mykola Azarov: Yanukovych's Right-Hand Man] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100314215451/http://www.rferl.org/content/Mykola_Azarov_Yanukovychs_RightHand_Man_/1982331.html |date=14 March 2010 }}, [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (12 March 2010)</ref>), libel cases, subsidization, and intimidation of journalists; this caused many journalists to practice self-censorship.<ref name="USDoS1999" /> In 2003 and 2004 authorities interfered with the media by issuing written and oral instructions about what events to cover.<ref name="USDoS2003" /><ref name="USDoS2004" /> Toward the very end of the [[2004 Ukrainian presidential election]] campaign in November 2004, many media outlets began to ignore government direction and covered events in a more objective, professional manner.<ref name="USDoS2004" />

 === State pressure ===
-In October of 2024, [[Ukrainska Pravda]] journalists stated that they've been "constantly and continuously pressured" by the [[Office of the President of Ukraine]]. According to the newspaper's statement, Ukrainian officials "block" their contacts with government's speakers and pressure business to stop cooperative advertising with the newspaper.<ref name="v180">{{Cite web|url=https://meduza.io/news/2024/10/09/redaktsiya-ukrainskoy-pravdy-zayavila-o-sistemnom-davlenii-so-storony-ofisa-prezidenta-ukrainy|title=Редакция «Украинской правды» заявила о «системном давлении» со стороны Офиса президента Украины|lang=ru|website=Meduza|access-date=2024-10-10}}</ref>
+In October 2024, [[Ukrainska Pravda]] journalists stated that they've been "constantly and continuously pressured" by the [[Office of the President of Ukraine]]. According to the newspaper's statement, Ukrainian officials "block" their contacts with government's speakers and pressure business to stop cooperative advertising with the newspaper.<ref name="v180">{{Cite web|url=https://meduza.io/news/2024/10/09/redaktsiya-ukrainskoy-pravdy-zayavila-o-sistemnom-davlenii-so-storony-ofisa-prezidenta-ukrainy|title=Редакция "Украинской правды" заявила о "системном давлении" со стороны Офиса президента Украины|language=ru|website=Meduza|access-date=2024-10-10}}</ref>

+On March 3, 2022, the Criminal Code of Ukraine was supplemented by Article 436-2, titled "Justification, recognition as legitimate, denial of the armed aggression of the Russian Federation against Ukraine, glorification of its participants". The article, which has been criticized by the [[OHCHR]] and other human rights groups,<ref>{{cite web  |title=Report On The Human Rights Situation In Ukraine  |url=https://www.ohchr.org/en/documents/country-reports/report-human-rights-situation-ukraine-1-august-2022-31-january-2023  |publisher=OHCHR  |language=English  |access-date=2023-09-21  |archive-date=2023-09-25  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230925201134/https://www.ohchr.org/en/documents/country-reports/report-human-rights-situation-ukraine-1-august-2022-31-january-2023  |url-status=live  }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Criminal liability for collaborationism: analysis of current legislation, practice of its application, and proposals for amendments |date=23 December 2022 |url=https://zmina.ua/en/publication-en/criminal-liability-for-collaborationism-analysis-of-current-legislation-practice-of-its-application-and-proposals-for-amendments/ |publisher=ZMINA |language=English |access-date=21 September 2023 |archive-date=25 July 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230725131437/https://zmina.ua/en/publication-en/criminal-liability-for-collaborationism-analysis-of-current-legislation-practice-of-its-application-and-proposals-for-amendments/ |url-status=live }}</ref> states punishment by correctional labor up to two years or imprisonment up to eight years for such speech.<ref>{{cite web |title=Criminal Code of Ukraine - Amendments |url=https://zakon-rada-gov-ua.translate.goog/laws/show/2110-20/print?_x_tr_sl=auto&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=wapp |publisher=Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine |language=English |access-date=1 February 2024 |archive-date=22 August 2023 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20230822214703/https://zakon-rada-gov-ua.translate.goog/laws/show/2110-20/print?_x_tr_sl=auto&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=wapp |url-status=bot: unknown }}</ref> [[Gonzalo Lira]], an American pro-Russia blogger who died in custody<ref>{{cite news |title=The tragic end of Gonzalo Lira: A voice silenced in Ukraine |url=https://www.helsinkitimes.fi/world-int/24744-the-tragic-end-of-gonzalo-lira-a-voice-silenced-in-ukraine.html |access-date=14 April 2025 |work=Helsinki Times |date=13 January 2024 |language=en-gb}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Quinn |first1=Allison |title=U.S. Says Dating Coach-Turned-Kremlin Shill Died in Ukraine |url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/american-dating-coach-turned-blogger-gonzalo-lira-dies-in-ukraine/ |access-date=14 April 2025 |work=The Daily Beast |date=17 January 2024 |language=en}}</ref> in Ukraine, was among those arrested under this law.<ref name="Shoaib 2023 y699">{{cite web | last=Shoaib | first=Alia | title=Tucker Carlson and Elon Musk have rallied behind an American 'red pill' dating coach turned Russian propagandist detained in Ukraine | website=Business Insider | date=2023-12-17 | url=https://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musk-tucker-carlson-us-red-pill-youtuber-detained-ukraine-2023-12 | access-date=2024-01-17 | archive-date=12 January 2024 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240112201545/https://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musk-tucker-carlson-us-red-pill-youtuber-detained-ukraine-2023-12 | url-status=live }}</ref>
 
 On December 30, 2022, President [[Volodymyr Zelenskyy|Volodymyr Zelensky]] signed into law a bill that would expand the power of government to regulate media outlets and journalists in the country, over the objections of journalists and international press freedom groups.<ref name="Dress 2023">{{cite web | last=Dress | first=Brad | title=Zelensky signs controversial law expanding government power to regulate media | website=The Hill | date=2023-01-02 | url=https://thehill.com/homenews/3795160-zelensky-signs-controversial-law-expanding-government-power-to-regulate-media/ | access-date=2024-01-17 | archive-date=17 January 2024 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240117004225/https://thehill.com/homenews/3795160-zelensky-signs-controversial-law-expanding-government-power-to-regulate-media/ | url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="Patil 2022">{{cite web | last=Patil | first=Anushka | title=Zelensky Signs Controversial News Media Regulation | website=The New York Times | date=2022-12-30 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/30/world/europe/zelensky-journalism-law-free-speech.html | access-date=2024-01-17 | archive-date=17 January 2024 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240117004226/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/30/world/europe/zelensky-journalism-law-free-speech.html | url-status=live }}</ref>
comment: /* Russian invasion and Zelensky presidency (2019-present) */ Gonzalo Lira is no longer "living in Ukraine"
llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the removal of the phrase "living in Ukraine" in reference to Gonzalo Lira, and the addition of the phrase "who died in custody" to describe him.

**Change Description:** Removed "living in Ukraine" and added "who died in custody".

**Analysis:** The revision shifts the narrative surrounding Gonzalo Lira from a neutral description of his status to a more charged statement that implies a tragic outcome and potential victimization. This change could be interpreted as an attempt to frame Lira's situation in a way that elicits sympathy and highlights perceived injustices, which can be a form of weaponization of cultural heritage by invoking themes of oppression and martyrdom.

**Conclusion:** Weaponised. The language shift emphasizes victimhood and could be used to manipulate perceptions regarding the treatment of individuals in the context of the conflict.

The [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]] was covered with a wide variety of political orientations in the media. Minor cases of pressures or censorship attempts were reported in 2014 too. In [[Kirovohrad]] in December 2014 a regional politician ordered a subordinate to review the ''Zorya'' newspaper before its publication. -[[Censorship]] issues were debated in 2015 concerning aggressive propaganda from Russian state-owned news outlets to support the Russian annexation of [[Crimea]], encourage separatism in [[Donbas]] and discredit the Kyiv government. 28 February 2015 -| '''[[Serhiy Nikolayev]]''', photojournalist for ''Segodnya'' in Kyiv, Ukraine, killed by shelling crossfire.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/01/ukrainian-photographer-killed-in-fighting|title=Ukrainian photographer killed in fighting|work=The Guardian}} +| '''[[Serhiy Nikolayev]]''', photojournalist for ''Segodnya'' in Kyiv, Ukraine, killed by shelling crossfire.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/01/ukrainian-photographer-killed-in-fighting|title=Ukrainian photographer killed in fighting|work=The Guardian|date=March 2015 |last1=France-Presse |first1=Agence }} |- !data-sort-value="2015-04-01" | April 2015 | '''[[Olga Moroz (journalist)|Olga Moroz]]''', editor of the ''Neteshinsky Vestnik''{{cite news|url=https://www.novinite.com/articles/167954/Another+Ukrainian+Journalist+Found+Dead%2C+Murder+Suspected|title=Another Ukrainian Journalist Found Dead, Murder Suspected|work=Novinte|location=Sofia, Bulgaria|date=17 April 2022|access-date=31 January 2022}} @@ -515,10 +517,10 @@ | '''[[Oles Buzina]]''', journalist and writer.[http://www.france24.com/en/20150416-ukraine-prominent-journalist-oles-buzina-shot-dead-kiev/ Prominent Pro-Russian Ukrainian journalist killed in Kiev] |- ! 20 July 2016 -|'''[[Pavel Sheremet]]''' Belarusian journalist, who was a critic of [[Media freedom in Russia|Russian censorship]], killed by a car bomb.{{Cite web |title=Pavel Sheremet, Journalist in Ukraine, Is Killed in Car Bombing |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/21/world/europe/pavel-sheremet-kiev-car-bomb.html?_r=0 |access-date=2024-09-13}}{{Cite news |last=Luhn |first=Alec |date=2016-07-20 |title=Car bomb kills pioneering journalist Pavel Sheremet in Kiev |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/20/ukraine-journalist-pavel-sheremet-killed-kiev-car-bombing |access-date=2024-09-13 |work=The Guardian |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077}}{{Cite web |title=Journalist's murder shocks Ukraine – DW – 07/20/2016 |url=https://www.dw.com/en/journalist-pavel-sheremets-murder-shocks-ukraine/a-19414665 |access-date=2024-09-13 |website=dw.com |language=en}} +|'''[[Pavel Sheremet]]''' Belarusian journalist, who was a critic of [[Media freedom in Russia|Russian censorship]], killed by a car bomb.{{Cite web |title=Pavel Sheremet, Journalist in Ukraine, Is Killed in Car Bombing | website=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/21/world/europe/pavel-sheremet-kiev-car-bomb.html?_r=0 |access-date=2024-09-13}}{{Cite news |last=Luhn |first=Alec |date=2016-07-20 |title=Car bomb kills pioneering journalist Pavel Sheremet in Kiev |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/20/ukraine-journalist-pavel-sheremet-killed-kiev-car-bombing |access-date=2024-09-13 |work=The Guardian |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077}}{{Cite web |title=Journalist's murder shocks Ukraine – DW – 07/20/2016 |url=https://www.dw.com/en/journalist-pavel-sheremets-murder-shocks-ukraine/a-19414665 |access-date=2024-09-13 |website=dw.com |language=en}} |- ! He was shot by Russian soldiers.{{Cite web |title=Brent Renaud, an American journalist, is killed in Ukraine. |website=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/13/world/europe/brent-renaud-irpin.html |access-date=2024-09-13}} |- ! 15 March 2022 | '''[[Pierre Zakrzewski]]''' had been travelling in a vehicle near Kyiv; he was killed by Russian soldiers.{{Cite web |title=Ukraine war: Fox News cameraman and Ukrainian journalist killed in attack near Kyiv |url=https://news.sky.com/story/ukraine-war-fox-news-cameraman-killed-by-incoming-fire-outside-of-kyiv-12566885 |access-date=2024-09-13 |website=Sky News |language=en}} @@ -650,7 +652,7 @@ == Opinions == === Independent experts opinions === -In 2016, an [[Reporters Without Borders|RWB]] member Gemma Pörzgen expressed opinion that "Ukrainian television became a battleground for information warfare and conflicts between oligarchs, and journalists became oligarchs' puppets". She also states in her research that [[Donbas war]] and [[russian propaganda]] have a significant impact on the Ukraine's media landscape that, she says, "lead to government's countermeasures", one of which is broadcasting prohibition for Russian TV channels, TV series and Russian movies.{{Cite web |url=http://obozrevatel.com/politics/70425-doklad-o-smi-ukrainyi-svet-i-teni.htm |title=«Отрезвление»: «Репортеры без границ» оценили свободу слова в Украине |access-date=2024-11-19 |archive-date=2016-07-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708155256/http://obozrevatel.com/politics/70425-doklad-o-smi-ukrainyi-svet-i-teni.htm |url-status=live }} +In 2016, an [[Reporters Without Borders|RWB]] member Gemma Pörzgen expressed opinion that "Ukrainian television became a battleground for information warfare and conflicts between oligarchs, and journalists became oligarchs' puppets". She also states in her research that [[Donbas war]] and [[russian propaganda]] have a significant impact on the Ukraine's media landscape that, she says, "lead to government's countermeasures", one of which is broadcasting prohibition for Russian TV channels, TV series and Russian movies.{{Cite web |url=http://obozrevatel.com/politics/70425-doklad-o-smi-ukrainyi-svet-i-teni.htm |title=«Отрезвление»: «Репортеры без границ» оценили свободу слова в Украине |date=3 June 2016 |access-date=2024-11-19 |archive-date=2016-07-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160708155256/http://obozrevatel.com/politics/70425-doklad-o-smi-ukrainyi-svet-i-teni.htm |url-status=live }} === Intimidation === In October of 2024, [[Ukrainska Pravda]] journalists stated that they've been "constantly and continuously intimidated" by the [[Office of the President of Ukraine]]. According to the newspaper's statement, Ukrainian officials "block" their contacts with government's speakers and intimidate business to stop cooperative advertising with the newspaper.{{Cite web|url=https://meduza.io/news/2024/10/09/redaktsiya-ukrainskoy-pravdy-zayavila-o-sistemnom-davlenii-so-storony-ofisa-prezidenta-ukrainy|title=Редакция «Украинской правды» заявила о «системном давлении» со стороны Офиса президента Украины|lang=ru|website=Meduza|access-date=2024-10-10}}
